Posts.Content: If it's a single core of G6, with 2.5% involvement, and .15 cm; then yes, Active Surveillance could make sense as long as he is "wired" for AS (you on the other hand, like many others, may not be, and are in the "get it out" category - no right or wrong answer...) One thing a lot of us would strongly suggest is to have the slides sent out for a second opinion to be sure that's a G6... Also, please read the "AS" sticky, it contains a lot of good info. Did your Dad go through a full physical and blood work including vitamin levels? If not, that may be a good next step. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Dads biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Read "What I wish I knew before i chose Active Surveillance" (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...e-Surveillance), the thread mentioned some additional tests which can be done as part of AS. Walt's "AS Diet" in that thread is also a nice read. Also, consider having your slides read by someone in a "Center of Excellence" to confirm it's a "true" 6 and nothing borderline. For your next biopsy, discuss with your urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" and doing some sort of "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... If that second (saturation) biopsy only shows Gleason 6, and the other tests look good, you have a reason to consider extending your AS. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Affordable Viagra?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick Really great. 3 weeks post-RP, feel 100%, very slight incontinence. Glad to hear you're doing Great! Originally Posted by dshinnick I know I need to ask my Dr. this, but I get faster answers here, and I like asking folks who've been through it. Good to hear, and please stick around to "give back" and help others.... Originally Posted by dshinnick 1. I'm feeling the need to play some pickleball (kinda like tennis; Youtube it). It is aggressive exercise. When should I think about trying it? My surgeon insisted I wait six weeks before doing anything aggressive without exception using the threat of putting the catheter back in if I do anything "stupid" . I'm sure I could have started a week or two sooner but I decided to heed his advice. Originally Posted by dshinnick 2. I drink a lot of coffee in the morning, and since the catheter came out, it's been decaf. We usually drink a half-decaf coffee. How much of an irritant is caffeine on the bladder? Are we trying to go easy on the bladder, or on the new bladder/urethra suture? And how long do we need to be concerned about it? I believe it would be stitches and the general healing. I started drinking some regular coffee after a month (and noticed the difference, in both how I felt and an increase in leakage) and then cut back until I found a good middle ground and then slowly increased it again

Posts.Title: Doing great.

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". Since robotic takes more time. It was basically upside down during the surgery and you are "under" for a longer time (notthat you know that of course), so it places slightly more strain on the body. It is not recommended if you have a previous heath condition such as a heart condition. At your age the vast majority of us would recommend robotic. It is less invasive and the healing time is quicker. In fact,many of us had to "hold back" from exercising and lifting heavy items as the stitches outside were gone rather quickly but there was still a lot of healing to be done inside. I believe there is some research which indicates that robotic has a slightly higher success rate with incontinence since some surgeons report that it is easier to stitch up the muscles down there. But as everyone has stressed, the most important thing is the experience of the surgeon. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: do i have pc?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind A skilled urologist using a modern ultrasound guided biopsy tool has about a 90% chance of finding any cancer present.. 10% of the time, they don't find it, at least not the first time.. It took them 3 tries to find mine...Your insurance company has some rather strict rules about what they will pay for and what they won't. Your tissue samples will go to a local pathology lab. Unless there is reason to doubt their findings, ordering an expert second opinion could cost you $800 if your insurance company balks.... Not a bad idea to call the insurance company first and "pave the road" for a second opinion on the slides, and ask up-front about sending the slides out. It seems some places have never done it before, charge extra, etc (which is an extra cause of stress just when you don't need it)

Posts.Title: Questions to ask Pre-Biopsy?

Posts.Content: Read "What I wish I knew before i chose Active Surveillance" (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...e-Surveillance), the thread mentioned some additional tests which can be done as part of AS. Walt's "AS Diet" in that thread is also a nice read. Also, consider having your slides read by someone in a "Center of Excellence" to confirm it's a "true" 6 and nothing borderline. For your next biopsy, discuss with your urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" and doing some sort of "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... If that second (saturation) biopsy only shows Gleason 6, and the other tests look good, you have a reason to consider extending your AS. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance or Extended Preparation Time for Treatment?

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". Since robotic takes more time. It was basically upside down during the surgery and you are "under" for a longer time (notthat you know that of course), so it places slightly more strain on the body. It is not recommended if you have a previous heath condition such as a heart condition. At your age the vast majority of us would recommend robotic. It is less invasive and the healing time is quicker. In fact,many of us had to "hold back" from exercising and lifting heavy items as the stitches outside were gone rather quickly but there was still a lot of healing to be done inside. I believe there is some research which indicates that robotic has a slightly higher success rate with incontinence since some surgeons report that it is easier to stitch up the muscles down there. But as everyone has stressed, the most important thing is the experience of the surgeon. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: I was diagnosed 3 weeks ago with prostate cancer. Type of surgery.

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". It does sound like the doctors want to "starve" any cells as soon as possible to ensure it doesn't spread. My totally uneducated opinion is that it sounds like a good idea since at least with surgery you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy and you want to make sure it doesn't spread while you wait. (Not sure if the waiting is also true for radiation or not). Since you need to be treated as quickly as possible, I suggest you schedule surgery while you research radiation. That way if you decide on surgery your spot is "reserved" without any delay. If you decide on radiation, then simply cancel the surgery. Good luck

Posts.Content: Read the stickies and some of the detailed posts by praeto and others who went through exactly what your going to go through only a short time ago. While no case is identical, they all share some commonalities. It's a bump in the road. As hard as it may seem now of for the first two weeks after your surgery, it really is a bump in the road. Share your experiences so others may benefit as well. Good luck, see you on the other side (and hopefully the "zero" side)

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: If it's a single core of G6, with 2.5% involvement, and .15 cm; then yes, Active Surveillance could make sense as long as he is "wired" for AS (you on the other hand, like many others, may not be, and are in the "get it out" category - no right or wrong answer...) One thing a lot of us would strongly suggest is to have the slides sent out for a second opinion to be sure that's a G6... Also, please read the "AS" sticky, it contains a lot of good info. Did your Dad go through a full physical and blood work including vitamin levels? If not, that may be a good next step. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Affordable Viagra?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind A skilled urologist using a modern ultrasound guided biopsy tool has about a 90% chance of finding any cancer present.. 10% of the time, they don't find it, at least not the first time.. It took them 3 tries to find mine...Your insurance company has some rather strict rules about what they will pay for and what they won't. Your tissue samples will go to a local pathology lab. Unless there is reason to doubt their findings, ordering an expert second opinion could cost you $800 if your insurance company balks.... Not a bad idea to call the insurance company first and "pave the road" for a second opinion on the slides, and ask up-front about sending the slides out. It seems some places have never done it before, charge extra, etc (which is an extra cause of stress just when you don't need it)

Posts.Title: Questions to ask Pre-Biopsy?

Posts.Content: Read the stickies and some of the detailed posts by praeto and others who went through exactly what your going to go through only a short time ago. While no case is identical, they all share some commonalities. It's a bump in the road. As hard as it may seem now of for the first two weeks after your surgery, it really is a bump in the road. Share your experiences so others may benefit as well. Good luck, see you on the other side (and hopefully the "zero" side)

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick Really great. 3 weeks post-RP, feel 100%, very slight incontinence. Glad to hear you're doing Great! Originally Posted by dshinnick I know I need to ask my Dr. this, but I get faster answers here, and I like asking folks who've been through it. Good to hear, and please stick around to "give back" and help others.... Originally Posted by dshinnick 1. I'm feeling the need to play some pickleball (kinda like tennis; Youtube it). It is aggressive exercise. When should I think about trying it? My surgeon insisted I wait six weeks before doing anything aggressive without exception using the threat of putting the catheter back in if I do anything "stupid" . I'm sure I could have started a week or two sooner but I decided to heed his advice. Originally Posted by dshinnick 2. I drink a lot of coffee in the morning, and since the catheter came out, it's been decaf. We usually drink a half-decaf coffee. How much of an irritant is caffeine on the bladder? Are we trying to go easy on the bladder, or on the new bladder/urethra suture? And how long do we need to be concerned about it? I believe it would be stitches and the general healing. I started drinking some regular coffee after a month (and noticed the difference, in both how I felt and an increase in leakage) and then cut back until I found a good middle ground and then slowly increased it again

Posts.Title: do i have pc?

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". Since robotic takes more time. It was basically upside down during the surgery and you are "under" for a longer time (notthat you know that of course), so it places slightly more strain on the body. It is not recommended if you have a previous heath condition such as a heart condition. At your age the vast majority of us would recommend robotic. It is less invasive and the healing time is quicker. In fact,many of us had to "hold back" from exercising and lifting heavy items as the stitches outside were gone rather quickly but there was still a lot of healing to be done inside. I believe there is some research which indicates that robotic has a slightly higher success rate with incontinence since some surgeons report that it is easier to stitch up the muscles down there. But as everyone has stressed, the most important thing is the experience of the surgeon. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: I was diagnosed 3 weeks ago with prostate cancer. Type of surgery.

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". It does sound like the doctors want to "starve" any cells as soon as possible to ensure it doesn't spread. My totally uneducated opinion is that it sounds like a good idea since at least with surgery you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy and you want to make sure it doesn't spread while you wait. (Not sure if the waiting is also true for radiation or not). Since you need to be treated as quickly as possible, I suggest you schedule surgery while you research radiation. That way if you decide on surgery your spot is "reserved" without any delay. If you decide on radiation, then simply cancel the surgery. Good luck

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: Don't know if is too late, but you should consider having a "MRI-Guided" biopsy. (Others will know the details). A state-of-the-art MRI is used in conjunction with the biopsy to ensure that the biopsy is targeting any areas of concern. Some of us aren't "wired" for AS and believe that since there's about a 20% chance of a biopsy missing PC or even that they can't stand the idea of even low-grade PC "growing" inside of them (and there's no right or wrong answer). Others (like you) are "wired". You (in consultation with your Dr) need to decide on what is your "tipping point" when you go off of AS and seek active treatment. If the biopsy test wasn't that bad then don't take a Valium unless you feel the need to. Also, read the "AS" sticky. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Rise in PSA with last positive biopsy 3 years ago

Posts.Content: I had my one year PSA in July and it was a big fat ZERO. My surgeon day I was on a one-year schedule and have it every July...... I decided that for my own sanity I would have my physical in January and have another PSA test, in order to keep me on a six month schedule. Well, after a few delays due to snowstorms, I finally had my PSA test... Glad to say ANOTHER ZERO. I'm gonna keep it every six months..... makes me feel better if nothing else.

Posts.Title: Concerned about upcoming biopsy

Posts.Content: This is dedicated to our future Da Vinci friends (Such as Ralph P)... In no particular order, most of this stuff was probably mentioned or I read a dozen times but somehow it either never penetrated my thick skull or I did not put enough importance to it: Make the nurse go through how to use the catheter several times. DO IT YOURSELF. You make think you get it but you really don't Bacitracin (or whatever ointment your Dr likes) is your friend. ask the Dr beforehand so you have plenty at home Your catheter pee will be red for a while. don't be too alarmed. Some Drs give you a color chart to match up the colors with your progress. You may have a low-grade fever. Have a towel on top of your pillow when sleeping. Don't be to alarmed but call the Dr if it goes over 101 degrees. If you have a recliner, plan on using it to sleep. I could not even imagine getting in and out of a regular bed sleep in the recliner overnight a few days before the surgery. That way the first time won't be the first time immediately after the surgery. For a few days after the surgery, you will need someone to help you push the recliner in and help to get up onto your feet.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: This is dedicated to our future Da Vinci friends (Such as Ralph P)... In no particular order, most of this stuff was probably mentioned or I read a dozen times but somehow it either never penetrated my thick skull or I did not put enough importance to it: Make the nurse go through how to use the catheter several times. DO IT YOURSELF. You make think you get it but you really don't Bacitracin (or whatever ointment your Dr likes) is your friend. ask the Dr beforehand so you have plenty at home Your catheter pee will be red for a while. don't be too alarmed. Some Drs give you a color chart to match up the colors with your progress. You may have a low-grade fever. Have a towel on top of your pillow when sleeping. Don't be to alarmed but call the Dr if it goes over 101 degrees. If you have a recliner, plan on using it to sleep. I could not even imagine getting in and out of a regular bed sleep in the recliner overnight a few days before the surgery. That way the first time won't be the first time immediately after the surgery. For a few days after the surgery, you will need someone to help you push the recliner in and help to get up onto your feet.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: This is dedicated to our future Da Vinci friends (Such as Ralph P)... In no particular order, most of this stuff was probably mentioned or I read a dozen times but somehow it either never penetrated my thick skull or I did not put enough importance to it: Make the nurse go through how to use the catheter several times. DO IT YOURSELF. You make think you get it but you really don't Bacitracin (or whatever ointment your Dr likes) is your friend. ask the Dr beforehand so you have plenty at home Your catheter pee will be red for a while. don't be too alarmed. Some Drs give you a color chart to match up the colors with your progress. You may have a low-grade fever. Have a towel on top of your pillow when sleeping. Don't be to alarmed but call the Dr if it goes over 101 degrees. If you have a recliner, plan on using it to sleep. I could not even imagine getting in and out of a regular bed sleep in the recliner overnight a few days before the surgery. That way the first time won't be the first time immediately after the surgery. For a few days after the surgery, you will need someone to help you push the recliner in and help to get up onto your feet.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: here's a link which works for me: http://www.foxnews.com/health/2014/0...-surveillance/ But Otago's article puts everything in perspective. Sounds like some people were really not good candidates for AS in the first place. - 415/848 patients had Gleason 3 + 3 = 6 disease on initial biopsy? So the majority of people were G7 or above??? Which Dr would recommend AS in that case? What would be most interesting would be the outcome for the 24 percent, who also had two or less cores involved. AND exactly what their "Active Surveillance" entailed. Was it just testing PSA every 6 months? Or something more "Active"?

Posts.Title: Current Tools To Identify AS Candidates Not Accurate

Posts.Content: My first biopsy was negative, and another biopsy was recommended after my six month PSA retest increased once again. (Which was positive, see my sig). My regret was that I did not do all of my research for treatment options during those six months and felt like I was "drinking water from a fire hose" Once the second biopsy was positive. If I were you, I would review all treatment options now and then put your notes away and hope you never have to refer to them again. But if you do, you'll be prepared and well ahead of time. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Any need for second opinion on negative biopsy?

Posts.Content: There's a saying "Hope for the best but prepare for the worst". Plan on very frequent PSA testing (say every six weeks for at least six months) and have a treatment path for salvage radiation and possibly hormone treatment already planned out if needed. Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: This is dedicated to our future Da Vinci friends (Such as Ralph P)... In no particular order, most of this stuff was probably mentioned or I read a dozen times but somehow it either never penetrated my thick skull or I did not put enough importance to it: Make the nurse go through how to use the catheter several times. DO IT YOURSELF. You make think you get it but you really don't Bacitracin (or whatever ointment your Dr likes) is your friend. ask the Dr beforehand so you have plenty at home Your catheter pee will be red for a while. don't be too alarmed. Some Drs give you a color chart to match up the colors with your progress. You may have a low-grade fever. Have a towel on top of your pillow when sleeping. Don't be to alarmed but call the Dr if it goes over 101 degrees. If you have a recliner, plan on using it to sleep. I could not even imagine getting in and out of a regular bed sleep in the recliner overnight a few days before the surgery. That way the first time won't be the first time immediately after the surgery. For a few days after the surgery, you will need someone to help you push the recliner in and help to get up onto your feet.

Posts.Title: Husband recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: My surgeon likes to have PSA taken after one month, and three months after that (which was a Zero), and today, three months later (month seven). He asked on a scale of 1-10 how active things were "down there". I told him a three. He looked me up and said I was a two last time, so he was encouraged. He told me to continue the Viagra/Cialis... A few other points: He personally likes the injection rather than the pump. He said that the "rocco stitch" was big a while ago, but most surgeons nowadays reconstruct the external urinary sphincter, which is much easier to do with Robotic Surgery. If I stay a member of the "Zero Club", I don't have to come back for six months I'll know the results in a week or so, which me luck...

Posts.Title: Seven month follow-up

Posts.Content: Some sort of "targeted" biopsy (MRI-targeted?) or saturation biopsy sounds like a good idea. Get your vitamin-D level checked as well, as there's some research which show a relationship between low vitamin D and PCa. Good luck

Posts.Title: PCA3 High ????

Posts.Content: here's a link which works for me: http://www.foxnews.com/health/2014/0...-surveillance/ But Otago's article puts everything in perspective. Sounds like some people were really not good candidates for AS in the first place. - 415/848 patients had Gleason 3 + 3 = 6 disease on initial biopsy? So the majority of people were G7 or above??? Which Dr would recommend AS in that case? What would be most interesting would be the outcome for the 24 percent, who also had two or less cores involved. AND exactly what their "Active Surveillance" entailed. Was it just testing PSA every 6 months? Or something more "Active"?

Posts.Title: Current Tools To Identify AS Candidates Not Accurate

Posts.Content: This is dedicated to our future Da Vinci friends (Such as Ralph P)... In no particular order, most of this stuff was probably mentioned or I read a dozen times but somehow it either never penetrated my thick skull or I did not put enough importance to it: Make the nurse go through how to use the catheter several times. DO IT YOURSELF. You make think you get it but you really don't Bacitracin (or whatever ointment your Dr likes) is your friend. ask the Dr beforehand so you have plenty at home Your catheter pee will be red for a while. don't be too alarmed. Some Drs give you a color chart to match up the colors with your progress. You may have a low-grade fever. Have a towel on top of your pillow when sleeping. Don't be to alarmed but call the Dr if it goes over 101 degrees. If you have a recliner, plan on using it to sleep. I could not even imagine getting in and out of a regular bed sleep in the recliner overnight a few days before the surgery. That way the first time won't be the first time immediately after the surgery. For a few days after the surgery, you will need someone to help you push the recliner in and help to get up onto your feet.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Flkjr Congratulations on the wood! Seeing that I had my surgery a day before you, I consider myself late in achieving the same. I am still hopeful that I have the same issue shortly, pain or no pain! LOL Fran Well, I wouldn't call it "hard wood", more like balsa... But it was still there, in the middle of the night, without any help from "Mr Palm and his five friends"... Anyway, I went to the Dr, he tool a urine culture (clean), he looked and pulled and poked around and didn't find anything. So maybe it was just some irritation, and said not to worry about it and be very glad that my little friend seem to be awaking from his almost year-long hibernation. He also said that he wants PSA level every six months for now, so he suggested that I schedulie his annual visit for August and my standard physical in January.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: There's a saying "Hope for the best but prepare for the worst". Plan on very frequent PSA testing (say every six weeks for at least six months) and have a treatment path for salvage radiation and possibly hormone treatment already planned out if needed. Good luck, we have your hubby's membership in the Zero Club already written out!

Posts.Title: Husband recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lzicc I believe at first I'll need to have my PSA check every 6 months. I did go regularly anyhow prior to this since I was on testosterone replacement. I just want some kind of peace of mind knowing that the cancer is gone. I guess there is no way of really knowing. Even though my surgeon says I'm on an annual schedule for checking PSA, I'm scheduling my annual physical and annual visit with my surgeon six months apart. It will make me feel a little better that I'll be testing my PSA every six months.

Posts.Title: When I get post PSA test done

Posts.Content: My first biopsy was negative, and another biopsy was recommended after my six month PSA retest increased once again. (Which was positive, see my sig). My regret was that I did not do all of my research for treatment options during those six months and felt like I was "drinking water from a fire hose" Once the second biopsy was positive. If I were you, I would review all treatment options now and then put your notes away and hope you never have to refer to them again. But if you do, you'll be prepared and well ahead of time. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Any need for second opinion on negative biopsy?

Posts.Content: My surgeon likes to have PSA taken after one month, and three months after that (which was a Zero), and today, three months later (month seven). He asked on a scale of 1-10 how active things were "down there". I told him a three. He looked me up and said I was a two last time, so he was encouraged. He told me to continue the Viagra/Cialis... A few other points: He personally likes the injection rather than the pump. He said that the "rocco stitch" was big a while ago, but most surgeons nowadays reconstruct the external urinary sphincter, which is much easier to do with Robotic Surgery. If I stay a member of the "Zero Club", I don't have to come back for six months I'll know the results in a week or so, which me luck...

Posts.Title: Seven month follow-up

Posts.Content: I had my one year PSA in July and it was a big fat ZERO. My surgeon day I was on a one-year schedule and have it every July...... I decided that for my own sanity I would have my physical in January and have another PSA test, in order to keep me on a six month schedule. Well, after a few delays due to snowstorms, I finally had my PSA test... Glad to say ANOTHER ZERO. I'm gonna keep it every six months..... makes me feel better if nothing else.

Posts.Title: Where are the best doctors for prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: 10 months almost to the day after my surgery. Woke up with some nice "wood" last night and felt a few "twinges" during the day... (Made it a point to check out as many pretty girls as possible, for medical reasons of course). Overall, I was quite happy about this.. Until... Now I've had some sharp pain at the tip of my penis a few times today. It lasts for a few seconds each time. Almost like a pinch. Not too intense, but enough for me take notice for sure. It seems to have nothing to do with urinating. I called the service and the Dr said it doesn't sound like anything to worry about, and make a followup with my surgeon. (Which I will...) Has anyone experienced anything like this? Thanks!

Posts.Title: September is National Prostate Cancer Awareness Month

Posts.Content: As Jim pointed out, you are doing a great job of staying on top of things. I had a PCA3 test after a DRE. I don't remember it as being any more rigorous than a normal DRE but then again I didn't exactly keep score. I believe the PCA3 test will only be positive if there's bilateral PC. Have you inquired about a T3-MRI? At a minimum, it would give your urologist a good baseline for the future. And if anything seems suspicious, the biopsy would be targeted to those areas (I think that's called a "MRI Targeted biopsy") I think that would make sense, especially if you have a large prostate, which I believe would mean that a standard biopsy would have an even less change of finding anything. We hope you never have to join our "club" for many years if at all, but if you do, you can be comforted by the fact that your doing an excellent job of staying on top of things

Posts.Title: Where to from here

Posts.Content: A reluctant welcome to our "club". Based on your stats, you do need treatment, it's just a matter of what is best for you. (which you need to decide based on your age, physical health, etc). Not sure of your age and general health, as your heart condition may lead you to one type of treatment over another. (Robotic surgery is harder on the body during the initial surgery, as you are basically lying at a 45 degree angle upside down, and I believe you are under longer and "deeper" -- although recovery is a bit faster.). Not sure of your age and health, but if your cardiologist and urologist believe surgery is an option, then I would research surgeons (both open and robotic - the most important thing is EXPERIENCE) and *schedule* the surgery. You'll need about six weeks for your prostate to heal. Also research other treatments such as radiation... You can cancel the surgery if you decide on other treatment, but if you decide to go through with the surgery then your spot is "reserved" and you'll never have to second guess yourself about waiting more than the six weeks (athough with G6, your decision does not have to be a rush-job). Good luck!

Posts.Title: OT: Happy Fathers Day

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JoeInBucks I found that you can over the Kegels. Not sure If the analogy is perfect but like working out or lifting weights you typically don't work the same body part two days in a row. I think I was over doing it early after my operation. I'm sort of on a one day on one day off routine now. Seems to work better. Stopped using any pads or shields about 2 - 2 1/2 months after the operation. The progress is not linear at all at least for me. I found this as well. Your pee-muscles have been traumatized. And they aren't big like a bicep or chest muscle to begin with. They have to work anyway even without kegels. Don't overdo the kegels, and think about giving the poor muscle a day free from kegels on a regular basis.

Posts.Title: Best post surgery pads

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JoeInBucks I found that you can over the Kegels. Not sure If the analogy is perfect but like working out or lifting weights you typically don't work the same body part two days in a row. I think I was over doing it early after my operation. I'm sort of on a one day on one day off routine now. Seems to work better. Stopped using any pads or shields about 2 - 2 1/2 months after the operation. The progress is not linear at all at least for me. I found this as well. Your pee-muscles have been traumatized. And they aren't big like a bicep or chest muscle to begin with. They have to work anyway even without kegels. Don't overdo the kegels, and think about giving the poor muscle a day free from kegels on a regular basis.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Don't put too much emphasis on the PSA today. One month from surgery seems like an awfully quick expectation because, even if you are fully "cured", the PSA may not have had enough time to clear completely out of your bloodstream. My recollection is that a PSA at the 90-day mark after surgery should provide a more definitive overview. Good luck. My surgeon likes the first test to be at six weeks, in some ways more of a baseline for the 90-day PSA test than anything else. Good Luck

Posts.Title: 1 month post op PSA check.

Posts.Content: Caverject was covered by my insurance, so I suggested to my uro that we try that first. There's also no compounding pharmacy nearby so it would be a bit of a hassle for me to go to one. While I had nerve-sparing DaVinci, I never fully recovered and would basically make it to 60% for short periods of time so our hope was that the Caverject would be enough for me to make it to the next step. The doc was careful not to overdo it the first time (he warned me multiple times about erections over 4 hours long. I told him I would like to experience a full three-hour full erection at least once... I received six vials full of powder and needed to add the distilled(?) water to one of them. No big deal. Anyway, the doc showed me where to inject myself and made me do it. 15 units. I felt a slight twinge. Wouldn't call it painful. Just... Different... I felt a bit of warmth in area around the shot for a few minutes. Anyway after 10 minutes, my little friend started to wake up. I reached about 60% of firmness, but this was different as I wasn't helping myself or thinking about naughty stuff. It was like a spontaneous boner we all use to get for no reason when we were teens. I definitely felt areas of my little (well, maybe not so little) friend stretching out and waking up. Areas which haven't been stretched out like that for over two years The doc came back in and he said it looked good. I asked him if I could have a lap dance with the pretty receptionist. He agreed that she was cute but it probably wouldn't be a good idea for him to ask her LOL. I felt that in the correct setting with 20 units and some help from porn or the wifey) I would have achieved some "real" wood. Maybe not raging-boner-hang-wet-towels wood, but good enough. My next step is to do the 20 in a couple of days. I'm keeping the mix in the fridge. After the vials are used up, the doc agreed that if either I'll get a refill or "graduate" to trimix.

Posts.Title: Trimix update

Posts.Content: Caverject was covered by my insurance, so I suggested to my uro that we try that first. There's also no compounding pharmacy nearby so it would be a bit of a hassle for me to go to one. While I had nerve-sparing DaVinci, I never fully recovered and would basically make it to 60% for short periods of time so our hope was that the Caverject would be enough for me to make it to the next step. The doc was careful not to overdo it the first time (he warned me multiple times about erections over 4 hours long. I told him I would like to experience a full three-hour full erection at least once... I received six vials full of powder and needed to add the distilled(?) water to one of them. No big deal. Anyway, the doc showed me where to inject myself and made me do it. 15 units. I felt a slight twinge. Wouldn't call it painful. Just... Different... I felt a bit of warmth in area around the shot for a few minutes. Anyway after 10 minutes, my little friend started to wake up. I reached about 60% of firmness, but this was different as I wasn't helping myself or thinking about naughty stuff. It was like a spontaneous boner we all use to get for no reason when we were teens. I definitely felt areas of my little (well, maybe not so little) friend stretching out and waking up. Areas which haven't been stretched out like that for over two years The doc came back in and he said it looked good. I asked him if I could have a lap dance with the pretty receptionist. He agreed that she was cute but it probably wouldn't be a good idea for him to ask her LOL. I felt that in the correct setting with 20 units and some help from porn or the wifey) I would have achieved some "real" wood. Maybe not raging-boner-hang-wet-towels wood, but good enough. My next step is to do the 20 in a couple of days. I'm keeping the mix in the fridge. After the vials are used up, the doc agreed that if either I'll get a refill or "graduate" to trimix.

Posts.Content: Wouldn't those numbers would be highly dependent on the amount of G3 & G4, and the percentage of each... Lumping someone who has with 1 core at 5% involved vs 9 cores each >50% doesn't seem right even if they are both G3 or G4... I also assume also that lumping together someone who is someone who is 45% G4 vs 5% G4 (but both G3+4) doesn't seem right as well.

Posts.Content: I know I'm asking a lot of questions but you guys are really putting my mind at ease... Assuming that the catheter gets pulled out one week after the surgery, when did you feel that it was OK to drive short distances? Or 30 minutes... Thanks!
Posts.Title: 54 years old...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo I know I'm asking a lot of questions but you guys are really putting my mind at ease... Assuming that the catheter gets pulled out one week after the surgery, when did you feel that it was OK to drive short distances? Or 30 minutes... Thanks! I guess I'm almost looking for a list of tasks and when you felt you were up to it, ie What could you do while you still had the catheter in? take a short drive as a passenger? drive yourself to a local store? etc... How soon after you had the catheter out and were you able to take long walks? Short drives by yourself? Longer drive? working from home? etc... etc.. Thanks!
Posts.Title: 54 years old...

Posts.Content: I'm not going to say I'm glad to be here... My physical 6 months ago showed PSA 4.9, biopsy clean. Bump on right side of prostate. Asked to do another PSA test 6 months later. PSA went up to 5.9. Another biopsy. One core positive on the left top, one "suggestive" on the left bottom. Rest were clean. Gleason 3+4. Tumor is "T1C". I remember hearing "5%" but not sure if I heard that right. I'm not the kind of person to do active monitoring or "watchful waiting". So the choice was seeds or the nerve-sparing robotic surgery. Of course the radiologists said radiation was fine and there is no difference between that and surgery while the surgeons said there is a difference, especially at my age. I'm sure that 15 years from now they will have perfected the seeds-then-surgery but for now it seems to be one or the other. I scheduled the surgery for July 18th and unless I absolutely hear otherwise I'm going to go through with it. The head of surgery at the hospital is going to do the daVincie. He's done about 400 and has published several research articles. One thing I found interesting is that the definition of "dry" depends on the study or doctor. His definition of "dry" is ZERO pads while some studies define it as one-per-day. The worst part so far is my wife... She doesn't handle stress well. She's ready to have a full-time nurse for me for the next few weeks after the surgery.. Thanks for listening

Posts.Title: New Member w/Rising PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank "Of course the radiologists said radiation was fine and there is no difference between that and surgery while the surgeons said there is a difference, especially at my age." What does that mean exactly? It is a myth that age has anything to do with radiation as a treatment for PCa. The dry part is a good question. What sort of results does your surgeon have with that? How about erections? Cancer control? I had seeds done in March and have no urinary or erection problems at all - the only weird sexual side effect I have is an orgasm that is dry or nearly drug. Good luck with your surgery! According to the surgeons, there is a lack of data past 15 years for seeds... They said that if I was 70 they would recommend seeds....

AgeInfo.Phrase: said that if I was 70 they would recommend seeds <Z>

I am just happy to have my hubby. Good point. I remind myself that the "Ultimate ED" is much worse than what I have now...

Posts.Title: Looking for insight and experience....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by steveinErie Greetings. Newly diagnosed, details below. As I follow in all of your footsteps, doing as much online research as humanly possible to determine which treatments to consider, I'd pose the following question: In Dr. Walsh's book, he advocates for a biopsy second opinion. Has anyone requested and benefited from having their results reviewed by a another pathologist? Thanks in advance for any help. {Congrats on a terrific and useful Forum} In my case, if I were diagnosed with G6, AS would have been an option... I then would have had a second opinion to validate the first diagnosis. If BOTH were G6, then a second opinion would have been a huge benefit. (I decided since I was "awarded" a G3+4 on my first biopsy, my "threshold" for AS was exceeded and it was time for active treatment.) I know this does not directly answer your question, but at least in my case of deciding whether AS would have been appropriate for me, if my first biopsy was G6, then a second opinion would have been absolutely essential.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer.....3 month waiting game???

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank "Of course the radiologists said radiation was fine and there is no difference between that and surgery while the surgeons said there is a difference, especially at my age." What does that mean exactly? It is a myth that age has anything to do with radiation as a treatment for PCa. The dry part is a good question. What sort of results does your surgeon have with that? How about erections? Cancer control? I had seeds done in March and have no urinary or erection problems at all - the only weird sexual side effect I have is an orgasm that is dry or nearly drug. Good luck with your surgery! According to the surgeons, there is a lack of data past 15 years for seeds... They said that if I was 70 they would recommend seeds....

AgeInfo.Phrase: said that if I was 70 they would recommend seeds <Z>

Posts.Title: 54 years old...

Posts.Content: I'm not going to say I'm glad to be here... My physical 6 months ago showed PSA 4.9, biopsy clean. Bump on right side of prostate. Asked to do another PSA test 6 months later. PSA went up to 5.9. Another biopsy. One core positive on the left top, one "suggestive" on the left bottom. Rest were clean. Gleason 3+4. Tumor is "T1C". I remember hearing "5%" but not sure if I heard that right. I'm not the kind of person to do active monitoring or "watchful waiting". So the choice was seeds or the nerve-sparing robotic surgery. Of course the radiologists said radiation was fine and there is no difference between that and surgery while the surgeons said there is a difference, especially at my age. I'm sure that 15 years from now they will have perfected the seeds-then-surgery but for now it seems to be one or the other. I scheduled the surgery for July 18th and unless I absolutely hear otherwise I'm going to go through with it. The head of surgery at the hospital is going to do the daVincie. He's done about 400 and has published several research articles. One thing I found interesting is that the definition of "dry" depends on the study or doctor. His definition of "dry" is ZERO pads while some studies define it as one-per-day. The worst part so far is my wife... She doesn't handle stress well. She's ready to have a full-time nurse for me for the next few weeks after the surgery.. Thanks for listening
Posts.Title: 54 years old...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo I know I'm asking a lot of questions but you guys are really putting my mind at ease... Assuming that the catheter gets pulled out one week after the surgery, when did you feel that it was OK to drive short distances? Or 30 minutes... Thanks! I guess I'm almost looking for a list of tasks and when you felt you were up to it, ie What could you do while you still had the catheter in? take a short drive as a passenger? drive yourself to a local store? etc... How soon after you had the catheter out and were you able to take long walks? Short drives by yourself? Longer drive? working from home? etc... etc.. Thanks!

Posts.Content: My doc told me that I could drive "very short distances" when I felt up to it even with the catheter in (automatic, not manual). I drove both to and from the Dr's office to have the catheter removed (15 minute drive). Was told I needed to wait 8 weeks before full activity, but I did not start again at the gym until 10 weeks or so. Still feel it when I try to do situps...

Posts.Title: New Member w/Rising PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WhiteLightning I have taken both, but now only take flomax. I have taken it for over 10 years. I took saw palmetto before PC for BPH, then the doc told me to lay off the saw palmetto because it could affect the PSA numbers. After my first biopsy was negative, I asked my Dr about Saw Palmetto and other "Healthy Prostate" products. He said that he did not want me to take anything which could affect my PSA numbers. The only thing he put me on was Vitamin-D supplements, which in other threads notes that low vitamin-d levels is a potential "marker" for a higher-risk PCa.

Posts.Title: Husband diagnose with prostate cancer...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Every urologist should know not to perform a DRE before taking a blood sample for psa. I can't understand him doing that. But, apparently, it has no effect on the Apifiny test. PSA, agree. However, one urologist I went to did a DRE before a PCA-3 test. (As a side note, he was the one who suggested AS for me, which I declined as I already had one reading as a G3+4, and I would have needed two separate G3+3 readings to consider AS).

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Deb 27 It sounds like the robotic surgery is a little easier. Robotic surgery is actually harder. You are under longer and deeper. It's not recommended for patients with heart or other health conditions. However, recovery is usually faster and there is some research which shows that the usual side effects (incontinence, etc) are not as severe. However, may far the most important criteria is the experience of the surgeon. I'd rather have open surgery with a surgeon whose done 1200+ vs someone who has performed 50 robotic surgeries... Make sure the Robotic surgeon is in the VERY experienced... in the 1200+ surgery category. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi F54! Your PSA is elevated - especially relative to your young age - and needs to be explained. Since it appears that the elevation is not due to infection/inflammation, Chuck has asked the key question: "Did the uro say anything about an enlarged prostate?" Since your Uro only did a DRE, the questions I would ask is: "Can one have an enlarged prostate that is not detected by DRE?" and "Can this be the cause of my elevated PSA?" I'm not qualified to challenge the judgement of your Uro MD; however, if me, I would not jump onto the biopsy table quite so quickly! I would inquire about getting a MP 3T MRI that can be later "fused" with subsequent a TRUS biopsy (IF and when biopsy is indicated). This MRI is about 90% effective in detecting and locating Prostate Cancer (PC). Fairwind points out the reimbursement issue that must be addressed in advance. PC can only be diagnosed by histologic evaluation of tissue obtained from a biopsy. However, prostate biopsy is not an exact science or technique. It is like shoving a fine needle into a relatively large haystack hoping to hit a "needle" (focus of PC) deep inside! The 12 core biopsy can miss PC cells and result in a "False Negative" biopsy. Also, biopsy in not without risk. Infection is a known risk. Several on this Forum have had infections due to biopsy. Also, theoretically and possibly in reality, "needle tracking" can displace PC cells outside of the prostate and create a worsened PC scenario. What part of the country do you live and how far from a major medical center? If me, I would go to the nearest academic teaching hospital that has a Urology Program and make an appointment to get evaluated. If biopsy is indicated, they will likely perform an MRI fused TRUS biopsy. If the MRI is (-), you will likely NOT have a biopsy at his time and thus will have been spared an unnecessary procedure on June 6. Also, another benefit of having this MRI is it will serve as a "baseline" to compare any future changes or developments. At very least, I'd get a 2nd opinion about having a biopsy at this time. If you are in a small community, turn to the nearest large city and make an appointment with a Uro MD who specializes in PC for a 2nd opinion. Keep in mind that if/when you are diagnosed with PC either now or in the future (hopefully never!) you want to be treated by an expert PC specialist who is treating at least 3 PC patients per week. By finding such an MD now and getting a 2nd opinion puts you in that MD's patient population. Continue to ask questions and take control of your course of action(s). Good luck moving forward and keep us updated! MF Strong Agree on all points... Get the T3 MRI first....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi F54! Your PSA is elevated - especially relative to your young age - and needs to be explained. Since it appears that the elevation is not due to infection/inflammation, Chuck has asked the key question: "Did the uro say anything about an enlarged prostate?" Since your Uro only did a DRE, the questions I would ask is: "Can one have an enlarged prostate that is not detected by DRE?" and "Can this be the cause of my elevated PSA?" I'm not qualified to challenge the judgement of your Uro MD; however, if me, I would not jump onto the biopsy table quite so quickly! I would inquire about getting a MP 3T MRI that can be later "fused" with subsequent a TRUS biopsy (IF and when biopsy is indicated). This MRI is about 90% effective in detecting and locating Prostate Cancer (PC). Fairwind points out the reimbursement issue that must be addressed in advance. PC can only be diagnosed by histologic evaluation of tissue obtained from a biopsy. However, prostate biopsy is not an exact science or technique. It is like shoving a fine needle into a relatively large haystack hoping to hit a "needle" (focus of PC) deep inside! The 12 core biopsy can miss PC cells and result in a "False Negative" biopsy. Also, biopsy in not without risk. Infection is a known risk. Several on this Forum have had infections due to biopsy. Also, theoretically and possibly in reality, "needle tracking" can displace PC cells outside of the prostate and create a worsened PC scenario. What part of the country do you live and how far from a major medical center? If me, I would go to the nearest academic teaching hospital that has a Urology Program and make an appointment to get evaluated. If biopsy is indicated, they will likely perform an MRI fused TRUS biopsy. If the MRI is (-), you will likely NOT have a biopsy at his time and thus will have been spared an unnecessary procedure on June 6. Also, another benefit of having this MRI is it will serve as a "baseline" to compare any future changes or developments. At very least, I'd get a 2nd opinion about having a biopsy at this time. If you are in a small community, turn to the nearest large city and make an appointment with a Uro MD who specializes in PC for a 2nd opinion. Keep in mind that if/when you are diagnosed with PC either now or in the future (hopefully never!) you want to be treated by an expert PC specialist who is treating at least 3 PC patients per week. By finding such an MD now and getting a 2nd opinion puts you in that MD's patient population. Continue to ask questions and take control of your course of action(s). Good luck moving forward and keep us updated! MF Strong Agree on all points... Get the T3 MRI first....

Posts.Title: Robotic surgery vs hands

Posts.Content: Are you are "wired' for AS? Some of us are not. (There's no right or wrong answer, some of us just want to "get it out", and would stay up night wondering about whether or not the biopsy missed anything and whether or not there is higher-grade PCa lurking and growing down there). If you are wired...: Get a second opinion with another experienced urologist to ensure this person agrees. Send your slides out to Dr Epstein and make sure he agrees with the G6. Find a medical center which does a guided T3 MRI biopsy, in case you need to have another one. Decide on surgery vs radiation, and pick a good experience no matter which way you go,. That way if a second option from another urologist, and a second opinion on the slides all agree you are a candidate for AS, you know that you've done your due-diligence, and if you need to have active treatment in the future, your research on a course of action has already been completed, and you can pull the trigger if needed, without any delay. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with questions

Posts.Content: Read the AS sticky, there's some of additional tests listed there which would give you a full "baseline" on your AS journey. I would also send your slides out for a second opinion, to be sure two labs agree that the G3+3 stays a 3+3. I also read somewhere that surgery gets more difficult after each biopsy, so make each one count - maybe a MRI-Guided saturation biopsy? You may wish to ask you Dr about how many biopsies you can have before it affects surgery. Basically, you have to decide on what your "trigger" is before seeking treatment. Is it additional G6? If G7 is discovered? A 25% increase in PSA over 3 months? My trigger (if I had a choice, which I did not) would have been very low for going off AS and seeking treatment. Some people have zero trigger and are just not "wired" for AS (no right or wrong answer). For example, one Dr suggested I have my slides reevaluated to see if my G3+4 would be downgraded to a G3+3. I decided that for me to be on AS I would have needed TWO independent labs both agreeing on a G6, so AS was out for me (and I did have more PC than the initial biopsy indicated). But for every month on AS you are enjoying "normalcy" such as sex life. So it is a trade-off... Good luck and keep in touch

Posts.Title: Interesting radio ads by Joe Torre, regarding AS

Posts.Content: I seem to one of those people who cancer staging grade was UPGRADED after the prostate was removed and the pathology was performed. PSA was 4.9 in January 2012, bioposy clean. PSA was 5.9 in May 2013. Biopsy in the end of May showed 1 "positive" core, Gleason 3+4, one "suspicious" (both on left side), T1c, and DRE showing a "bump" on the right side. I seem to remember 5% mentioned. Anyway, after much research, help from this board, discussing with Doctors, etc. I had DaVinci on 7/18. The Dr prefaced the pathology report by saying he "got it all out" with "no indications of anything spreading" Anyway, I hope he is correct. Here is my Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Total prostatectomy with seminal vesicles: invasive adenocarcinoma Invasive carcinoma involves left lobe of prostate only invasive carcinoma extends from left apex to posterior mid region of left lobe surgical resection surfaces of apex and base are free of tumor Invasive carcinoma gleason grade 7/10 (4+3) gleason pattern four tumor comprises 75% of invasive carcinoma present Estimated total volume of carcinoma in entire prostate gland: 10% No blood vessel or lymphatic tutor invasion found No extraprostatic tumor extension present No seminal vesicle involvement by tumor present No perineural tumor invasion found No tumor invasion of prostate capsule present Adenofibromatous Prostatic Hyperplasia of non-neoplastic prostate tissue Cancer Staging: TNM: T2b NX MX (Stage IIA) My surgeon is NOT a believer in Active Surveillance or "watchful waiting", so, maybe I'm reading him wrong, but he almost seemed happy that the amount of bad stuff I had was more than what was indicated from the biopsy (or maybe he was just happy that I didn't wait and took action in a short period of time since the cancer was more widespread and of a worse grade than the biopsy results). Not sure if that is because the biopsy underrepresented the bad stuff in my prostate or if it had just spread from May to July. He really was 100 times happier that I did have the surgery and that he "got it all out" with "no indications of anything spreading" and joking that "you should look so good from the outside". (Please let me know based on the above if you have any opinions on my pathology report which I should follow up with him on) I really feel like when I started this journey I was on shit's creak with no paddle, and you guys threw me a life-raft and helped me to realize that I wasn't alone in this. Bless you all.

Posts.Title: My Final Pathologic Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Are you are "wired' for AS? Some of us are not. (There's no right or wrong answer, some of us just want to "get it out", and would stay up night wondering about whether or not the biopsy missed anything and whether or not there is higher-grade PCa lurking and growing down there). If you are wired...: Get a second opinion with another experienced urologist to ensure this person agrees. Send your slides out to Dr Epstein and make sure he agrees with the G6. Find a medical center which does a guided T3 MRI biopsy, in case you need to have another one. Decide on surgery vs radiation, and pick a good experience no matter which way you go,. That way if a second option from another urologist, and a second opinion on the slides all agree you are a candidate for AS, you know that you've done your due-diligence, and if you need to have active treatment in the future, your research on a course of action has already been completed, and you can pull the trigger if needed, without any delay. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ThatBiopsyHurt Ever notice how you'll find lots of threads with comments along the lines of "Surgeon X can get the same outcomes from an open as most robotic guys get" and never "Surgeon Y can get the same outcomes from a robotic as most open guys get"? Actually you'll see web pages stating that with robotic it's easier to reconstruct the muscles "down there" and there is a greater rate of full urinary control, as compared to open. Of course, these reports and web pages are all located on sites of Robotic centers and surgeons

Posts.Title: Brachy or Open Surgery? My Dilemma

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I wish they never invented the PSA test. I know it sounds selfish of me and I'm sure it's help a lot of guys, but for me its been nothing but a nerve racking, anxiety ordeal. My journey started with a physical in Dec 2012 where the PSA was 5.9, up from 2.2. Now 3 years later Ive had two biopsies and many PSA test, my last test number taken this week was 2.8. All the PSA test Ive had have been below 5.9. If I had of just skip that physical in 2012, look at all the trouble free days and weeks I could have spent. If the PSA test wasn't invented, then I would not have been around to watch my son get married or even graduate College. (I know you are venting, but for every person going through what you did, how many lives have been saved by early detection of PCA....)

Posts.Content: I would schedule the surgery as soon as possible (probably about 6 weeks after the biopsy) and then research the other alternatives. That way if you decide on surgery than your place is "reserved" and there is no delay. If you guys decide on alternate treatment, then you can always cancel the surgery. Most people in your situation would have the (robotic) surgery. (I did, I'm just a bit older, with a 12-year old, who wants to be around for a loooong time). Good Luck!

Posts.Title: My Final Pathologic Diagnosis

Posts.Content: I would schedule the surgery as soon as possible (probably about 6 weeks after the biopsy) and then research the other alternatives. That way if you decide on surgery than your place is "reserved" and there is no delay. If you guys decide on alternate treatment, then you can always cancel the surgery. Most people in your situation would have the (robotic) surgery. (I did, I'm just a bit older, with a 12-year old, who wants to be around for a loooong time). Good Luck!

Posts.Title: PCa diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by thunderchief Brad, Not sure if it is a bounce or not. Since you still have a prostate it could be an infection and that could explain the increase in PSA. I had IMRT 10 years ago . My lowest PSA was 0.295 after two years. It then bounced around going as high as 0.47 six months after the 0.295 reading. For the most part my readings have been in the 0.35 range. My radiation doctor first told me that after treatment the PSA would be like a saw blade. It would probably go up and down , up and downand it has. I can remember him telling me that I had an 88% chance of being under 0.50 mark ten years down the road. I would say relax and see what it is in 6 months How about a retest to be sure this isn't an outlier, and then another PSA test in 3 months?

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Bounce

Posts.Content: Definitely not a straight line. Progress needs to be looked at on a weekly basis and as you get more active or change diet be prepared for a "surprise". I still have minor leaks when lifting a 40 lb bag of wood pellets or rock salt. Alcohol in particular causes leakage for me for some reason. Not a lot, but enough to notice. Good luck and welcome to the "Zero Club"

Posts.Title: Wheelar

Posts.Content: With the summer vacation and general senior moments, I had my PSA tested a month later than I should have... This would have caused me a lot of "PSAnxiety", HOWEVER, even though my surgeon said I can have my PSA test performed annually, I decided to have my annual physical and surgeon visit scheduled six months apart, with each drawing PSA. So, my even though I was late by a month due to my own stupidity, my last test was actually seven months ago ... well within the annual testing my surgeon recommended, so I didn't freak out... My insurance covered the additional test, but even if it did not, I would have had it done anyway for my own piece of mind.. Anyway, I'm still in the zero club...

Posts.Title: My PSA Testing Schedule (and Good News)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Narnar I was talking to a friend of mine the other night and came to find he also gad pc. He was diagnosed 5 years and had a RALP followed by radiation the following year. According to him the dr. Said the pc was confined to the prostate and he was cured. He said he had a PSA last week and it came back at 0.2. The Dr. says all is well and still nothing to worry about. My thoughts are if you have had your prostate removed and radiation and you still have a PSA of 0.2 your not really cured and there is still some cancer somewhere. Do you agree or disagree with me on this. I don’t want to say something and alarm for no good reason. Ron I would suggest that your friend be retested in three months. I'd be surprised and concerned if the Dr didn't already suggest some sort of testing schedule to establish a baseline and trend...

Posts.Title: It's taken me a year to get our local newspaper to do a story about prostate cancer

Posts.Content: The actual Robotic procedure is harder on the body.. You are under for a longer period of time and as Chuck says you are basically placed at a 45 degree angle with the legs above the head. Do you have high blood pressure or any medical condition which would preclude you from Davinci? The actual recovery time from Davinci (and I guess laparoscopic as well) is quicker. When I researched laparoscopic, I quickly excluded it because, which there was less blood loss, I read somewhere that extremely advanced laparoscopic skills were needed to maneuver the rigid laparoscopic instruments, with less room for maneuvering than open surgery (which is needed to ensure the nerves are spared and things are restitched the best way possible to help with incontinence. I was then left with DaVinci vs Open. I chose DaVinci because I remember reading that due to the angle that the DaVinci machine can move (it has a much larger range of motion vs the human wrist), the continence rate and nerve-sparing was slightly higher. (Sorry, this is all from memory). However, as Chuck has mentioned, that is if ALL OTHER THINGS ARE EQUAL. I believe that we all agree that it's better to have a very skilled open surgeon over an inexperienced DaVinci surgeon. HTHs, and good luck.

Posts.Title: Blue balls !!??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CPO2CWO I used a glycerin suppository to get things started. Just be gentle on inserting it and don't go too far up there. I also had been using stool softeners but they couldn't get that first good BM. Hydration is a key factor. Don't cut back to far or you will pay for it. Actually two liters per day seems about right. Just stop about 3-4 hours before bedtime. Only consume enough right before bedtime to prevent dry mouth. My surgeon was against any kind of suppositories or anything "up there" for the first six weeks. He suggested as much fruit as possible, especially Watermelon, Dulcolax, and prunes in their own juice. I'll happen, just don't push too much or you can create hemorrhoids or make existing ones worse.

Posts.Content: I read about Jerry Orbach (the guy from Law and Order), who was diagnosed with PCa and was on HT basically the entire time he was starring on Law and Order. I saw how he, even with his PCa metastasized; he starred in the show for over 10 years on HT... and that was over 14 years ago, and treatments have advanced since then. My coworker got discouraged as he did in fact pass away, which of course is the exact opposite of what I intended. I'm done using my right leg to kick myself in the ass, now it's time to use my left leg and aim for the other cheek

Posts.Title: PSA >700, G9, chemo+HT - looking for long-term success stories

Posts.Title: Getting tough to deal with

Posts.Content: My coworker's brother is 60 years old. He never had physicals nor had PSA tested. About two months ago, he had severe urination problems, to make a long story short, he had a TURP. It turns out that the analysis of the tissue removed was a Gleason Score is G9 (not sure if it is a 4+5 or 5+4), and his PSA is "over 700". It did spread to "his bones". He is scheduled for a full-body scan as well. He's saw an oncologist, and today, he will receive a one-month hormone shot, and after assessing how he responds to the initial treatment, and then have the dosage or meds adjusted if needed, and go for another (three-month?) hormone treatment. The oncologist will also be consulting with her colleagues as to the best course of treatment. In addition, his oncologist aalso recommended chemo. I am getting this all second-hand so forgive me if I I don't have all of the details. Her brother is the kind of person who trusts the Dr and doesn't want to know all of the details. My coworker (and I) are the opposite, the more information, the better. She's an extremely strong person but I can see that this is eating her up inside. I think the world of her and she's like both my work-spouse and sister to me. Her mother passed away from breast cancer (and also had chemo) less than ten years ago so that's still a vivid and sad memory. Her brother's oncologist, who I have a good feeling about, has said that she will be with throughout his journey and she doesn't expect him to pass away from this evil disease. Anyway, I'm looking for some success stories, especially long-term ones, from anyone who had similar stats (very high gleason and very high PSA). Links to posts or profiles are fine... I've suggested that my coworker visits this forum as well as her brother, or even better, link to this post which has some "success stories". Thanks -Dave

AgeInfo.Phrase: stories My coworker's brother is 60 years old <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick Hey all- I'm 9 days post-RP. All has gone well. This morning, though, as I sit outside with coffee and laptop, I feel/see what appears to be a tan-colored mushy-looking stuff oozing out from the tip of my penis around the catheter. Not a lot; maybe the size of 2 BB's. And I feel a slight "need to go", though I've felt that before and it has passed. Been filling the urine bag well, and the urine looks healthy. Any thoughts on this? Wondering if it might be a sign of infection, but other than that feeling of needing to go, nothing else "feels bad". Thoughts? thanks- dave Does it have any smell or are you more tender than "normal" up there (if having a catheter can be described as "normal"...)? Anyway, I would call your surgeon if you have any concerns. Good Luck...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wolfgang Anyway, I forgot to mention in my original post that my CT and bone scans were done after the last biopsy and they were negative. It was some kind of relief after getting the first pathology results with most Gleason scores to be 9. I am still expecting the final pathology results to see more details. Will keep you posted as soon as I get them. I believe that with a G9 that you need to be aggressive with followup testing... My surgery was on 7/18; I had followup PSAs on 8/25, 11/4, and 2/6 and I'm now on a 6 month schedule. I were in your Gleason shoes I would feel better if I was tested very regularly.. My first thought would be to ask the Dr about being tested every six weeks for the first six months and then every three months thereafter for the following year... (I'm sure others will contribute their thoughts and knowledge as well). Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Welcome Thom: It's fine that you're OK with waiting but you bring up one of the weaknesses in an active surveillance program. What do you do if the PSA keeps rising? Do you wait until the PSA reaches 14 -- or 20 -- or 30? Where do you draw the line? Who makes that decision? Speaking only for myself (and perhaps a handful of others), I would be measuring the distance that I needed to cover in doing a somersault onto an operating table. But that's just me. We all have different comfort levels. I wish you the best, Jim Good point... To lazythom: What if you get your PSA tested every two months and it keeps rising... what is your "trigger" to go off of AS? Is it when PSA reaches 11? 12? ... 14? For me, that trigger would have already passed and I would have started active treatment...

Posts.Content: I wish I had or found some sort of "checklist" of what to do once I found out my biopsy was positive. A sheet of paper with checkboxes and empty lines to be filled in... Things to ask your Doctor, things to organize all of the results, things to ask your radiologist or surgeon, to help decide on a surgeon or radiation, useful links, and all of the things I've read on this great list, like: ---------------------------------------------------------- PSA Score(s): ___ Gleason Score(s): ___ + ____ Your Age: ____ Stage: _____ Number of Positive Cores: ______ Location of Positive Cores: ______ How many surgeries has your surgeon performed ____ etc Useful links: _______ Useful links: _______ Useful links: _______ ------------------------------------------------------------- Basically, all of the information I wish I had asked when I first found out when I joined our Club. Is there such a thing out there? If not, or if there is one but maybe can to be customized based on our personal experience, I'd be interested in collaborating to create one... You guys are great, Thanks

Posts.Title: Did they perform a junk transplant?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F As Chuck stated, most MDs will check the 1st post RP PSA at the 12 week mark. However, on this Forum and elsewhere we are seeing a growing trend where PSAs are being checked at 6 weeks. Possibly the PSA test at 6 weeks is being ordered due to elevated risk findings discovered at time of surgery or at pathology. Post RP, ones PSA should drop fairly quickly. The 1/2 life of PSA is between 2 - 3 days. Therefore, by 6 weeks, ones PSA should be "0" unless PC or residual healthy prostate tissues remain or PSA is being generated by peri prostatic tissues. For example, If your Piggy Bank had 100 pennies with a 1/2 Life of 2.5 days, at the 3 week mark you would have 1 penny remaining. At 6 weeks it would be down to $0.0001 which is 1/100th of a penny which is negligible. Make sure to discuss your PSA with your URO and the frequency of PSA testing moving forward. Good luck keeping your PSA off the radar screen! My surgeon does six weeks it as part of his standard process... - if PSA is Zero at six weeks then it's good news and he likes the idea of sharing that news... if not, then he has the extra data point for the three-month draw. I know I really liked the idea of knowing my PSA after six weeks was zero... it really reduced my stress and made the wait to the three-month PSA a lot easier. For that reason alone I would recommend that everyone ask for a six-week PSA test.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Welcome Thom: It's fine that you're OK with waiting but you bring up one of the weaknesses in an active surveillance program. What do you do if the PSA keeps rising? Do you wait until the PSA reaches 14 -- or 20 -- or 30? Where do you draw the line? Who makes that decision? Speaking only for myself (and perhaps a handful of others), I would be measuring the distance that I needed to cover in doing a somersault onto an operating table. But that's just me. We all have different comfort levels. I wish you the best, Jim Good point... To lazythom: What if you get your PSA tested every two months and it keeps rising... what is your "trigger" to go off of AS? Is it when PSA reaches 11? 12? ... 14? For me, that trigger would have already passed and I would have started active treatment...

Posts.Title: Radical Questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F As Chuck stated, most MDs will check the 1st post RP PSA at the 12 week mark. However, on this Forum and elsewhere we are seeing a growing trend where PSAs are being checked at 6 weeks. Possibly the PSA test at 6 weeks is being ordered due to elevated risk findings discovered at time of surgery or at pathology. Post RP, ones PSA should drop fairly quickly. The 1/2 life of PSA is between 2 - 3 days. Therefore, by 6 weeks, ones PSA should be "0" unless PC or residual healthy prostate tissues remain or PSA is being generated by peri prostatic tissues. For example, If your Piggy Bank had 100 pennies with a 1/2 Life of 2.5 days, at the 3 week mark you would have 1 penny remaining. At 6 weeks it would be down to $0.0001 which is 1/100th of a penny which is negligible. Make sure to discuss your PSA with your URO and the frequency of PSA testing moving forward. Good luck keeping your PSA off the radar screen! My surgeon does six weeks it as part of his standard process... - if PSA is Zero at six weeks then it's good news and he likes the idea of sharing that news... if not, then he has the extra data point for the three-month draw. I know I really liked the idea of knowing my PSA after six weeks was zero... it really reduced my stress and made the wait to the three-month PSA a lot easier. For that reason alone I would recommend that everyone ask for a six-week PSA test.

Posts.Title: PSA Checked!?!?!?!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Thom, I may have an experience much different than the others that have posted, but I will try to relate it to your case. I have found that a prostate biopsy can TRIPLE your psa, and that the rise can last for six months. This happened to me TWICE! No antibiotics were recommended the second time, and they didn't make any difference the the first time. I found that a week of hot sitz baths returned my psa to normal both times. Again, I don't mean to argue with the above advice, it's just that I have walked down a different path, and want to offer you this input. Say lazythom has the hot sitz baths regularly for a few weeks... Gets retested in six weeks. If the PSA continues to rise, would you then agree that it's time for lazythom to start active treatment? Or maybe wait another six weeks for a "final" PSA retest and if it continues to rise yet again, then start active treatment? Whie Lazythom is OK with waiting, what is the point (eg trigger) where a "threshold" has been reached and it's time bid farewell to AS? For most of us, especially those (such as myself) whose PCa was higher than what the biopsy indicated, that threshold already passed. While each person (and prostate) is different, I'm just wondering if that threshold could be quantified in some way...

Posts.Title: Check-Up 18 months after Da Vinci

Posts.Content: Hi Paul A sad welcome to our "club". The others have all given you good advise. Those with G6 could consider Active Surveillance (AS) although I don't see the number of cores involved, your age, or the percentage of involvement. Some of us are not "wired" for AS (and from the sounds of it you may not be) -- which is not a negative, only an observation. I had G3+4 in one core and was given the option of sending my slides out for a second opinion, and, if it came back as G6, then consider AS. I decided against it as in my mind I would need two "reads" of both G6 before considering AS. (While I was "wired" for AS, my results were above my "trigger", or threshold needed for me to consider AS instead of treatment.) Anyway I had surgery and I was one of those 20 or 30% whose results were greater than the biopsy report. The "good" news is that with G6 you don't need to run into treatment. Take a few weeks (or longer) to research the different treatment types and find a good experienced surgeon while deciding on your treatment and receive the rest of your results. You can even schedule a date for surgery with the idea of canceling it you decide on AS or radiation. That way, if you decide on surgery, your spot is already "reserved". If you decide on AS or radiation, you can just cancel the surgery. Good Luck and stay in touch

Posts.Title: First time diagnosis with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Hello Anne: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here and deal with this dreadful disease. Since your surgery date is not until 9/11, u might want to take the time before then to do some research and homework. BTW...a surgery on 9/11? That date and surgery don't seem to go together!! Since your husband has already been DX as a cT3a, you owe it to yourself and him to explore all your treatment options. T3 means the horse has already left the barn, and while a cure is still very possible, you need to go about this with the least amount of SE as possible. Surgery may not be curative by itself, and then u will find yourself in the SRT and perhaps other treatment modalities type of situation. Check out all your options, see a RO and learn about the various forms of radiation therapy. I am the poster boy for SE, and I would just like to pass along my experience on the subject. Be your own advocate, and ask questions. This is a life changing event, and the decisions u make now will be forever. I am available anytime to be helpful. Best regards, MM I was going to comment, but MichiganMan said everything which I was thinking, and more. Strong agree!
