Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Hello Anne: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here and deal with this dreadful disease. Since your surgery date is not until 9/11, u might want to take the time before then to do some research and homework. BTW...a surgery on 9/11? That date and surgery don't seem to go together!! Since your husband has already been DX as a cT3a, you owe it to yourself and him to explore all your treatment options. T3 means the horse has already left the barn, and while a cure is still very possible, you need to go about this with the least amount of SE as possible. Surgery may not be curative by itself, and then u will find yourself in the SRT and perhaps other treatment modalities type of situation. Check out all your options, see a RO and learn about the various forms of radiation therapy. I am the poster boy for SE, and I would just like to pass along my experience on the subject. Be your own advocate, and ask questions. This is a life changing event, and the decisions u make now will be forever. I am available anytime to be helpful. Best regards, MM I was going to comment, but MichiganMan said everything which I was thinking, and more. Strong agree!

Posts.Title: New Memeber - First Post What to do, what to do????

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Welcome Thom: It's fine that you're OK with waiting but you bring up one of the weaknesses in an active surveillance program. What do you do if the PSA keeps rising? Do you wait until the PSA reaches 14 -- or 20 -- or 30? Where do you draw the line? Who makes that decision? Speaking only for myself (and perhaps a handful of others), I would be measuring the distance that I needed to cover in doing a somersault onto an operating table. But that's just me. We all have different comfort levels. I wish you the best, Jim Good point... To lazythom: What if you get your PSA tested every two months and it keeps rising... what is your "trigger" to go off of AS? Is it when PSA reaches 11? 12? ... 14? For me, that trigger would have already passed and I would have started active treatment...

Posts.Title: Hello new member first test ever 5.9 at age 58.

Posts.Content: I was in a similar situation, similar age, but with a 12-year-old. I was not sure which way to go for treatment. I searched and found a surgeon I was comfortable with (I chose robotic/Da Vinci) and scheduled my surgery. I then interviewed radiation oncologists. I figured that if I decided to go with radiation, then I would just cancel the surgery. If I decided to go with surgery, then my date was already reserved and there was no extra wait. (I ended up choosing DaVinci). Good Luck!

Posts.Title: New here, having the same decision issues everyone does

Posts.Content: Hi Paul A sad welcome to our "club". The others have all given you good advise. Those with G6 could consider Active Surveillance (AS) although I don't see the number of cores involved, your age, or the percentage of involvement. Some of us are not "wired" for AS (and from the sounds of it you may not be) -- which is not a negative, only an observation. I had G3+4 in one core and was given the option of sending my slides out for a second opinion, and, if it came back as G6, then consider AS. I decided against it as in my mind I would need two "reads" of both G6 before considering AS. (While I was "wired" for AS, my results were above my "trigger", or threshold needed for me to consider AS instead of treatment.) Anyway I had surgery and I was one of those 20 or 30% whose results were greater than the biopsy report. The "good" news is that with G6 you don't need to run into treatment. Take a few weeks (or longer) to research the different treatment types and find a good experienced surgeon while deciding on your treatment and receive the rest of your results. You can even schedule a date for surgery with the idea of canceling it you decide on AS or radiation. That way, if you decide on surgery, your spot is already "reserved". If you decide on AS or radiation, you can just cancel the surgery. Good Luck and stay in touch

Posts.Title: Off Topic: Virtual Colonoscopy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Ddayglo, did you mean this to be posted in the colon cancer forum?? Actually no, since I don't have colon cancer... but that's a good idea as long as the board admins don't mind me posting in a forum that I'm not a member of. I've read that a virtual colonoscopy a)is additional radiation, b)can find abnormalities in other organs c)it does a better job of looking at the entire colon, d)it may miss small polyps.. So what I've seen there are pluses and minuses, was wondering if anyone here has researched or had the virtual colonoscopy. Are there any advantages or disadvantages of us club members to have a virtual vs an optical colonoscopy...

Posts.Title: Hello new member first test ever 5.9 at age 58.

Posts.Content: I haven't been shy about making sure that every male I know over 45 years old is getting a physical and a PSA test. I'd wear a tie with a prostate design on it if I could find one .... Anyway, I scared, err convinced a friend to get tested, and now he's in the High PSA-Biopsy stage and he's been asking me about prostate cancer. He says that he wants to thank me, shake my hand, punch me, apologize and thank me again, in that order Anyway, he asked me how a negative margin could be a good indicator of the surgeon's expertise: Friend: "The Dr takes out the entire prostate, right?" Me: "yes" Friend: "Then if the margin is positive it means that the cancer spread and negative means it was contained, right" Me: "right" Friend: "If he takes out the entire prostate, if the margin was positive, then it doesn't have anything to do with the surgeon's expertise, but more to do with the progression of the cancer, wouldn't it?" I really didn't know how to answer him.... Advise appreciated. Thanks.

Posts.Title: still a member of the zero club

Posts.Content: your results do seem to fall above the guidelines for AS many of us would recommend treatment as there are 4 positive cores. Before deciding on AS, you should have a second opinion on the slides from someone like Dr Epstein to corroborate the first reading, as well as MF's suggestion about a 3T MRI and retest your PSA in three months. If you still plan on AS, then read the AS sticky as it contains other tests you can have. Also research surgeons and decide on one you like in case you change your mind about radiation. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Hello new member first test ever 5.9 at age 58.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Arthro92 My urologist called me today. I DO NOT HAVE PROSTATE CANCER!!!!!!!! He says what I have is asymptomatic prostatitis. My uro believes that is the reason for the elevated PSA. I am so thankful! I am THANKFUL to all of you for your soothing, comforting, encouraging words. Sorry, I don't want to be a downer, but please have your PSA tested in another four or six months.... I was given the same initial diagnosis....

Posts.Title: Surgery Scheduled

Posts.Content: HI msjoh88 Your dad will probably have a scan (ask about a T3 MRI) and/or a biopsy. If it's confirmed that it's PC, then its time for aggressive treatment, such a HT therapy (which will deprive any PC of testosterone and therefore stop the PC from growing any more while other treatment (such as radiation) is started. There are some members here who had PC much higher and with treatment its been under control for many years and there's every reason to believe that it continue to be under control for many more years. Good luck

Posts.Title: PSA results in

Posts.Content: Hi Delta In addition with everyone's great comments, have your PSA tested more often than what your surgeon/urologist recommends. Once I "graduated" to annual testing, there was always the thought in the back of my mind that it could be 11 months before a recurrence is discovered, which caused me lots of "PSAnxiety". I now schedule my annual surgical visit and my annual physical six months apart, with each drawing PSA. Knowing that I'm getting tested twice as often as recommended has greatly decreased my anxiety. PS - I take the standard PSA test so I don't have to sweat every decimal place...

Posts.Content: I used a full depends and a pad inside for the first few days, then "graduated" to "just" a large pad. I didn't mind getting up when I felt like I had to pee, as it meant I was gaining back some control and feeling down there. I got up three times each night at first... I felt the tradeoff of keeping the pad (and me and the bed), dry and gaining back some control was worth the tradeoff of sleeping through the night

Posts.Title: Catheter removal. Excited and worried

Posts.Content: Immediately following my surgery, I added as much fiber as possible to by diet.... And I believe I've recommended it to a few members of our "club". I was reading about fiber today and noticed that the side effects of fiber alone is... flatulence, bloating, abdominal cramps, and temporary constipation... until your system gets used to the increase in fiber. Now I'm wondering, if, immediately after surgery, if adding a lot of fiber is such a good idea. You system was shocked already by the surgery and anesthesia, and already bloated. Adding "plenty of fiber", especially if you were not a big fiber user before surgery, doesn't seem to be a great idea. Right after surgery, stool softener, absolutely. Some fiber, absolutely. But "plenty of fiber", now I'm not so sure.. Increasing your fiber slowly... absolutely.

Adding "plenty of fiber", especially if you were not a big fiber user before surgery, doesn't seem to be a great idea. Right after surgery, stool softener, absolutely. Some fiber, absolutely. But "plenty of fiber", now I'm not so sure.. Increasing your fiber slowly... absolutely.

Posts.Title: Question for the wives and one for the men re incontinence.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Waiting for PSA results is one of the most stressful part s of all of our lives, once we have been diagnosed and treated. Good luck I still get nervous as well. Even though the surgeon put me on an annual PSA schedule, I scheduled my annual visit with the surgeon and my annual physical six months apart, each with PSA draws. My stress has definitely reduced knowing that I'm testing my PSA twice as often, and if the numbers do creep up, I've caught it six months earlier. So far the insurance hasn't complained...

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter I am now in the camp that G6 can successfully do AS without additional risk provided one is a true G6. The challenge for us patients is when confronted with a biopsy report of G6 and no other differentiations as to the type of cancer, how do we know if there is a chance we have "more aggressive variants lurking around"? I think at a minimum, if you are a G6 and are considering AS, send your biopsy to at least one other place like JH for a second read to make sure you are a pure G6. Strong Agree. When I was first diagnosed, (G3+4, one core), one surgeon recommend I have a second opinion and if the second read was G6, then consider AS. I decided against it, as I would have needed TWO different labs to agree on G6, which in my mind would be a "true" G6. (And I ended up a G4+3). Some people aren't "Wired" for AS. At all. I would have been "wired" for AS -- assuming a "True" G6 -- but also with a very low threshold/trigger to leave AS.

Posts.Title: Still in the Zero Club :grin:

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace Sometimes PSA can jump from inflammation or enlargement or infection. Since prostate cancer usually grows slowly, there may be no rush for another biopsy. A multiparametric MRI is available at some large centers. There is a free PSA blood test that sometimes provides some info. If you know the prostate size, you can compute PSA density. There are other blood tests. Good luck with your research and efforts. Antibiotics, a retest of PSA within a month or so, and if the PSA does not decrease, then an MRI and other blood tests like lancepeace mentioned makes sense. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mark524 Hi everyone. I am 57 and in October I found out my PSA had increased from 2.5 two years ago to 5.0 . Went to Urologist and DRE was normal - he put me on antibiotics and 5 weeks later PSA down to 3.8. Just had a 3T MRI which came back relatively clean with Pi-RADS score of 2 (and no significant lesions). He now wants me to get a biopsy (standard 12 core). I am wondering if it is my best course of action to just jump into an invasive procedure or if anyone else with a similar circumstance went a different route? He didn't really give me any other options (he strongly suggested the biopsy) but I really want to do some homework before I get this done. Right now I am thinking the good from it (either a little more piece of mind or perhaps something being found that the MRI did not catch) most likely outweighs the bad (slight chance of infection and an uncomfortable 15 minutes!) but I would love to hear others thoughts or experiences. Schedule another PSA in eight weeks... if your PSA rises again, then yes, a biopsy would be a good idea... A "guided" biopsy would be best, unless the MRI you already had would qualify. If it stays below 4, then retest every three months. As Chuck mentions, asking for other tests is a good idea. I remember being low on vitamin D3 and found out after-the-fact that low vityamin D levels are also a marker for PCa. You are doing great by staying on top of things. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Caregivers role post-surgery

Posts.Content: I agonized over which path to choose and I finally choose surgery. If I was 10-15 years older, or there was more research onto the long-term survival and occurrence rates (>20 years) of brachy vs surgery, perhaps I would have chosen differently. Then again, maybe not, as I'm the kind of person who felt best to "get it out and as far away from my body as possible" and deal with the side effects. It's a personal choice, there is no right-or-wrong answer, and, like the AS-vs-treatment debate, it stirs up some strong emotions which we all have seen and need to be aware of... Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: Even though my urologist "graduated" me to annual PSA testing, I decided to schedule my annual urologist visit and annual physical six months apart, with PSA tested each time. The insurance hasn't complained.... that way I'm getting my PSA tested every six months instead of annually. It's made a huge decrease in my anxiety level while waiting for the PSA results, the last test was six months ago (and not a full year), and knowing that even if the PSA does go up, I've potentially caught it months earlier. Anyway, it's still <.01, so I'm still a member of the Zero Club

Posts.Title: Still in the Zero Club :grin:

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Samie Staples and catheter out and all appears to be fine. Received pathology report also today. Upgraded from Gleason 7 4+3 to 8 4+4....lymph nodes negative for malignancy...one with sinus histiocytosis...2.4cm x 0.9 tumor size...involving 20 to 25%...right seminal vesicles involved by tumor...right lateral margin involved by tumor, distal margin negstive, proximal margin - sent for 2nd opinion...lymphovascular and perineural invasion not identified...pathological staging pT3b pNO pM Comment: Immunohistochemica stain Pankeratin is pending to assess the proximal margin and will be reported in a addedum. This case will be sent for a second opinion. The above is taken from the written report we received. Urologist says to have PSA tested in 3 months and return to discuss next steps based on PSA finding. Any comments on above appreciated and welcomed! We know this is not as good as we hoped. Unfortunately you are one of the members of the final-pathology-upgraded-the-Biopsy-Gleason-Score club... But its good that the lymph nodes were negative (not sure what the treatment for sinus histiocytosis is). I would suggest a 6-week PSA and then another one at 3-months for an additional data point and trending... Good luck

Posts.Content: My doc's PSA schedule was 6 weeks, 6 weeks, then 3 months, then 6 months and annually after that (assuming all Zero's). So as chuck says it seems to be simply your Doctor's preference. I decided to have my annual physical and annual PSA test six months apart so I can still have the PSA test every six months (not because any Dr told me to, but for my own sanity). Anyway, we have spot reserved at the zero-club with your name penciled in. Hope we can change it to pen (or, even better, indelible ink) soon. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Newbie--26 days on the other side!!!!!

Posts.Content: I had zero symptoms, first biopsy negative, second one positive. I was undecided but leaning towards surgery. I decided to schedule the surgery while exploring other treatment options. That way if I decided on the surgery I had the first available slot and if not then I would just cancel the surgery. I decided on the surgery. Assuming that the rest of your scans are OK, then most of us would suggest surgery as well, as you could always have followup "salvage" radiation but having surgery after radiation is much more difficult. Read the stickies and put up a book by Dr Walsh caled "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". Good Luck!

Posts.Title: New Member here - my story.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Badman Am 7 weeks post op and am doing better. I spurt every time I move quickly or strain in any way. Also when sneezing or at work, as I am always up and down at work. So is the spurting versus the constant dribble I had a sign of my Kegels working? I do them twice a day and also at night the flow is greatly reduced. Just wondering if anyone has this experience also and is it a good sign? I had the same thing... The muscle is working and then sort of fails for a bit. So I believe its a good sign... You may wish to stop the kegels for a day or two in case you are overworking the muscle, or try an every-other-day schedule to give the muscle a chance to heal (like what is usually recommended for when lifting weights). You are ahead of where many of us were at 7 weeks.

Posts.Title: Incontinence Update

Posts.Content: Drs not dealing with pain well... Every time my surgeon would say "it's not that bad" I would ask him if he knows from experience or not and he would smile and say no. When it came time to take out the catheter tube, I suggested that to improve Patient-Doctor communication, I will grab his testicles and will twist them in direct relation to how much pain I was feeling as the catheter was being pulled out.... He told me it wouldn't be necessary and that just telling me would be fine

Posts.Title: Value of Second Opinions and Newly Diagnosed Questions

Posts.Content: I had one positive core at 3+4 and thought about a second opinion. I decided that even if a second opinion was a G6, someone qualified to read the slides did see some G4 cells. And I would have needed TWO G6's (in my mind, a "solid" G6), to consider AS. Also as a biopsy only samples a small portion of the prostate, there's a chance that there was more bad stuff out there in my prostate which was missed by the biopsy... It turns out I was upgraded to a G4+3 after my RP, so I'm glad I did what I did. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Questions I should ask my Urologist when receiving my Biopsy results ?

Posts.Content: If it's a Gleason 7 (3+4 but not for 4+3), you could ask for a second opinion, and if is changed to a Gleason 6 (3+3), then AS COULD be an option. (I had a 3+4 and thought about a second opinion but decided against it as in my mind it would not be a "solid" G6. ) If I had a a Gleason 6, and wanted to explore AS, I would have asked for a second opinion to be sure it's a "Solid" Gleason 6 before going the AS route (also taking into consideration the number and involvement of each core, PSA level, etc) If it's negative, then you need to have PSA taken and another biopsy (consider doing a saturation biopsy) in six months. (I did that, and the second biopsy was positive...). In hindsight, when my first biopsy was negative, I wish I would have put myself in "AS mode", and follow many of the items listed in this thread: What-I-wish-I-Knew-Before-I-Chose-Active-Surveillance, especially Walt's "AS Diet".

Posts.Title: Decisions Decisions DaVinci Prostatectomy versus External Beam Radiation????

Posts.Content: Find a good, experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery for the earliest possible time after your biopsy (5-6 weeks). THEN if you have second thoughts about radiation, you can research it knowing that your surgery appointment is already "reserved" and you are already scheduled for the earliest possible time and will never second-guess yourself about waiting. But if you decide to switch to radiation, you can simply cancel the surgery. Going back to work two weeks after the surgery is optimistic... I went back to work 3 1/2 weeks after my surgery, have a desk job, and the first week was rough. Read the DaVinci sticky for many first-person details on others who have had robotic surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: The Forum

Posts.Content: See a urologist, stay on an every six month schedule for PSA and DRE Have your Vitamin-D level checked regularly. See (http://www.webmd.com/prostate-cancer...-cancers-study) Freeze your sperm Consider yourself on "Active Surveillance" (which you are already doing in a way, good for you.) Read the AS sticky. Research the tests for people on AS, such as this one and any other "marker" which the people on AS use when they need to seek more aggressive treatment Ask about having an MRI as a "baseline". (see http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...MRI-vs.-Biopsy)...Hopefully your insurance will cover it... Good luck and we hope you never have to join our "club".

Posts.Title: The Forum

Posts.Content: Find a good, experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery for the earliest possible time after your biopsy (5-6 weeks). THEN if you have second thoughts about radiation, you can research it knowing that your surgery appointment is already "reserved" and you are already scheduled for the earliest possible time and will never second-guess yourself about waiting. But if you decide to switch to radiation, you can simply cancel the surgery. Going back to work two weeks after the surgery is optimistic... I went back to work 3 1/2 weeks after my surgery, have a desk job, and the first week was rough. Read the DaVinci sticky for many first-person details on others who have had robotic surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: The Forum

Posts.Content: I had one positive core at 3+4 and thought about a second opinion. I decided that even if a second opinion was a G6, someone qualified to read the slides did see some G4 cells. And I would have needed TWO G6's (in my mind, a "solid" G6), to consider AS. Also as a biopsy only samples a small portion of the prostate, there's a chance that there was more bad stuff out there in my prostate which was missed by the biopsy... It turns out I was upgraded to a G4+3 after my RP, so I'm glad I did what I did. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Uncle Bill This is my first post since 2013. I'm hoping someone can help me understand what's going on with me. My PSA count in July 2015 was 4.9, a big jump from January 2015 at 3.0. I included below about an eight year history of my PSA counts. As you can see my counts have always been high for my age group. Earlier this month my doctor put me on Bactrim twice a day for thirty days and will retest me again in September. I have a feeling another biopsy is coming. Should I ask for an MRI first? I'm very active. I workout twice a day 5 times a week and I run a couple times a week. I been having a lot of lower abdominal pain, most of the pain happens when I run. It seems I have a lot of inflammation in my pelvic area and lower back area. Would this cause an increase in PSA levels? I stopped taking fish oil because I heard it can cause an increase. I'm very worried Date PSA age 7/15 4.9 49 1/15 3.0 49 5/14 3.6 48 9/13 3.6 47 3/12 3.2 46 free PSA 14% 4/11 3.4 45 7/11 biopsy 44 5/10 3.1 44 9/9 3.2 43 2/9 2.3 43 5/8 2.1 42 1/8 2.4 42 If your insurance covers it, you should consider a T3(?) MRI which would help "target" the biopsy to suspicious-looking spots. Others will have the exact name of the test and process. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Merc428 To me, the thin liners were all about placement. Too high and they're no good...the end of the penis is too low. Too middle and they weren't as effective as they could be because I naturally "hang" to the left. I had to place them where the end of my penis was most likely to be in the middle of the pad. Not the center of my underwear (as the nurse showed me). Cialis and Viagra, I think, are different for everyone. I take low dose 5mg Cialis everyday. Some days I know I won't see my girlfriend and I don't take it. Other days I'm sure I'll see her and I take 2 or 3. I rarely have a problem being floppy using this method. And I'm quite happy, not just "OK". But I know each mans journey is different. And the drugs that work for some don't work for others. And that even with nerve sparing surgery, the nerves can be stretched and damaged quite a bit and need 12-24 months to heal. So everyone is different. Your husband is lucky to have such a caring and understanding wife. All the best to both of you on this recovery journey. Agree. The fact that your hubby is having some "action" about three months after DaVinci is great news. I also tried a few brands of thin pads until I found one which was "just right". I also bought one of those 12-packs of cloth baby diapers and cut them into quarters and put one in front of the thin pad. I would just throw them out after I leaked a little. It helped me "graduate" from the medium pads to the thin pads. Or I would just go with one of those in the front for half a day or so as they were much softer than pads. Your hubby is doing great. Don't get discouraged if there isn't improvement for a few days. Also insist that if he wakes up with a bulge under the covers that he needs to wake you up as well, just for encouragement and to admire the view if nothing else....

Posts.Title: Dre ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Sorry to be the bearer of bad news. Your post operation pathology is worrisome: G9, positive margin, with one positive lymph node and positive bladder neck. In my non professional opinion, your cancer is probably still there, so if I were you I would go immediately into plan B, with perhaps adjuvant RT and hormone start right away to hopefully catch the cancer before it goes systemic. Get a second opinion from a prostate oncologist ASAP if I were you. Good luck. I reluctantly agree with newporter. While you can hope for the best, you have to prepare for the worst. Plan out a course of action immediately with a prostate oncologist who specializes in salvage radiation. You've "debulked" the G9, gotten rid of at least 99.9% of it. If its not totally gone, then a tiny part is hiding in a corner, and needs one final blow to kill it off. Discuss with the oncologist whether immediate treatment is warranted in order to be 100% sure that it's banished forever. Good Luck

Posts.Title: My Post-Op Pathology

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Sorry to be the bearer of bad news. Your post operation pathology is worrisome: G9, positive margin, with one positive lymph node and positive bladder neck. In my non professional opinion, your cancer is probably still there, so if I were you I would go immediately into plan B, with perhaps adjuvant RT and hormone start right away to hopefully catch the cancer before it goes systemic. Get a second opinion from a prostate oncologist ASAP if I were you. Good luck. I reluctantly agree with newporter. While you can hope for the best, you have to prepare for the worst. Plan out a course of action immediately with a prostate oncologist who specializes in salvage radiation. You've "debulked" the G9, gotten rid of at least 99.9% of it. If its not totally gone, then a tiny part is hiding in a corner, and needs one final blow to kill it off. Discuss with the oncologist whether immediate treatment is warranted in order to be 100% sure that it's banished forever. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Uncle Bill This is my first post since 2013. I'm hoping someone can help me understand what's going on with me. My PSA count in July 2015 was 4.9, a big jump from January 2015 at 3.0. I included below about an eight year history of my PSA counts. As you can see my counts have always been high for my age group. Earlier this month my doctor put me on Bactrim twice a day for thirty days and will retest me again in September. I have a feeling another biopsy is coming. Should I ask for an MRI first? I'm very active. I workout twice a day 5 times a week and I run a couple times a week. I been having a lot of lower abdominal pain, most of the pain happens when I run. It seems I have a lot of inflammation in my pelvic area and lower back area. Would this cause an increase in PSA levels? I stopped taking fish oil because I heard it can cause an increase. I'm very worried Date PSA age 7/15 4.9 49 1/15 3.0 49 5/14 3.6 48 9/13 3.6 47 3/12 3.2 46 free PSA 14% 4/11 3.4 45 7/11 biopsy 44 5/10 3.1 44 9/9 3.2 43 2/9 2.3 43 5/8 2.1 42 1/8 2.4 42 If your insurance covers it, you should consider a T3(?) MRI which would help "target" the biopsy to suspicious-looking spots. Others will have the exact name of the test and process. Good Luck

Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: First, see a therapist to get your emotions under control... Is it PCa which freaks you out, or the thought of any kind of cancer..? Assuming that the biopsy is negative, then, due to your family history, perhaps you should consider yourself on "watchful waiting" or "Active Surveillance" right now... so if you do get bad PCa news next week, or next year, or even five or ten years from now you'll be fully prepared to kick the PC the hell out of your body, and not be scrambling for information like most of were. If it makes you feel better, then do everything possible to detect PCa as early as possible.... even if it means what some people would call "overtesting".... For example, get a 3Tesla MRI like Pratoman suggests and see if your insurance will pay for it on an annual basis. If it makes you feel better, get your PSA tested every six months. Not everyone will agree with me on this as most believe an annual PSA and DRE with a physical is enough... but everyone agrees that PCa is very slow growing and catching it as early as possible vastly increases the chances for a 100% cure. good luck

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla Hi Barry... you may want to get a second opinion on the biopsy. Your uro may know of someone or you can have him send it to John Hopkins. Also given no findings on the DRE any treatment you may decide to go with should have an excellent chance of success. But if a second opinion comes back as a 3+3 it means you may also have the alternative of AS. In any case, it sounds like you have some time to absorb and learn that the best choice is for you. Good Luck! I was also diagnosed with a G3+4 and was given the choice of having a second opinion, and if it was G3+3, researching AS. After much deliberation, I decided not to, because for me (and everyone is different), as someone who was qualified did rate me as a G3+4. For me to proceed with AS, I would need TWO reports of G6 (ie, a "solid" G6). I'm also not the type of person who would feel comfortable with AS (I wanted the surgery the day after I found out the biopsy was positive and was told i needed to wait six weeks). Also, your testosterone replacement therapy may also contraindicate AS, if you decide to go that route. Read the stickies, take a deep breath, and good luck!

Posts.Title: 17 Days post op

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ron_G So, I got my first issue of the 'Discovery' quarterly newsletter from Hopkins since my surgery. Pretty informative regarding PC and treatment developments. Aside from that, from what it's indicating, the new protocol regarding PC scores that were developed by Jonathan Epstein and presented at the American Urological Association meeting in New Orleans have been accepted by the World Health Organization and will be used in conjunction with the current Gleason system "until it becomes widely accepted and practiced." It seems he's trying to simplify and categorize things better. Grade Group 1: Gleason 3+3=6 Grade Group 2: Gleason 3+4=7 Grade Group 3: Gleason 4+3=7 Grade Group 4: Gleason 8 Grade Group 5: Gleason 9 & 10 Some may have already heard of this proposal, but this is the first I've heard of its acceptance. Seems the G7 needed to be clarified, as well as the fact that nothing lower than a G6 would be diagnosed anyways. this looks interesting, as long as the number of cores and percent involvement are also reported and taken into account when deciding on whether or not AS is an option

Posts.Title: New PCa grading system

Posts.Content: In my case, I was diagnosed with G3+4 in one core, <5%. One Dr strongly suggested AS. I decided that if I was diagnosed with G6, then AS would have been an option... and I would have had a second opinion to validate the first diagnosis. And if both reads were for G6, then I would have called it a "True G6", and would have started on the AS path. But I ultimately decided that since I was "awarded" a G3+4 on my first biopsy, SOMEONE saw something which looked like G4. Therefore, my "threshold" for AS was exceeded, and a second opinion did not matter, and it was time for active treatment. I made the right choice as I was one of those 20% or so who was upgraded, to G4+3.

Posts.Title: 81 viewers..more than any other forum..?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla Hi Barry... you may want to get a second opinion on the biopsy. Your uro may know of someone or you can have him send it to John Hopkins. Also given no findings on the DRE any treatment you may decide to go with should have an excellent chance of success. But if a second opinion comes back as a 3+3 it means you may also have the alternative of AS. In any case, it sounds like you have some time to absorb and learn that the best choice is for you. Good Luck! I was also diagnosed with a G3+4 and was given the choice of having a second opinion, and if it was G3+3, researching AS. After much deliberation, I decided not to, because for me (and everyone is different), as someone who was qualified did rate me as a G3+4. For me to proceed with AS, I would need TWO reports of G6 (ie, a "solid" G6). I'm also not the type of person who would feel comfortable with AS (I wanted the surgery the day after I found out the biopsy was positive and was told i needed to wait six weeks). Also, your testosterone replacement therapy may also contraindicate AS, if you decide to go that route. Read the stickies, take a deep breath, and good luck!

Posts.Title: Vitamins after RP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 Dave, suggest you read response to recent thread titled New here...looking for Lupron info. by those on it. Responses to that thread will give you info. As to answers to your co-workers situation, your questions are rather fragmented, and so difficult to answer. It is typical for men to have a psa test. If high, then a biopsy of the prostate to detect cancer, and Gleason score rating. Has this been done?? This then determines what needs, or needs not be done, in the way of future treatment. Apologies for the fragmented question. The information I received is from my "work spouse" so it's a bit spotty. Her brother never had physicals or had PSA tested. When he had urination problems, to make a long story short, he had a TURP. It turns out that his Gleason Score is G9 (not sure if it is a 4+5 or 5+4) and his PSA is "over 700". It did spread to "his bones". He is scheduled for a full-body scan as well. Today, he will receive hormone treatment for one month, reassess how he responds to the initial treatment, and then have the dosage or meds adjusted and go for another hormone treatment. In addition, his oncologist recommended chemo. So i'ts no longer a case of "short-term" hormone treatment. I've suggested several times that my coworker visits this forum as well as her brother.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago "In more than 14,000 radical prostatectomies, there was not a single case of a Gleason score 6 tumor ever spreading to lymph nodes." Though there is always the chance of finding a 3+4 or 4+3 in the post surgical pathology report, the information above may well allow many more men to be willing to go ahead with AS for several years. Zero in 14,000 is pretty impressive. Knowing that something like 20% (25%?) of biopsies results are upgraded, one can only hope that PC detection (biopsy, MRI etc) and the reliability of biopsy scoring increases

Posts.Title: Great Article about Gleason 6, New Gleason Groups

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". I was a Gleason 3+4 and was given the choice of getting a second opinion to see if it could be downgraded to a G6. I decided against it as someone who was qualified decided I was a G3+4, and decided that I would have needed two "solid" G6's for me to go with AS. I then needed to decide what type of treatment. I scheduled my surgery (I believe you need to wait between 6 and 8 weeks after the biopsy to the prostate to heal) in the meantime. I figured I could always cancel my surgery if I changed my mind and went with radiation, but if I did not change my mind, I already had a place "reserved" for my surgery. After much agonizing, I went ahead with the surgery (robotic). I decided on robotic because, while it is a longer surgery (and therefore a greater risk for people with heart issues), it does have a faster recovery from surgery. I also believe that with robotic surgery, there's a larger percentage of people who regain full urinary control vs open. -- I believe because it's easier toreconstruct/restitch one of the muscles down there a bit better with Robotic vs Open. But the most important thing, if you decide on surgery, is to find an experienced one. (The above is my personal opinion and experiences) Please read all of the stickies on the top of the board, and good luck with whatever treatment you decide.

Posts.Title: Is this calculator accurate????

Posts.Content: First off, I'm happy to say that I am still in the Zero Club. Even though I could have my PSA teste annually, I am still having it tested every six months. It's reduced a lot of stress on my part knowing that if my PSA does rise, it will be caught in less than six months rather than a year. Anyway, a coworker's brother, 60 years old, did not have annual physicals or any PSA testing. Suddenly he could not pee. A catheter was put in and he was put on a drug to help with urinary flow. within a day after the catheter was taken out, he had the same issue so he had a "scraping" to help with his urinary problems. I believe it was open surgery but I am not 100% sure. The result of the "scraping" was positive for PCa. I don't know the Gleason score or any other details as present. His Dr is discussing radiation. The X-rays were negative and he's waiting word on the results of the MRI. A couple of questions... 1 - how long is a typical time to wait before radiation after surgery? 2 - while he heals, would a one-time hormone treatment be something to consider? I guess Lupron but I my be wrong. Or should this only be considered if his PCa did spread, and/or he has a high Gleason score? 3 - What are the side effects of a one-time treatment? Thanks! -Dave

Posts.Title: Short Term Effects of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". I was a Gleason 3+4 and was given the choice of getting a second opinion to see if it could be downgraded to a G6. I decided against it as someone who was qualified decided I was a G3+4, and decided that I would have needed two "solid" G6's for me to go with AS. I then needed to decide what type of treatment. I scheduled my surgery (I believe you need to wait between 6 and 8 weeks after the biopsy to the prostate to heal) in the meantime. I figured I could always cancel my surgery if I changed my mind and went with radiation, but if I did not change my mind, I already had a place "reserved" for my surgery. After much agonizing, I went ahead with the surgery (robotic). I decided on robotic because, while it is a longer surgery (and therefore a greater risk for people with heart issues), it does have a faster recovery from surgery. I also believe that with robotic surgery, there's a larger percentage of people who regain full urinary control vs open. -- I believe because it's easier toreconstruct/restitch one of the muscles down there a bit better with Robotic vs Open. But the most important thing, if you decide on surgery, is to find an experienced one. (The above is my personal opinion and experiences) Please read all of the stickies on the top of the board, and good luck with whatever treatment you decide.

Posts.Title: New guy...dazed and confused

Posts.Content: As others have said, the number of cores, and the percent of each core, is very important on whether or not to consider Active Surveillance (AS). And some of us may not be "wired" for AS. If the number of cores and % involvement is low enough for AS, and you decide on pursuing AS as an option, have your slides sent out to another lab and see if the other lab agrees on a G6. To me, I would need two labs both agreeing on a G6 before deciding on AS. The good news is that with a G6, you don't have to rush to decide on treatment. As others have said, if you do decide on treatment. See a good, experienced surgeon and a good experienced radiologist. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Gleason 6

Posts.Content: Some of us aren't "wired" for AS (and especially considering there's about a 25% chance of a higher-grade missed by the biopsy). Others can if it is low-risk (but with three cores you are sort of borderline). I believe i would have considered AS under the right conditions, but with a very low "trigger" for active treatment. Alas, I was not given the choice with a G3+4 (and it ended up G4+3). If you insist on AS, then you should send the slides to John Hopkins to ensure they agree with a G6, and consider doing the test mentioned by ASAdvocate as well as those in the AS sticky.... Perhaps have PSA drawn every three months for the next year. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy HAMA PSA rise from 0.02 to 0.04 (still < 0.1 guide) worry? HELP!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde Hello Brava, I also have one metal hip and my surgeon said there was no point of a MRI since the picture gets very distorted so they did not do it. I had the surgery anyway and for me it went fine. Nerves spared, cancer free after one year and very little incontinence. As I understand it the surgeon takes the decision on nerve-sparing when he actually sees the prostate during surgery and if there is no visible tumor he can go ahead. Good Luck Would a metal hip complicate radiation? Brava - stock up on the Viagra now... some insurance companies will only approve 6 or so a month, so make sure you have a head-start. Good luck

Posts.Title: Easing the prostatectomy experience for husband

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wifey No he means 2 weeks from the date of surgery which I just can't see happening. He's most worried about having the cathether in (and out) That seems rather aggressive. I have a desk job and I know I needed about two weeks after the catheter was out to feel ready to go back to work. Even then, I did need to get up and go "tinkle" or "adjust things" and check on my guy every hour or so, and change my pad if neeeded.

Posts.Title: Easing the prostatectomy experience for husband

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Whitney777 I'm starting a Low-Iodine soon in preparation for RAI treatment. Any good menu ideas? Does anyone have advice on good Hormone Replacement, T4 only, T4, T3 combo (Thyrolar) or natural such as Armour. Also curious if besides diet and exercise if there is any other metabolism boosting supplements I can take? I have been slender and athletic my entire life and am so afraid to start gaining weight. My wife has been on synthroid and armour and for the past 15 years. It takes a while to get the dose right but once it is correct everything will be fine. There is a school of thought that Armour is better because it contains both T-3 and T-4 but there have been severe shortages lately. One endocrinologist she spoke to said that the amount of T3/T4 in Armour may vary a bit (since it is natural) which makes identifying the correct dosage more difficult. For a while she was on both Syntheroid and Armour (the Armour in a smaller dose) with her endocrinologist doing some fancy math to convert it to a pure Syntheroid dosage. She said she felt better that way but I never noticed a difference.... But for the last three years or so the shortages of Armour have made it very difficult and challenging so she's been on just Syntheroid. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Post DaVinci Fatigue

Posts.Content: Good news and good advise. With G9, testing PSA every two months for at least a year may not be a bad idea.
Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Posts.Content: I would start with the "What-I-Need-to-Know-About-Da-Vinci-surgery" sticky... It contains many first-hand experiences from others who had DaVinci surgery. Also, it's important to tell your hubby that even though he may feel better after a few weeks , it's really important to wait a full six weeks before lifting anything heavier than a gallon of milk or doing anything with twisting motions. In the meantime, do the dirty deed as often as possible

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: You'll see weekly progress, don't get caught up in day-to-day. I had my first beer over the weekend and I felt like I was back to week one. Kegels are good, there are lots of posts about the best way to do them. Just don't overdo it and exhaust the muscle.

Posts.Title: 9 days post-op

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wifey No he means 2 weeks from the date of surgery which I just can't see happening. He's most worried about having the cathether in (and out) That seems rather aggressive. I have a desk job and I know I needed about two weeks after the catheter was out to feel ready to go back to work. Even then, I did need to get up and go "tinkle" or "adjust things" and check on my guy every hour or so, and change my pad if neeeded.

Posts.Title: Easing the prostatectomy experience for husband

Posts.Content: As you need treatment, I'm not sure what would be gained by a second opinion. In my case, I had a single G3+4 core and thought about a second opinion. But even if the second opinion was a G6, I decided that someone read my biopsy as G7, which crossed my threshold of A.S. vs treatment. And after an RP, it turns out I was a G4+3 so I made the right decision. In my opinion, you should instead concentrate on deciding on treatment paths...
Posts.Title: Second Opinion Costs/Benefits

Posts.Content: Bubble-wrap and duct tape. Tape him to his favorite chair. Seriously, waaay to soon for anything like this. Even when the catheter and staples are out.

Posts.Title: Sustained relatively high PSA confirming next steps

Posts.Content: I scheduled my surgery and looked into the other options. That way if I decided on the surgery, I knew my spot was already "reserved" and if I decided against surgery I could always cancel. I believe surgeons will always try to perform nerve-sparing surgery if they can. The surgeon could give an indication when they read the report butthere's no guarantee. Depends on the location of the PCa and the skill of the surgeon.... In my case, I'm not where I was before my surgery sexually. In your case, you'll want to pick the absolutely most experienced surgeon possible even if it means traveling several hundred miles or more.. Or decide against the surgery and do some other treatment. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Dad's PSA is still 0!!!

Posts.Content: Some medical centers and hospitals do "Guided Biopsies", where a T3 MRI is first performed which will help guide the biopsy needles into any areas of concern. You should ask about it. In the meantime, find a good experienced (400+) surgeon just in case the biopsy was positive. That way you will already be prepared just in case. I believe you are also going to prescribed a few days of antibiotics to take after the biopsy. I'm wondering if you could ask for a larger dose (maybe 10 days worth, ask your urologist), in case the cause of your high PSA is an infection. Then you'll already be on the antibiotics you'll need. Good luck

Posts.Content: I would start with the "What-I-Need-to-Know-About-Da-Vinci-surgery" sticky... It contains many first-hand experiences from others who had DaVinci surgery. Also, it's important to tell your hubby that even though he may feel better after a few weeks , it's really important to wait a full six weeks before lifting anything heavier than a gallon of milk or doing anything with twisting motions. In the meantime, do the dirty deed as often as possible

Posts.Title: 6 weeks post ralp

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". You can add to your signature some details (number of positive cores, location of the positives, % involvement, Gleason 3+4 or 4+3, etc). As you will soon find out, surgeons tend to recommend surgery and radiologists tend to recommend seeds or other types of radiation. To my case, deciding upon a treatment course was almost as stressful as the initial diagnosis. Whichever way to choose, experience is key.... For example, if you decide on surgery, then choose one (open or DaVinci) who's performed at least 300-400 (some say 1200) of those surgeries. Read the stickies at the top of the forum, Get Walsh's book. No matter what you decide, you have some time to decide -- For example, even if you decided on surgery today, you have to wait a minimum of six weeks after the biopsy to proceed (not sure about the other treatments). Good luck. You are not alone...

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". You can add to your signature some details (number of positive cores, location of the positives, % involvement, Gleason 3+4 or 4+3, etc). As you will soon find out, surgeons tend to recommend surgery and radiologists tend to recommend seeds or other types of radiation. To my case, deciding upon a treatment course was almost as stressful as the initial diagnosis. Whichever way to choose, experience is key.... For example, if you decide on surgery, then choose one (open or DaVinci) who's performed at least 300-400 (some say 1200) of those surgeries. Read the stickies at the top of the forum, Get Walsh's book. No matter what you decide, you have some time to decide -- For example, even if you decided on surgery today, you have to wait a minimum of six weeks after the biopsy to proceed (not sure about the other treatments). Good luck. You are not alone...

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mosserj Hi members After putting off a biopsy for awhile I finally had one recently and received my results by email, at my request, as my urologist is away for a week. The results for this healthy 66 year old were a Gleason 7 (3+4) on 6 cores and Gleason 6 (3+3) on a further 6 cores of the 15 taken. Some perineurial invasions on 2 cores. Recent PSA of 9.1 and %fPSA of 9 and PHI of 62. Having read many forum posts the first thing I am doing is keeping calm and reading. Life is what it is and the way forward for me has always involved no panicking and informed decision making. Clearly my next step will be to understand from my urologist surgeon the initial biopsy results, any further imaging and suggestive curative treatments. In the mean time I am avidly reading for information. Happy for any member feedback to assist me in my initial phase and considerations, noting choices for the future will be supported by the Doctors recommendations and my gained knowledge. A warm but reluctant welcome to the forum and our "club". "Step Zero" would be to order Dr. Patrick Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". I'm not sure a second opinion on the sides is necessary as you are in the "absolutely need treatment" category. You should ask about additional scans to ensure that nothing has spread... Also, if surgery is an option, then then find a good experienced (minimum 400+) surgeon and schedule the surgery. (You need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy). Then research and interview radiation and other treatments. That way if you decide on another treatment, you can simply cancel the surgery. But if decide to on the surgery, you already have it scheduled for the earliest possible date and will never have to second-guess yourself regarding treatment. Good luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: The results for this healthy 66 year old were a Gleason

Posts.Title: Hitting a platform

Posts.Content: Your stomach will be very bloated so a seat which reclines will be important. My ride was about 30 minutes but felt twice as long. Be prepared to stop a couple of times (perhaps to empty your bag). There shouldn't be any leakage as your catheter will be your lil' buddy for the next week or so. I didn't have a donut but for the long ride I can see how that would be nice to have. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Dad's post op diagnosis question

Posts.Content: I find carbonated beverages, alcohol, and especially beer cause me to leak. Don't overdo the Kegals - it's a small muscle and you may be tiring it out without realizing it. I wonder if Kegals should be treated like weightlifting and done every other day in order to give the muscle time to rest and rejuvenate (or at least alternate "heavy" kegal days with "light" ones). I seem to recall someone mentioning that the best way to determine if the Kegals are being performed correctly is to try them while urinating as there should be some change in the flow if you are targeting the right muscle. Some people have also mentioned biofeedback, so you may wish to see if there's someplace nearby which specializes in this type of biofeedback. It will get better. Good luck.

Posts.Content: I would start with the "What-I-Need-to-Know-About-Da-Vinci-surgery" sticky... It contains many first-hand experiences from others who had DaVinci surgery. Also, it's important to tell your hubby that even though he may feel better after a few weeks , it's really important to wait a full six weeks before lifting anything heavier than a gallon of milk or doing anything with twisting motions. In the meantime, do the dirty deed as often as possible

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: Some medical centers and hospitals do "Guided Biopsies", where a T3 MRI is first performed which will help guide the biopsy needles into any areas of concern. You should ask about it. In the meantime, find a good experienced (400+) surgeon just in case the biopsy was positive. That way you will already be prepared just in case. I believe you are also going to prescribed a few days of antibiotics to take after the biopsy. I'm wondering if you could ask for a larger dose (maybe 10 days worth, ask your urologist), in case the cause of your high PSA is an infection. Then you'll already be on the antibiotics you'll need. Good luck

Posts.Title: PSA of 22.39

Posts.Content: I scheduled my surgery and looked into the other options. That way if I decided on the surgery, I knew my spot was already "reserved" and if I decided against surgery I could always cancel. I believe surgeons will always try to perform nerve-sparing surgery if they can. The surgeon could give an indication when they read the report butthere's no guarantee. Depends on the location of the PCa and the skill of the surgeon.... In my case, I'm not where I was before my surgery sexually. In your case, you'll want to pick the absolutely most experienced surgeon possible even if it means traveling several hundred miles or more.. Or decide against the surgery and do some other treatment. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PecenkA Well there is no hope left for a complete cure. His PSA 3 months after surgery is 12.4. He was given 18 months at best using all available treatments. I still have a question though. I'm completely lost on what we should get him for his birthday which is in 2 weeks. For his birthday... Maybe all of you should go out to an IMAX 3D movie and get all of your minds off of things for a few hours. Or find out his favorite movie and rent it. Don't give up hope... here are members here who had PSA in the hundreds and even THOUSANDS who are around for almost ten years (I hope they post here).

Posts.Title: PSA of 22.39

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". You can add to your signature some details (number of positive cores, location of the positives, % involvement, Gleason 3+4 or 4+3, etc). As you will soon find out, surgeons tend to recommend surgery and radiologists tend to recommend seeds or other types of radiation. To my case, deciding upon a treatment course was almost as stressful as the initial diagnosis. Whichever way to choose, experience is key.... For example, if you decide on surgery, then choose one (open or DaVinci) who's performed at least 300-400 (some say 1200) of those surgeries. Read the stickies at the top of the forum, Get Walsh's book. No matter what you decide, you have some time to decide -- For example, even if you decided on surgery today, you have to wait a minimum of six weeks after the biopsy to proceed (not sure about the other treatments). Good luck. You are not alone...

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mosserj Hi members After putting off a biopsy for awhile I finally had one recently and received my results by email, at my request, as my urologist is away for a week. The results for this healthy 66 year old were a Gleason 7 (3+4) on 6 cores and Gleason 6 (3+3) on a further 6 cores of the 15 taken. Some perineurial invasions on 2 cores. Recent PSA of 9.1 and %fPSA of 9 and PHI of 62. Having read many forum posts the first thing I am doing is keeping calm and reading. Life is what it is and the way forward for me has always involved no panicking and informed decision making. Clearly my next step will be to understand from my urologist surgeon the initial biopsy results, any further imaging and suggestive curative treatments. In the mean time I am avidly reading for information. Happy for any member feedback to assist me in my initial phase and considerations, noting choices for the future will be supported by the Doctors recommendations and my gained knowledge. A warm but reluctant welcome to the forum and our "club". "Step Zero" would be to order Dr. Patrick Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". I'm not sure a second opinion on the sides is necessary as you are in the "absolutely need treatment" category. You should ask about additional scans to ensure that nothing has spread... Also, if surgery is an option, then then find a good experienced (minimum 400+) surgeon and schedule the surgery. (You need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy). Then research and interview radiation and other treatments. That way if you decide on another treatment, you can simply cancel the surgery. But if decide to on the surgery, you already have it scheduled for the earliest possible date and will never have to second-guess yourself regarding treatment. Good luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: The results for this healthy 66 year old were a Gleason

Posts.Title: Biopsy/Treatment if in early stages of Dementia

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Being on anticoagulants may be problematic for a prostate biopsy (as you allude to in Post #5), so there is risk in doing the biopsy to confirm PC. Alternatively, a 3T MRI can provide the needed information for a PC diagnosis if biopsy can not be performed. Also, have they done a "bone scan?" MF A 3T MRI sounds like a very good idea, even if the biopsy can be performed - it should help the urologist "zero in" on any suspicious spots. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Blood Clots revealed PSA of 94.0

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JMorris271 Hi Everyone. I'm so thankful I found this forum and the good people here. Ok. Here it goes. I was just informed that I had joined the 7 (3+4) club 3 weeks ago. and have been trying to glean what I can to have my cancer treated. One point that resonates with me is to find the best surgeon, Rad/oncol possible. I'm at a loss of how to go about that. With no contacts in medical circles or first hand knowledge of my areas talent. Does anyone have suggestions on where I can begin researching and rating my doctor options? Thank you so much and Merry Christmas. A reluctant welcome to our "club". I would get a copy of the latest edition of Dr Wash's book "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". A few questions to consider: How many cores were positive? Would you be willing to have the slides sent out for a second opinion to determine if it a G3+3 instead? (and if so, would that even make a difference or do you just want treatment and not consider AS)? Do you have any leanings toward radiation vs surgery? (such as wanting the cancer "out" as quickly as possible? ) Do you live close to a first-class medical center (or would you mind traveling to one and staying a few days)? Do you have any preexisting medical conditions (such as heart trouble) which may preclude surgery? As far a a surgeon goes, the most important item is experience - at least 400 (or even better, 1000+ surgeries). I was also a G3+4. One Dr highly recommended that I get a second opinion on my slides to see if I could be downgraded to a G3+3 and start on AS. I decided against it, because even though I am "wired" for AS, my "threshold" or "trigger" to go off AS is rather low, and I would have required two different labs agreeing on a G3+3 as a prerequisite before even starting on AS. I then researched surgeons and picked one who had more than 400 surgeries (robotic). I scheduled the surgery while STILL researching radiation -- that way I could cancel the surgery if I decided on radiation but keep the appointment if I decided on the surgery after all. I kept my original appointment and had the surgery -- and since I already had the appointment, I never had to second-guess myself with "what ifs" because I put off the surgery while researching the alternatives. Good luck with whatever you choose, we have a reservation in your name in the "zero" club waiting for you.

Posts.Content: When it rains it pours I feel for you Regarding the Rocco stitch, I asked my surgeon and he says that he doesn't do it, but does something better (whatever that means). Just the fact that my surgeon was very familiar with the Rocco stitch, and said that his success rate is as good or better, gave me a warm-and-fuzzy feeling. And he was right.... I just purchased three 50 lb bags of rock salt, put them in my trunk, and then into the garage. A total of one tiny little squirt, which I could have prevented if I thought about it first is proof that he was basically right. (Meanwhile my back and ankle feel like they need surgery........)

Posts.Content: I find carbonated beverages, alcohol, and especially beer cause me to leak. Don't overdo the Kegals - it's a small muscle and you may be tiring it out without realizing it. I wonder if Kegals should be treated like weightlifting and done every other day in order to give the muscle time to rest and rejuvenate (or at least alternate "heavy" kegal days with "light" ones). I seem to recall someone mentioning that the best way to determine if the Kegals are being performed correctly is to try them while urinating as there should be some change in the flow if you are targeting the right muscle. Some people have also mentioned biofeedback, so you may wish to see if there's someplace nearby which specializes in this type of biofeedback. It will get better. Good luck.

Posts.Title: How do you choose the right surgeon and hospital to perform a daVinci Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut Interesting article from Bloomberg. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html Clip from the article: Given the recent spike in infection complications after prostate biopsy, the ideal method to diagnose prostate cancer must be pondered, Matthew Gettman, professor of urology at the Mayo Graduate School of Medicine in Rochester, Minnesota, wrote in an editorial in the journal European Urology last May. Despite local anesthetics, the whole procedure is barbaric, and it is surprising that the issue of infection has not come to light years ago. Knowing what I do now (hindsight is always 20-20), knowing that... Biopsies do have a risk, such as infections You can't have an infinite number of biopsies without issues such as scarring Biopsies can miss PCa Biopsies may catch PCa but miss the higher Gleason Grade Until an MRI is found to be as accurate or more accurate than a biopsy, biopsies are the "Gold Standard" and will continue to be used. Therefore, I would do my best to ensure that each biopsy has the best chance being accurate. Therefore, I'm wondering if one should always have an MRI Guided/Targeted biopsy instead of a "blind", 12-core standard biopsy... For example, see this article: http://www.nwhroboticsurgery.org/def...lay/news_id,10. (This was my surgeon, who I do recommend. He did not do my biopsies)

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: What is a "multi-core biopsy"? Is that like a saturation biopsy where 20+ cores are taken? Also, ask about a MRI-guided/targeted biopsy - I believe with a targeted biopsy, more samples will be taken from "suspicious" areas. Since repeated biopsies (I believe more than 3 or 4) can cause issues if you need have your "friend" removed, you need to make sure each biopsy counts! You may also consider going to a "center of excellence" and consult with surgeons who are experienced with large prostates. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Prowler My purpose here is not to scare anyone from their choice of treatment options but to make them aware of possible complications and a better advocate for themselves. Believe it or not, you may know your body better than your doctor. About three days after surgery at NYU hospital in Sept 2013, I developed a fever just under the cutoff for calling in to the doctor 101F. As you are on pain and antibiotic meds your temperature will be suppressed. I called the hotline anyway and was told not to worry but call back if you surpass 101F which it never did. As I live 200 miles north of NYC I had retained a hotel near NYU for ten days in the event a complication should occur. As it turned out the large incision at the umbilicus where the prostate gland was pulled through, had opened. When I presented myself first thing Monday morning at the doctors offices I at first was treated very poorly as to why I was there and then their response was that my wife should be able to dress my wound. When they saw that the wound was open and you can look at the deep hole in my body their attitude changed. However, they kept telling me the wound wasn't infected as the drainage was clear but since I was on Cipro as the cath was still in place they were wrong. Every morning I went to the doctors office and was told the same thing (no infection) as they had to pack a wet dressing deep into the wound. They had to arrange for a nurse to come to my home each day to dress the wound and allow it to heal from the bottom up. Once an incision opens it is considered a dirty wound that must be allowed to heal on its own. This took three months to heal and when I got home my internist changed the antibiotic after lab tests showed a staph infection that proved very difficult to resolve. I took antibiotics for nearly three months to clear the infection that would return every three days after completing that course of drugs. The problem here was that even though I felt I had a wound infection and kept telling them so from right after surgery, no doctor would believed me until I completed a round of drugs and smelly yellow fluid squirted out into my doctor's face as she pressed around the open wound that at least three doctors and many nurses said was not infected. Now that they had proof, they could then collect the yellow fluid to send to the lab and determine the best antibiotic treatment. Finally clear of infection, at my urging, my doctor ordered a CAT scan to see that there was no internal access and make sure all was well. The scan showed a huge mass in my abdominal area that the radiologist thought was cancer. My doctor thought I was history. It was nearly two liters in size, compressing and displacing my bladder to the left. After much worry a good surgeon I went to said it wasn't cancer but rather a very large lynphocele caused by removing a lymph node and not having a proper seal to stop the leakage of fluid. This process developed a cyst with many cambers containing fluid. Even though you may pick a fine surgeon to perform the robotic surgery he may be training others who may perform the lesser tasks like removing and sealing off lymph nodes. This may be especially true in teaching hospitals. I was told the lymphocele could be left in place unless it presented a problem. Some research literature states that small lymphoceles about the size of golf balls are quite common after cancer surgery but go undetected unless found as a result of imaging tests for some unrelated problem. About two months later I developed a very high fever 103+F and was rushed to a hospital and treated as a septis patient, a life threatening blood infection. I was put on every interveinous drug they had on the shelf and nothing lowered my fever. It turned out that Strep bacteria had invaded the lymph fluid in the lymphocele and I needed immediate surgery as drugs cannot get to the infected fluid. This was a very big surgery a difficult recovery with a large incision from my umbilical to nearly my penis. Then after about six months recovery from these issues I developed a very big incisional hernia with small intestine bulging about four or five inches out from my stomach. The surgeon said it was probably a result of the tissue having been weakened from the prior infection. He wants me to undergo a four hour surgery to repair the hernia by patching in some pig skin at the defect. I am reluctant to do this as there is about a 40% chance it will fail and the hernial will return. I wear an elastic wrap to somewhat hide and protect the hernia. The good news is that my PSA at two years post op is 0.00! Although all of the many doctors and radiologists I saw steered my toward surgery due to my age and general good health, I may have been better served or had an easier experience had I chosen another treatment or maybe a local surgeon rather than a "world class" university hospital. Holy Sh*t!!! The space where my prostate was hurts just reading your story! I hope its all downhill from now on!

Posts.Title: Negative, but

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glr3 Did not find a post about "What I Wish I Knew About Prostate Biopsies" before I had one. If there is one, can anyone direct me to it. If not, would anyone care to provide comments? My biopsy was painless. First one did not detect anything, the second one six months later did... It did feel weird when the needle(?) was pushed up there but since I had nerve blockers it didn't hurt at all. For some reason during my two biopsy visits the Dr had the most beautiful assistants that day... It was almost like he planned it The urine may have blood for the next week or so, the semen definitely will. The "standard" biopsy is 12 "cores". There are different types of biopsies, such as a "saturation biopsy" and a "guided biopsy", which can be used if the PSA level continues to rise to hopefully detect if there's cancer cells... I believe these "special" biopsies are usually used for people on AS or where the PSA continues to rise. There's also a limit to the number of biopsies one can have (3 or 4 I believe) before the scar tissue becomes an issue

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut Interesting article from Bloomberg. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html Clip from the article: Given the recent spike in infection complications after prostate biopsy, the ideal method to diagnose prostate cancer must be pondered, Matthew Gettman, professor of urology at the Mayo Graduate School of Medicine in Rochester, Minnesota, wrote in an editorial in the journal European Urology last May. Despite local anesthetics, the whole procedure is barbaric, and it is surprising that the issue of infection has not come to light years ago. Knowing what I do now (hindsight is always 20-20), knowing that... Biopsies do have a risk, such as infections You can't have an infinite number of biopsies without issues such as scarring Biopsies can miss PCa Biopsies may catch PCa but miss the higher Gleason Grade Until an MRI is found to be as accurate or more accurate than a biopsy, biopsies are the "Gold Standard" and will continue to be used. Therefore, I would do my best to ensure that each biopsy has the best chance being accurate. Therefore, I'm wondering if one should always have an MRI Guided/Targeted biopsy instead of a "blind", 12-core standard biopsy... For example, see this article: http://www.nwhroboticsurgery.org/def...lay/news_id,10. (This was my surgeon, who I do recommend. He did not do my biopsies)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rebern Greater Atlanta area. Travel would be very difficult. Would like to be able to travel but have local issues I can not get out of. Not to mention insurance issues. I would check out http://health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/area/atlanta-ga and other web sites and first choose a good hospital (a teaching hospital would also be good choice, as long as it's highly rated). Then research the individual Drs at those hospitals for ratings at healthgrades and other DR-ratings sites. Hopefully you'll have a "short list" of surgeons who are a)highly rated, b)work at a highly-rated hospital, and c)accept your insurance. Then you can set up appointments with each one and ask your questions. I can't find any right now, but there have been several posts regarding questions to ask your surgeon like positive margins, number of surgeries, etc. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Finding an experienced surgeon. How to?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glr3 Did not find a post about "What I Wish I Knew About Prostate Biopsies" before I had one. If there is one, can anyone direct me to it. If not, would anyone care to provide comments? My biopsy was painless. First one did not detect anything, the second one six months later did... It did feel weird when the needle(?) was pushed up there but since I had nerve blockers it didn't hurt at all. For some reason during my two biopsy visits the Dr had the most beautiful assistants that day... It was almost like he planned it The urine may have blood for the next week or so, the semen definitely will. The "standard" biopsy is 12 "cores". There are different types of biopsies, such as a "saturation biopsy" and a "guided biopsy", which can be used if the PSA level continues to rise to hopefully detect if there's cancer cells... I believe these "special" biopsies are usually used for people on AS or where the PSA continues to rise. There's also a limit to the number of biopsies one can have (3 or 4 I believe) before the scar tissue becomes an issue

Posts.Title: Question about active surveillance protocol

Posts.Content: this board has had some sad stories recently and I decided to share some of my good news... I've been wearing a light pad for the past few months. Have two or three small squirts a day, especially when lifting or for some reason right after I go to the bathroom. Anyway, I haven't improved for the past month or so and I "got used to" the squirts. I decided to "shake things up a bit" and try to go padless. So far so good. it's like I'm back three weeks after surgery in that I'm paying attention down there again to make sure I don't leak. One small squirt the first day and otherwise only a small drop or two. I only put a pad on before the gym. Two down, one to go. Tried maximum dose of Viagra and all it did was give me a splitting headache.. that trimex is looking better and better...
