Posts.Title: How Do You Feel After Surgery

Posts.Content: I still have occasional small "squirts" and I always feel like I haven't fully emptied my bladder. I actually walk away for a second and then go back for a final "squirt". Things do feel slightly different but I guess that is the "new normal" for me.
Posts.Signature: BD: 1959 PSA 4.9 11/2012 (no symptoms) Biopsy 12/2012 Negative PSA 5.9 05/2013 (still no symptoms) Biopsy 6/2013 3+4 (thank goodness for PSA tests) 1 core positive (upper left), 1 suspicious (lower left) out of 12 DRE: bump right side T1c; PCA-III = 20 (normal) Da Vinci 7/18/2013: Invasive carcinoma involves left lobe of prostate only, extends from left apex to posterior mid region of left lobe Gleason 7/10 (4+3); G4 tumor comprises 75% of invasive carcinoma present Estimated total volume of carcinoma in entire prostate gland: 10% TNM: T2b NX MX (Stage IIA) 8/25/13 11/4/13 2/11/14 8/1/14 2/15/15 8/20/15 3/1/16, 8/30/16, 3/25/17,9/25/17,4/14/18: PSA undetectable My Story: [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32491-T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci..."]T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci...[/URL] [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32693-Catheter-is-Out!?highlight=ddayglo"] Catheter is Out![/URL]
Posts.Title: How Do You Feel After Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut Interesting article from Bloomberg. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html Clip from the article: Given the recent spike in infection complications after prostate biopsy, the ideal method to diagnose prostate cancer must be pondered, Matthew Gettman, professor of urology at the Mayo Graduate School of Medicine in Rochester, Minnesota, wrote in an editorial in the journal European Urology last May. Despite local anesthetics, the whole procedure is barbaric, and it is surprising that the issue of infection has not come to light years ago. Knowing what I do now (hindsight is always 20-20), knowing that... Biopsies do have a risk, such as infections You can't have an infinite number of biopsies without issues such as scarring Biopsies can miss PCa Biopsies may catch PCa but miss the higher Gleason Grade Until an MRI is found to be as accurate or more accurate than a biopsy, biopsies are the "Gold Standard" and will continue to be used. Therefore, I would do my best to ensure that each biopsy has the best chance being accurate. Therefore, I'm wondering if one should always have an MRI Guided/Targeted biopsy instead of a "blind", 12-core standard biopsy... For example, see this article: http://www.nwhroboticsurgery.org/def...lay/news_id,10. (This was my surgeon, who I do recommend. He did not do my biopsies)

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glr3 Did not find a post about "What I Wish I Knew About Prostate Biopsies" before I had one. If there is one, can anyone direct me to it. If not, would anyone care to provide comments? My biopsy was painless. First one did not detect anything, the second one six months later did... It did feel weird when the needle(?) was pushed up there but since I had nerve blockers it didn't hurt at all. For some reason during my two biopsy visits the Dr had the most beautiful assistants that day... It was almost like he planned it The urine may have blood for the next week or so, the semen definitely will. The "standard" biopsy is 12 "cores". There are different types of biopsies, such as a "saturation biopsy" and a "guided biopsy", which can be used if the PSA level continues to rise to hopefully detect if there's cancer cells... I believe these "special" biopsies are usually used for people on AS or where the PSA continues to rise. There's also a limit to the number of biopsies one can have (3 or 4 I believe) before the scar tissue becomes an issue

Posts.Title: 4+3 vs. 3+4 GLEASON POST SURGERY ! IS THERE REALLY A HUGE DIFFERENCE ?

Posts.Content: I didn't realize you meant post-surgery. Post-surgery, I guess the important thing is whether or not the margins were clean. In a biopsy, G3+4 vs G4+3 would be important... (although those numbers can change post-surgery)

Posts.Title: 4+3 vs. 3+4 GLEASON POST SURGERY ! IS THERE REALLY A HUGE DIFFERENCE ?

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our "club". With a 12-year-old, I know how you feel about being tooo young. Regarding AS, I was asked if I wanted to have my slides read by another lab to see if it could be downgraded to a G6/ I decided against it, as in my mind I would have needed two labs both agreeing on a G6 before i would consider AS. Of course, its up-to-you. This post has some questions for a surgeon: Questions-for-Surgeon . As far as choosing one, experience is key (>400 or even >1000). Good luck!

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> With a 12 year old  I know how

I believe these "special" biopsies are usually used for people on AS or where the PSA continues to rise. There's also a limit to the number of biopsies one can have (3 or 4 I believe) before the scar tissue becomes an issue

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut Interesting article from Bloomberg. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html Clip from the article: Given the recent spike in infection complications after prostate biopsy, the ideal method to diagnose prostate cancer must be pondered, Matthew Gettman, professor of urology at the Mayo Graduate School of Medicine in Rochester, Minnesota, wrote in an editorial in the journal European Urology last May. Despite local anesthetics, the whole procedure is barbaric, and it is surprising that the issue of infection has not come to light years ago. Knowing what I do now (hindsight is always 20-20), knowing that... Biopsies do have a risk, such as infections You can't have an infinite number of biopsies without issues such as scarring Biopsies can miss PCa Biopsies may catch PCa but miss the higher Gleason Grade Until an MRI is found to be as accurate or more accurate than a biopsy, biopsies are the "Gold Standard" and will continue to be used. Therefore, I would do my best to ensure that each biopsy has the best chance being accurate. Therefore, I'm wondering if one should always have an MRI Guided/Targeted biopsy instead of a "blind", 12-core standard biopsy... For example, see this article: http://www.nwhroboticsurgery.org/def...lay/news_id,10. (This was my surgeon, who I do recommend. He did not do my biopsies)

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glr3 Did not find a post about "What I Wish I Knew About Prostate Biopsies" before I had one. If there is one, can anyone direct me to it. If not, would anyone care to provide comments? My biopsy was painless. First one did not detect anything, the second one six months later did... It did feel weird when the needle(?) was pushed up there but since I had nerve blockers it didn't hurt at all. For some reason during my two biopsy visits the Dr had the most beautiful assistants that day... It was almost like he planned it The urine may have blood for the next week or so, the semen definitely will. The "standard" biopsy is 12 "cores". There are different types of biopsies, such as a "saturation biopsy" and a "guided biopsy", which can be used if the PSA level continues to rise to hopefully detect if there's cancer cells... I believe these "special" biopsies are usually used for people on AS or where the PSA continues to rise. There's also a limit to the number of biopsies one can have (3 or 4 I believe) before the scar tissue becomes an issue

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Get your vitamin D tested - having a low level of vitamin-D is a "marker" for aggressive PCa. Also, instead of a "blind" 12-core biopsy, consider having an state-of-the-art MRI, or an MRI-guided biopsy (which I believe would give a better chance of the biopsy "zeroing in" on any suspicious areas. You may, if it doesn't freak you out, buy Dr Walsh's book and research treatment options immediately instead of waiting until the biopsy results. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: I'm back, and freakout time again

Posts.Content: What is a "multi-core biopsy"? Is that like a saturation biopsy where 20+ cores are taken? Also, ask about a MRI-guided/targeted biopsy - I believe with a targeted biopsy, more samples will be taken from "suspicious" areas. Since repeated biopsies (I believe more than 3 or 4) can cause issues if you need have your "friend" removed, you need to make sure each biopsy counts! You may also consider going to a "center of excellence" and consult with surgeons who are experienced with large prostates. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Guidance - probability of prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Get your vitamin D tested - having a low level of vitamin-D is a "marker" for aggressive PCa. Also, instead of a "blind" 12-core biopsy, consider having an state-of-the-art MRI, or an MRI-guided biopsy (which I believe would give a better chance of the biopsy "zeroing in" on any suspicious areas. You may, if it doesn't freak you out, buy Dr Walsh's book and research treatment options immediately instead of waiting until the biopsy results. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Must decide between surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut Interesting article from Bloomberg. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html Clip from the article: Given the recent spike in infection complications after prostate biopsy, the ideal method to diagnose prostate cancer must be pondered, Matthew Gettman, professor of urology at the Mayo Graduate School of Medicine in Rochester, Minnesota, wrote in an editorial in the journal European Urology last May. Despite local anesthetics, the whole procedure is barbaric, and it is surprising that the issue of infection has not come to light years ago. Knowing what I do now (hindsight is always 20-20), knowing that... Biopsies do have a risk, such as infections You can't have an infinite number of biopsies without issues such as scarring Biopsies can miss PCa Biopsies may catch PCa but miss the higher Gleason Grade Until an MRI is found to be as accurate or more accurate than a biopsy, biopsies are the "Gold Standard" and will continue to be used. Therefore, I would do my best to ensure that each biopsy has the best chance being accurate. Therefore, I'm wondering if one should always have an MRI Guided/Targeted biopsy instead of a "blind", 12-core standard biopsy... For example, see this article: http://www.nwhroboticsurgery.org/def...lay/news_id,10. (This was my surgeon, who I do recommend. He did not do my biopsies)

Posts.Title: Prostate muscle sparing??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I believe this muscle is not in the prostate, but is located in the bladder neck, which is usually cut out during prostate removal. This is called the internal sphincter. From what I've read, there is a new technique being developed in which the surgeon can sometimes leave the bladder neck intact and, thus, spare this internal sphincter. I'm willing to bet that experienced surgeons who "brag" about their patients being "completely dry" (ie no pads at all) within 3 months are sparing that second muscle. When I asked my surgeon about the "Rocco Stitch", he sort of smirked and said that he uses a variation which is "better" and bragged that his patients have been 100% dry within 3 months and he's not going to let me break his "perfect record", and that's he's submitted his results for publication.... No complains from me on this... If I achieve the "prostate trifecta" he can put a picture of my smiling face up in his office and web site for all I care...

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About About Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Now What? This is to the ladies or the male partners among us. Most of what I read here is about the physical healing of the men who underwent the prostatectomy. II absolutely love the support I have found here but I would love to hear about the emotional effects on their partners, either in the forum here or through private messages. I have been strong ever since he was diagnosed last year, all the way through the surgery last month and up until now at 3 weeks post-op. He is amazingly strong and seems to be healing well. We love each other very much and have a very good marriage (34 + years or so) But today for the very first time I broke down when I it hit me that the physical love life we had before the surgery, is now gone. But we are still happy with each other and sometimes it is fun as well. I cannot talk to my friends or family members (adult kids in particular!!) about this emotional aspect so that's why I put this out here. All my best to all of you. The physical love is not gone permanently. Viagra and other ED meds may help, or an injectable like caverject or trimex. <warning- "R" rated> I can get about "60% there" on my own, and use caverject to reach 100%... and I'm only limited by my endurance or when my wife has to beg me to stop.. LOL <end "R" rating>

Posts.Title: How long before no blood in C bag?

Posts.Content: A course of antibiotics and another PSA test sounds reasonable. After my PSA rose and the first biopsy was negative, I was diagnosed with something similar but at least my first urologist requested a followup PSA after six months. Knowing what I do now, I would have asked for antibiotics and a PSA retest after two months or so... Your doing a good job staying on top of things -- keep it up!

Posts.Title: My PSA Is 5.9 After One Year

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Now What? This is to the ladies or the male partners among us. Most of what I read here is about the physical healing of the men who underwent the prostatectomy. II absolutely love the support I have found here but I would love to hear about the emotional effects on their partners, either in the forum here or through private messages. I have been strong ever since he was diagnosed last year, all the way through the surgery last month and up until now at 3 weeks post-op. He is amazingly strong and seems to be healing well. We love each other very much and have a very good marriage (34 + years or so) But today for the very first time I broke down when I it hit me that the physical love life we had before the surgery, is now gone. But we are still happy with each other and sometimes it is fun as well. I cannot talk to my friends or family members (adult kids in particular!!) about this emotional aspect so that's why I put this out here. All my best to all of you. The physical love is not gone permanently. Viagra and other ED meds may help, or an injectable like caverject or trimex. <warning- "R" rated> I can get about "60% there" on my own, and use caverject to reach 100%... and I'm only limited by my endurance or when my wife has to beg me to stop.. LOL <end "R" rating>

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Thanks for the support guys, really appreciated. Every time I get an "undectable" outcome I tell myself I'm not going to worry about the next one. Unfortunately 2 weeks before the blood draw I revert to sweating bullets. Somehow and for no specific reason I feel if/when I go on HT my days are numbered. Allen How often does your Dr recommend having your PSA tested? Would increasing the frequency help? I know every situation is different, but I even though I was told by my surgeon to have it checked annually, I decided on every six months. It made a huge difference knowing that I was having it checked twice as often as "required".

Posts.Title: Stress is over for another 6 months

Posts.Content: At age 57, many Drs and people here would recommend surgery.... if additional treatment is needed, it's "easier" to have "salvage" radiation after surgery than the other way around. I would suggest scheduling the surgery (there needs to be about six weeks after a biopsy before surgery). Then research radiation. That way, if you decide on surgery, your spot is already "reserved" and you don't have to ever second-guess waiting for a spot to open. If you decide to have other treatment, you can simply cancel the surgery. Someone here recommended this page: http://www.pcf.org/site/c.leJRIROrEp...ons_to_Ask.htm. The stickies also have some information and links to questions to ask, and you may wish to tape your conversations as well. Good luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> At age 57  many Drs and people here

Posts.Content: There is a lot of posts concerning pre-treatment options such as seeds vs surgery. This is EXTREMELY useful for those who have not yet decided.... However, IMO, posts and arguments in favor of surgery is counterproductive for those who have ALREADY had seed inplants (or have decided on seeds). Likewise, posts and arguments in favor of seeds is counterproductive for those who have ALREADY had surgery (or have decided on surgery). I'm requesting that the seeds-vs-surgery debate not occur within threads unless it is clear that the person is requesting that kind of information.... Thanks in advance.

Update: Until I looked it up, I didn't realize it was for ED. I've read of other posters who regularly inject it into the penis. I'm glad they were able to. Me, I've got to be the biggest wuss on the planet because I have chills just thinking about a needle going into a pecker. Couldn't do it. Wish the best for you. Jim There's a version of MUSE which isn't injectable, you may wish to check it out. For me, I tried Viagra and friends and it didn't work well enough to offset the headaches. The two things I remember about being a teenager was peeing like a racehorse (which I do now), and having a woodie so hard I could hang wet towels on it....

I'm nearly convinced I need the davinci with Dr. Esposito of Hackensack but I saw this commercial on TV about the cyber knife. What are your thoughts on this? Since you are "nearly convinced" about robotic -- schedule it -- while researching the other treatments. If you decide to switch to another type of treatment, you just have to cancel the robotic. But if you decide to stick with surgery, your spot will be "reserved" and there won't be any delay in getting treatment. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Wondering about Cyber Knife

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ray61 Doc wants to try me on trimix. Anyone have any experience? Thanks Ray I just had an appointment with my uro, this is hot-off-the-presses... .... There are two types of Muse, one is injectable, called "Caverject" and the other is some sort of "pill" you insert down there. My uro strongly dissuaded me from the "pill" form - he said it, and I quote "it hurts like hell". Then it was between Caverject (the injectable Muse) and trimix for me. My uro likes trimix but you need to go to a compounding pharmacy and it was not covered by my insurance while Caverject was. Since I do have some "action" down there, we agreed that I would try the Caverject first and if that doesn't work then "graduate" to the Trimix. I just dropped off the prescription. Once I get from the pharmacy I make a short appointment and he'll show me how to inject it. I requested the prettiest nurses to be on duty that day but he wouldn't guarantee it.... Wish me luck

Posts.Title: Gleason 6 Tumor: Is It Cancer, and Should It Be Treated?

Posts.Content: * Get a state-of-the-art (T3?) MRI and a CT scan - if there's any evidence of spreading then surgery is probably not the best option * Ask your Dr about a hormone shot to slow the G9 down (actually stop it altogether from growing) as you decide on your course of treatment. * Assuming the scans are negative, schedule the surgery ASAP for the earliest possible moment (probably 4 or 5 weeks after the biopsy). Then research radiation (and salvage radiation as well). If your surrgeon recommends radiation, then you cancel the surgery. If not, then you've already scheduled the surgery for the earliest possible time. Good luck

But the most important thing is to find a very experienced (more than 300) surgeon, the more experienced the better. Keep in touch and hope you can leave the join the "Zero Club" soon. Good luck!

Posts.Title: PSA is Coming Down

Posts.Content: At age 57, many Drs and people here would recommend surgery.... if additional treatment is needed, it's "easier" to have "salvage" radiation after surgery than the other way around. I would suggest scheduling the surgery (there needs to be about six weeks after a biopsy before surgery). Then research radiation. That way, if you decide on surgery, your spot is already "reserved" and you don't have to ever second-guess waiting for a spot to open. If you decide to have other treatment, you can simply cancel the surgery. Someone here recommended this page: http://www.pcf.org/site/c.leJRIROrEp...ons_to_Ask.htm. The stickies also have some information and links to questions to ask, and you may wish to tape your conversations as well. Good luck

Posts.Title: At Johns Hopkins Tomorrow

Posts.Content: While we were waiting for the results of my Caverject (which I wrote about in another thread), I asked my surgeon his take on about second opinions for biopsy results. He said that before he puts anyone on AS, he insists on an T3 MRI as well as a second reading on the biopsy. But, he does not see the point of a second opinion if any G4 was seen as he would not recommend AS for anyone who had a reading with a G4 or higher. Just his opinion.... He also mentioned that his last two patients had cyberknife and unfortunately he's seeing more and more unsuccessful cyberknife patients. He thinks it will be between 5 and 10 years from now when the nextgen MRI machines will have enough accuracy to ensure that all there aren't any missed areas, that that will be the real game-changer. Again, just his opinion....

Posts.Title: Who do you tell? and why tell them?

Posts.Content: I really can't add much more than the already excellent responses listed above, but here is my two cents anyway... No one will suggest surgery now (and insurance will not cover it). If you have low-risk PC (G6, 1 core, etc), then there's a "tipping point", or "trigger", for one to switch from AS to treatment. Everyone's trigger is different. There is no right or wrong. For some, the trigger is already met and it's "I don't care if it's G6, lets get rid of the cancer before it spreads". For others, it's higher, like rising PSA or a second biopsy result. In some ways you could consider yourself on AS right now. Follow the "AS Diet" as listed in the stickies. As you seem to have a low "trigger" (again, not judging you at all), you may wish to consider increasing the frequency of your PSA tests from every six months to every three or four months. There are also some other kinds of tests (PCA-III, etc) listed on this board which may help as well. Also, there are types of biopsies (saturation biopsy, Guided (MRI?) biopsies, etc, which should have a better chance of finding out if actually have PC. I've read here that having too many biopsies can cause scar tissue which could make treatment more complicated. So you want to be sure each biopsy is as sophisticated as possible and gives you the best chance of finding (or hopefully not finding) and PC. Good Luck, and we hope you never have to join our "club".

Posts.Title: Why choose active surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fxoptions I received my result the other day and my Dr told me the following 12/15 samples positive - Gleason 7= 3+4 positive in following Samples: right base 70%, right lateral base 15%,right mid 85%, right lateral mid 100%, right apex 50%, right lateral apex 15%, left lateral base 35%, left mid 5%, left apex 40%, apical nodule 40% Multiple cores (3) PNI (Perineural Invasion present) in 4 cores. my age is 55 Before Biopsy CT showed nodule on apex of prostate (this is why I went to urologist) DRE positive PSA 2.5 was 1.5 10 months ago I will going back to DR soon, I guess he may suggest surgery, what I am concerned about is the PNI in four cores and the nodule. I have read this may show aggression, I will be sending my slide to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion soon, any advise on surgery that may help , open vs robotic? Looks like basically the whole prostate has cancer, 12out of 15, does this also determine treatment options ? Any reply or experience is helpful. I would do it in this order: 1. Find a good experienced (400+) surgeon and schedule the surgery. At your age, unless you have an underlying medical condition, robotic sounds best. 2. After you've scheduled the surgery (about six weeks after the biopsy), then research radiation alternatives. You can always cancel the surgery if you decide to go with radiation. And if you decide to go with surgery, you'll have the first available time "reserved" and you will never have to second guess yourself about waiting...

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results in, now what?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 Now have 5/13 cores positive with 4 7's and one 8. IMO, In the unlikely event that every core was downgraded to G6, you still need treatment. And with a G8, you should not wait too long to decide on the treatment type. I think you should choose a good, very experienced surgeon and set a date. You need to wait 6-8 weeks after a biopsy anyway for surgery. Then research radiation specialists. If you decide to choose radiation, you can just cancel the surgery. If you decide on surgery, then it's already "reserved" for the earliest date possible (especially in light of several G7s and a G8 ). Good Luck

Posts.Title: T-Minus 36 Hours until da Vinci...

Posts.Content: I wonder how much less that 20-28% rate is for a 24-core biopsy? Or even a 40-80 core "saturation biopsy"? Also, are there any side effects or risks of such a biopsy above and beyond a "regular" biopsy? Edit: here is one article: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2845744/ Based on this article, I wonder why the urologist did not recommend a 20-core for my repeat biopsy. Also, IF I was a candidate for AS (which unfortunately I was not), and was leaning towards it, from what I know now I would feel that a standard 12-core biopsy wouldn't be enough for me. I think I would personally only consider it if had a 'saturation biopsy" first to be sure any Gleason 7's wasn't hiding somewhere...

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: My Gleason score also changed (from a 3+4 to a 4+3) as well as amount... Are there any studies which compare biopsy reports with surgical pathology reports... what percentage of surgical reports basically downgraded the biopsy results; which "matched", and what percentage of the biopsy results "underestimated" the Score and amount? (I assume broken down by Gleason score and risk level, ie Gleason 3+3, 3+4, etc)? If I had a Gleason 3+3 (wishful thinking), but was told that (for example) that 40% of the time the biopsy "underreports" or "underestimates" the actual score, I may act differently regarding AS than if the biopsy "underreports" the actual score by 10%.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: Here's a reluctant welcome to our club. With all G6's, some would argue that you could consider Active Surveillance (AS). Other may suggest seeds or other treatments. But at your age, I believe most doctors would lean towards surgery. Also, you seem to have an excellent, experienced, caring surgeon. with your stats, there isn't a huge rush to have the surgery and I believe waiting a few extra weeks to decide wouldn't make a difference one way or another. If I were you, I would schedule the surgery and research other options since you can always cancel the surgery if you decide on AS or another treatment. But if you decide to go through with the surgery, your "spot" is already reserved... Take a deep breath, read the stickies, start your kegels now, get the viagra/cialis pills immediately (some insurance plans limit the number of six a month so you can "hoard" a few now). Have as much sex as possible right now. We have a ticket with your name on it already filled out for membership in the "zero" club. Good luck!

I would love to be a fly on the wall as you explain to the wife-unit that some stranger on the Internet named "ddayglo" insists that you MUST have as much sex as possible RIGHT NOW. Posts.Title: Well Crap!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mrs. GG Okay, another question that is on my mind. I know bruising and swelling is to be expected after RALP around the testicles and penis. My husband doesn't have that (he is one week post surgery) but he is massively black and blue from his hip bone to his rib cage on his right side. Just the right side and it is wicked. Every color of the rainbow and it looks like he's been beaten with a baseball bat. We are wondering if this was from the straps from the operating table (but just on one side?) or perhaps the doctor took more tissue sample from this side causing more internal bleeding?? We're stumped and will ask the doc about it tomorrow during catheter removal. I haven't noticed any other comments about torso bruising. Anybody else have this? GG I don't remember bruising, but my shoulders and right side were very stiff and sore as well as my mouth. I assume it was from the position you are in for the DaVinci and some sort of breathing assist thingy. Asking your Dr makes sense.

Posts.Title: Question about PSA Level

Posts.Content: Sorry you have you as a new member of our club. I assume you are having DaVinci... I was back at work after about three weeks although I have a desk job. You actually don't feel bad after a few weeks but you can't lift anything heavy for at least six as the stitches are still healing from the inside. Read the DaVinci Sticky on the top of the forum, they contain many links to first-hand experiences of those of us in the club. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Hi Guys

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH A 7 week post-op PSA of 0.0 cannot be any better. He probably wants to measure your PSA as the future unfolds and then trigger radiation treatments only if the PSA begins to rise. I suppose it can be done either way -- start adjunct radiation now or be prepared for salvage radiation in the future. The main reason is to spare you from any of the ravages of radiation if it is not really needed. A PSA of 0 sounds like a great start. What testing schedule has your Dr recommended? Every six weeks for the first six months? Every three months? Also - Welcome to the Zero-Club and hope we can change your membership card from pencil to indelible marker.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon LOL, the pain is no where near severe enough to warrant anesthetic. I would estimate the needle they give you hurts more than the biopsy. Put plugs in your ears and you won't even hear the noise, and that's the worse part. Allen Yes, the needle did hurt more (although it was more like the pain of the needle at the dentist, just in a strange place). But some people insist on getting the "happy gas" at the dentist, so if getting knocked out for a biopsy is needed, then by all means do it.

Posts.Title: biopsy

Posts.Content: I wonder how much less that 20-28% rate is for a 24-core biopsy? Or even a 40-80 core "saturation biopsy"? Also, are there any side effects or risks of such a biopsy above and beyond a "regular" biopsy? Edit: here is one article: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2845744/ Based on this article, I wonder why the urologist did not recommend a 20-core for my repeat biopsy. Also, IF I was a candidate for AS (which unfortunately I was not), and was leaning towards it, from what I know now I would feel that a standard 12-core biopsy wouldn't be enough for me. I think I would personally only consider it if had a 'saturation biopsy" first to be sure any Gleason 7's wasn't hiding somewhere...

Posts.Title: Another newbie...decided on surgery

Posts.Content: Are you "wired" for AS? Would knowing that you have at least some G6, with possible more that was missed (about 20% in some cases), bother you? If not, then perhaps go on AS with a low "trigger" for active treatment... for example, bi-monthly PSA testing with other tests listed in the AS Sticky... And plan on another biopsy (MRI-guided) in one year... If anything changes in the slightest (with either the PSA score, the biopsy results, or urinary issues), then schedule your surgery. Otherwise revisit in one year.

Posts.Content: Two questions which your Urologist (or someone here) may help answer and may affect your decision: 1. Does SBRT, seeds, or any other kind of radiation help (or hinder) urinating? 2. Say you are 100% cured of your PC due to some sort of radiation. How would that affect your options for future urinary treatment (for example, a TURP)?

Posts.Content: Get a second opinion on the G6 to be sure it's a "solid 6". Read the sticky thread on "AS". Follow the diet listed in the sticky. Take a "PCA-3" test and/or tests listed here Retest PSA in 3 or so months. If it goes up, have another biopsy (either a targeted biopsy or a "saturation" biopsy). Many of us did not have the choice of AS and wish we did. Good Luck. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Welcome me to the club!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde Hi Gary, I was diagnosed with G7 in october and was in shock of course. The advice you are given here are excellent and given by guys who are experienced so you are in the right place. The two things that stuck in me which helped a lot was: 1. You are not in a hurry, you have the time to make an informed decision, but with G7 you need to make a decision 2. Talk to an urologist AND an oncologist and if you do not have confidence in them find another. You need input from both sides. Good luck Not to be an alarmist, but with a G3+4 involving at 95%, and another G4+3 on the other side, in my opinion you should start treatment as soon as possible (which if you decide on surgery is about 6 weeks after the biopsy). If I were you, I'd schedule the surgery with an EXPERIENCED surgeon, and then explore other options. You can always cancel the surgery if you decide on something else. And if you decide to go through with the surgery you'll have not had any delay in treatment. I'm also not quite sure what the benefit of a second opinion on the slides would be in this case... You already know you need treatment..... I assume the Drs will be asking you to have scans run to ensure that everything is localized to your prostate, which by every indication seems to be (cross fingers). Good luck!

I told my GP that and he snickered and said that he never heard that before, I adamantly told him it is written..as such a side effect... Tell me what you think. It may just take time... Cialis and Viagra didn't work for me. I'm very slowly improving (sometimes I'm waking up at night with some nice feeling down there. Not "hang wet towels" hard but at least something) so the Dr is happy. On my next visit I will ask for Trimix. Check out this thread: What-I-Need-to-Know-About-ED Chuck - Perhaps it's time to add back the ED sticky? Or set up a master "What I wish or need to know about" sticky and put all of the "demoted" stickies (and other useful threads) into it for easy reference?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JoeInBucks Kozmic sounds like you are only doing cardio type exercises. I agree that that type of work out can be extreamly boring. Try some resistance training instead or mix it in. The advantage of resistance training is that as you increase muscle mass your resting metabolic rate increases. If partook your goal is to keep your heart rate up don't rest between sets, just alternate between two different exercises. I keep reading good things about circuit training (where you don't use heavy weights, move from exercise to exercise with zero or minimal rest). It is supposed to raise your heard rate and as much as cardio with the added benefit of exercises all of the muscles in your body. About the kegels: I found doing them every other day worked best. Give that weak lil' muscle down there time to recover and build up it's strength. After RP you'll be depending on that muscle a lot more than you used to, so treat it with some TLC

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: Based on the G9, I'm wondering if the Doctor could be thinking conservatively and with an "abundance of caution", and may recommend radiation prophylacticly to make sure all of it is gone. Not to scare you further (if that is possible), but wouldn't it be better to kill one or two cells of G9 lurking in the area surrounding the prostate rather than waiting until it spreads and then shows up on a PSA test? A google of "G9, radiation post ddr" does show that some Doctors seem to recommend radiation even for "G9, PSA 0". Get a second opinion, and good luck.

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: Agree with everyone. If you are forced to use physical force on a prisoner charges at you, you don't want to be put in the position of hesitating or second guessing yourself. Perhaps after 10-12 weeks meet one of your partners and go through some potential physical scenarios, starting easy at first, and then wait until the next day and see how you feel... (with Dr approval of course...). Sort of build yourself up over several weeks so you are both mentally and physically ready... ?

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves Husband, 61 years ~ Biopsy gleeson 7 & 8 right side only . Left side was clear . No symptoms this was caught on routine physical .. Just had Divinci last week now got results today from that upgraded to Gleeson 9 It was contained to prostate lymph glands clear, surgeon said everything was clear and free on edges . Bone scan ..negative Wondering if we dodged a bullet or 2 My question is do you all think we are out of the clear or should I still be worried . Have followed this since he was diagnosed and this seems not to be very good to have a score such as a 9 . We have a appt for cath removal next monday and will have a sit down with him then but I have gone from complete excitment that it was all gone to air sucking omg when he said it was up graded to a 9 ....thoughts We all hope you dodged a bullet! You know the saying, "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst".... If I were in your shoes, I would discuss with the doctor that you want to be as aggressive as possible with post-op PSA testing, scans, etc (every six weeks?) for as-early-as-possible detection of anything which may need further treatment. Also, have a complete plan already in place just in case your husband's PSA doesn't drop to zero (radiation?) . Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Help me wait for diagnosis. Biopsy today.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gunrun Psa 6.9 free Fpsa 11% Biopsy results yesterday from 12 cores? 1 core positive 1% Gleason 7 Sent to secondary pathologist for opinion. Going into Dr office today for consult. I'm 46 with 4 young kids so I have to treat this aggressively. Dr said it's possible he might Of missed other tumors or the tumor he found possibly just nicked it and could be more Than 1%. I will try and copy my pathologist report today. Anyone from Missouri know a good Dr for surgery? Agree, at your age with four young kids you should seek treatment. Most of us would recommend DaVinci rather than open surgery. I would suggest finding a good surgeon (400+ surgeries, perhaps at a major teaching hospital. and schedule the surgery (which will be 6-8 weeks after your biopsy). Then research radiation and other treatments (as well as undergo further tests if needed). You can always reschedule or cancel the surgery if necessary. But if you decide to go through with the surgery, your spot will be "reserved" for the earliest possible time and you will never second guess yourself about waiting an extra few weeks before having the surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news

Posts.Content: Sorry to see you join our "club". You may be a candidate for active survallence (AS). some people aren't "wired" for AS (for example, knowing that there's a chance the biopsy missed a higher grade of PCa). Others go on AS while realizing that probably will need treatment in the future but feel comfortable with active monitoring. If you decide on treatment, then given your age, most of us on this board would suggest DaVinci surgery. (But remember, there's no right or wrong answer). good luck on your journey, you're among friends who know what you are going through.

Posts.Content: Had Da Vinci July 18th, catheter removed on July 26th. Started back at work on Monday. One pad per day... Woke up this morning and notice that the "boys" as well as the entire area where the sun doesn't shine (perineum ?) is very sore. I coughed a bit this morning and I really felt it down there a few seconds... I'm hoping that this is not uncommon and just part of the healing process. Have a standard follow-up with the Surgeon in a week.... Does anyone see a reason for me to call him sooner? Thanks

Posts.Title: Help me wait for diagnosis. Biopsy today.

Posts.Content: In some ways your story is similar to mine, as my first biopsy was also negative. So, what I'm writing now is what I wish I would have done myself after my first biopsy was negative... (I hope this doesn't sound too negative so soon after you received good news)... I wish I would have considered myself on Active Surveillance (AS), as there's a chance that the standard 12-core biopsy missed my PCa. I wish I had done better with my diet, exercise, etc (for example, read the AS sticky) I wish I had asked my Doctor about having the followup PSA test after three or four months instead of six After my PCa continued to rise, and was told that I needed another biopsy, I wish I had pushed for a more aggressive biopsy (such as a guided biopsy) instead of a standard one to be sure that nothing was missed the second time... During the six months, I wish I had researched PCa and purchased Dr Walsh's book, and really learned about every treatment method, learning about each surgeon and treatment center, instead of waiting until after the second biopsy was positive, and then getting overwhelmed. "Hope for the best, but prepare for the worst" Hope this isn't a "downer"... one last thing... After my first biopsy was negative, I wished that I had told my wife that the Dr said that I must have as much sex as possible as it exercises the prostate and the muscles around the prostate. I mean, I just came from the Dr, so she maybe she would have believed it!

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: When I was at home, I used some of the old-fashioned cotton cloth diapers. I would fold it in quarters and just shove it down the front of my pants and change them a couple of times a night. If I knew I was sitting for a while I would also use it when I was out of the house between regular pads. They were a welcome relief from the store pads. Also try a bit of baby powder in the day pads, that also helped by keeping things dry down there.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Now What? I am his wife and he also has these questions and needs answers but doesn't ask, so that's why I am here.). It is two weeks post robotic surgery. Wounds are healing well, he needs to go to the bathroom twice at night and pees quite a bit from what I can hear. Leaking at night is minimal. My question is about rehabbing the penis for erections. We do get a careful, hesitant response so that is hopeful. How often do we need to practice rehab (masturbation) in order to maintain progress? At this time it is just rehab, not desire. He is not taking any Cialis or Viagra. Hubby is upbeat and beside all this basically back to his old self. Thanks for your support. There's still a month or so of healing, so one needs to be very careful notto do any pulling or stretching... One thing I would add is to "stock up" on the cialis and viagra now each month, in case his friend gets "stuck" at 50% or 70% firmness and needs a bit extra push...

Posts.Title: PSA that increased

Posts.Content: Some of us aren't "wired" for AS with the thought of active cancer living --and possibly growing -- like a parasite inside. I was wired for AS, but the decision was taken out of my hands as I had G4. Even though it was a single core with G3+4, it put me out of the standard (and my) threshold for AS. One Dr suggested I have a second opinion in case it was downgraded to a G3+3. I decided against it, as in my mind someone saw something which rated as a G4. For me to go on AS, I would have needed two different doctors both rating my core as a G3+3. Turns out after surgery I was a G4+3 and my surgeon and GP use me as a textbook case to seek active treatment if there's anything beyond a G3 living in a prostate. IF you decide to go on AS, then I suggest you get every test you can which are listed in the AS sticky and have a strict "threshold" to get off AS and seek active treatment (most of us would argue that you are already past that threshold). Have a mri-guided saturation biopsy to be 100% sure nothing is "hiding" in there. Have your PSA tested every three months. And have a plan in place for the day when you may have to seek active treatment. Decide on your treatment plan NOW (for example, have a surgeon already chosen). Good luck

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: In some ways your story is similar to mine, as my first biopsy was also negative. So, what I'm writing now is what I wish I would have done myself after my first biopsy was negative... (I hope this doesn't sound too negative so soon after you received good news)... I wish I would have considered myself on Active Surveillance (AS), as there's a chance that the standard 12-core biopsy missed my PCa. I wish I had done better with my diet, exercise, etc (for example, read the AS sticky) I wish I had asked my Doctor about having the followup PSA test after three or four months instead of six After my PCa continued to rise, and was told that I needed another biopsy, I wish I had pushed for a more aggressive biopsy (such as a guided biopsy) instead of a standard one to be sure that nothing was missed the second time... During the six months, I wish I had researched PCa and purchased Dr Walsh's book, and really learned about every treatment method, learning about each surgeon and treatment center, instead of waiting until after the second biopsy was positive, and then getting overwhelmed. "Hope for the best, but prepare for the worst" Hope this isn't a "downer"... one last thing... After my first biopsy was negative, I wished that I had told my wife that the Dr said that I must have as much sex as possible as it exercises the prostate and the muscles around the prostate. I mean, I just came from the Dr, so she maybe she would have believed it!

Posts.Title: Help me wait for diagnosis. Biopsy today.

Posts.Content: Agree with most posters - unless the treatment will change if one or more cores was upgraded to G7 or G8, then having a second opinion is optional since you need treatment. As you are deciding on surgery vs radiation, then I suggest doing it in this order: 1) find a good, experienced surgeon with 400+ surgeries. 2)immediately book the surgery (which will be about 6-8 weeks after the biopsy). 3) then research radiation treatment. If you decide to change to radiation, all you have to do is cancel the surgery. If you decide on surgery, then your spot is already "reserved" at the earliest possible time and you will never have to second guess yourself about having to wait to have the surgery (for example, if the second opinion or pathology find G7 or higher). Good Luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon I echo jim215's post. Better suited to a psychological or depression site. B To me, the ultimate ED is being six feet under. I wanted to get rid of whatever shouldn't be in my body and be around to spoil my 12-year-old's kids. Posts.Title: Why Men and Couples Suffer Alone

Posts.Content: Some of us aren't "wired" for AS with the thought of active cancer living --and possibly growing -- like a parasite inside. I was wired for AS, but the decision was taken out of my hands as I had G4. Even though it was a single core with G3+4, it put me out of the standard (and my) threshold for AS. One Dr suggested I have a second opinion in case it was downgraded to a G3+3. I decided against it, as in my mind someone saw something which rated as a G4. For me to go on AS, I would have needed two different doctors both rating my core as a G3+3. Turns out after surgery I was a G4+3 and my surgeon and GP use me as a textbook case to seek active treatment if there's anything beyond a G3 living in a prostate. IF you decide to go on AS, then I suggest you get every test you can which are listed in the AS sticky and have a strict "threshold" to get off AS and seek active treatment (most of us would argue that you are already past that threshold). Have a mri-guided saturation biopsy to be 100% sure nothing is "hiding" in there. Have your PSA tested every three months. And have a plan in place for the day when you may have to seek active treatment. Decide on your treatment plan NOW (for example, have a surgeon already chosen). Good luck

Posts.Title: Will 40mg of prednisone raise your PSA number

Posts.Content: Agree with most posters - unless the treatment will change if one or more cores was upgraded to G7 or G8, then having a second opinion is optional since you need treatment. As you are deciding on surgery vs radiation, then I suggest doing it in this order: 1) find a good, experienced surgeon with 400+ surgeries. 2)immediately book the surgery (which will be about 6-8 weeks after the biopsy). 3) then research radiation treatment. If you decide to change to radiation, all you have to do is cancel the surgery. If you decide on surgery, then your spot is already "reserved" at the earliest possible time and you will never have to second guess yourself about having to wait to have the surgery (for example, if the second opinion or pathology find G7 or higher). Good Luck

Posts.Title: What supplies to get after removing catheter?

Posts.Content: A sad welcome to our "club". While AS certainly seems like an option, Chuck's question about the your kidney situation is spot-on. IMO you need to go through the "what-if" scenarios. (I don't know much about kidney treatment and a possible transplant, so please excuse me if I'm off-base). For example: If your husband's number is called and he has the transplant, would that change his PCa treatment options? If your husband's number is called in the middle or radiation or seed therapy, can he still have the transplant? Regarding surgery, I believe my Dr said that I needed to check with him for three months if any other medical condition came up. How soon after the surgery would he be able to have a transplant? Good luck!

Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: Going back to what Otago said... If I were in your shoes (err had your prostate), and were considering AS, I would consider this course of action: - having slides read again to make sure there is agreement that it's a 6 - discussing with your Dr having a "saturation" biopsy in 3 (or 4) months or so. If the saturation biopsy is still a 6, then in my eyes there would be a strong case for AS.... Regarding Testosterone... Your Dr mentioned that after 6 months of radiation, it's possible that you could go back on it. Is the six months true for other forms of treatment such as surgery? Would one type of treatment would give you a "better" changes of resuming the Testosterone over another? Is that something for you to consider? Again, none of us are medical professionals, and by now you can see that everyone has their own very strong opinions... But we all have been down this road, and wish you the best.

Posts.Content: Going back to what Otago said... If I were in your shoes (err had your prostate), and were considering AS, I would consider this course of action: - having slides read again to make sure there is agreement that it's a 6 - discussing with your Dr having a "saturation" biopsy in 3 (or 4) months or so. If the saturation biopsy is still a 6, then in my eyes there would be a strong case for AS.... Regarding Testosterone... Your Dr mentioned that after 6 months of radiation, it's possible that you could go back on it. Is the six months true for other forms of treatment such as surgery? Would one type of treatment would give you a "better" changes of resuming the Testosterone over another? Is that something for you to consider? Again, none of us are medical professionals, and by now you can see that everyone has their own very strong opinions... But we all have been down this road, and wish you the best.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Frenchy One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. With 7 out of 12 cores positive (I guess five are G6, one G4+3, and one G3+4), you should ask your Dr about having an MRI(?) to be sure it hasn't spread. I also wouldn't wait to long to make a decision.... Pick an experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery (you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy to have surgery) while also researching proton and other treatments (and make sure that treatment is covered by your insurance). If you decide on surgery, you'll have it at the earliest possible moment and never have to second guess yourself about waiting. If you decide on proton or other treatment, then you can simply cancel the surgery.

Posts.Title: I guess it's my turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH A 7 week post-op PSA of 0.0 cannot be any better. He probably wants to measure your PSA as the future unfolds and then trigger radiation treatments only if the PSA begins to rise. I suppose it can be done either way -- start adjunct radiation now or be prepared for salvage radiation in the future. The main reason is to spare you from any of the ravages of radiation if it is not really needed. A PSA of 0 sounds like a great start. What testing schedule has your Dr recommended? Every six weeks for the first six months? Every three months? Also - Welcome to the Zero-Club and hope we can change your membership card from pencil to indelible marker.

Posts.Title: I guess it's my turn

Posts.Content: Agree with most posters - unless the treatment will change if one or more cores was upgraded to G7 or G8, then having a second opinion is optional since you need treatment. As you are deciding on surgery vs radiation, then I suggest doing it in this order: 1) find a good, experienced surgeon with 400+ surgeries. 2)immediately book the surgery (which will be about 6-8 weeks after the biopsy). 3) then research radiation treatment. If you decide to change to radiation, all you have to do is cancel the surgery. If you decide on surgery, then your spot is already "reserved" at the earliest possible time and you will never have to second guess yourself about having to wait to have the surgery (for example, if the second opinion or pathology find G7 or higher). Good Luck

Posts.Title: How long off work?

Posts.Content: You are not alone here, please remember that. As hard as it sounds, please don't panic. You said that "I put myself on Cipro"... were you on it the entire month along with the anti-inflammatory? You may also wish to have a second opinion, at a "center of excellence" such as a teaching or major hospital which had a separate and highly-rated Urology Department. What part of the country do you live in? Good luck and keep in touch

Posts.Content: Don't have a standard 12-core biopsy, especially with an "enormous" biopsy. There will be an even greater chance that the biopsy would miss something... Look into a MRI-Guided biopsy. That way the biopsy would be "zero-in" on any suspicious areas found. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Why dont we all stop saying "sorry you have to join our club"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Hi My fathers PSA from last year went from 4.5 to 5.2 . He had his 12 point biopsy done and today came back positive for pc. I dont know yet his number for sure but I believe he mentioned 7. His doctor send him for bone and lymph node scan. He is 64 years young. I'm also upset because previous doctor he went to when he was 4.5 told him not to worry and didn't order any fallow up tests. He never had any symptoms. Im just worried and scared. We are in NYC and I know that are few great surgeons that you guys recommend. Any help, advice will be highly appreciated. Im 37 now and I guess I have to make an appointment and get myself check too - is that a good idea ? Sorry that your father joined our "club" and we hope you never do. Your internist should be able to take your PSA as well as perform a "DRE" annually. You'll have a good baseline at a minimum for yourself. As far as your father goes, the more stats the better - the number of "positive" cores, the percent involvement, Grade (which sounds like either a G3+4 or a G4+3), etc. But with a G7, your father needs treatment and it is probably a choice between radiation and surgery. I'm sure others will also contribute. Dr Walsh has a book called the "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" - it's a must read. NYC has some of the best Doctors in the world; the more experience the better. Good Luck and we hope your father will soon join the "Zero Club" and also hope that you'll never be a member!

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Well its a small town. Seems like word will get around regardless. If you go the route of full disclosure, you have to overcome the word "cancer", which to the uninformed means ALL cancers. You'd be surprised at how uninformed the general public is about prostate cancer. Aside from telling them that only 1 in 6 prostate cancer patients ever dies from the condition, you would do well to supply current day examples of men who are in the news... after surgery for prostate cancer and living a completely normal life. A few you might include 1. Secretary of State, John Kerry, who has to be the most busy man on the planet. He had surgery 11.5 years ago. (heck, he ran for President ... shortly AFTER... he had surgery.... what could be more demanding than running for president?) 2. Rudy Giuliani, check the dates, but it was years ago, and he is traveling all over the country. 3. Arnold Palmer, had surgery 18 years ago. 4. Former Sec. of State, Colin Powell, 11 years ago in 2003. The man is very active and busy today and was shortly after surgery. There are hundreds of examples you could pick from... sports stars, politicians, seems you can't pick up the paper without seeing someone new. You need to give these ongoing examples to impress upon the staff, that this surgery will less disruptive than something like hip replacement surgery. That the chances you'll still be alive in 10 years is about 95%. There may be local town examples. Frankly I don't personally know of anyone who has actually died from the disease in my circle of acquaintances. This surgery will be far less disruptive than heart surgery. Anyway... I'd let them know via other examples. Great advise. Being from New York, I told people I decided to go the "Joe Torre" (surgery) treatment instead of the "Rudy Guilani" (non-surgical) treatment. (Yes I know I oversimplified things but I chose people from around the area I lived).

Posts.Content: Assuming the bone scan is negative, choose an EXPERIENCED surgeon as soon as possible and make an appointment for the surgery. Surgery cannot happen until about six weeks after the biopsy. Then research radiation.... If you decide on surgery, your spot is already "reserved" and you'll never second guess yourselves for any delay. If you decide on radiation, then you can simply cancel the surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: First Few Days Home After Surgery - Do I need Someone Their Fulltime?

Posts.Content: In the US, most employment contracts state that you could get laid off for any reason, such as a "reorg" (where they can simply change the wording of the title of your position). I also believe that in the US after you can go on disability after you've used all of your sick and vacation time. Perhaps go to Human Resources first and then tell your boss. Good Luck

It may be best to discuss this with legal council to be sure you are saying the right things in your "official" email or notification. I assume you're having surgery and not seeds. with seeds, I believe you would be obligated to tell everyone just in case one of your employees was pregnant. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Telling employees at work

Posts.Content: Did the Dr also tell you to have yogurt or acidophilus along with the Antibiotic? While Antibiotics kill bacteria-based germs, it also kills some of the good stuff in your body and stomach so many Drs tell you to have a lot of foods with "active cultures" like yogurt and acidophilus. Even though you are off of the Bactrim, continue having yogurt several times a day along with something like "culturelle" which has lots of active cultures. Prednisone is a type of steroid (not the type that athletes use)... It prevents the release of substances in the body that cause inflammation. It also suppresses the immune system. I'm prescribed it when I have a nasty sinus infection... I remember peeing more often when on it, and a search on the internet shows that some people complain that prednisone will cause more frequent urination, so that may be related to what you are going through. Are you on a "medrol" pack, which means you take one less pill each day for six days? If so, a day or two after you are off the prednisone you should begin to get back to normal. Have you contacted your surgeon? Another search of "Dr Google" shows that prednisone can affect PSA level, which you'll be tested for regularly post-surgery... So your surgeon needs to know ASAP about the predisone in case he wants to move back any testing by a week or two while the prednisone gets out of your system. (to be clear, I'm not questioning the need for prednisone, it sounds like you really needed it). Also, as Chuck says, asking your pharmacist would also be a good idea. Lets hope this is your only pothole in your road to recovery. Goo luck

Posts.Title: 3-Week Post-DaVinci Update - and a Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Hi My fathers PSA from last year went from 4.5 to 5.2 . He had his 12 point biopsy done and today came back positive for pc. I dont know yet his number for sure but I believe he mentioned 7. His doctor send him for bone and lymph node scan. He is 64 years young. I'm also upset because previous doctor he went to when he was 4.5 told him not to worry and didn't order any fallow up tests. He never had any symptoms. Im just worried and scared. We are in NYC and I know that are few great surgeons that you guys recommend. Any help, advice will be highly appreciated. Im 37 now and I guess I have to make an appointment and get myself check too - is that a good idea ? Sorry that your father joined our "club" and we hope you never do. Your internist should be able to take your PSA as well as perform a "DRE" annually. You'll have a good baseline at a minimum for yourself. As far as your father goes, the more stats the better - the number of "positive" cores, the percent involvement, Grade (which sounds like either a G3+4 or a G4+3), etc. But with a G7, your father needs treatment and it is probably a choice between radiation and surgery. I'm sure others will also contribute. Dr Walsh has a book called the "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" - it's a must read. NYC has some of the best Doctors in the world; the more experience the better. Good Luck and we hope your father will soon join the "Zero Club" and also hope that you'll never be a member!

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Frenchy One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. With 7 out of 12 cores positive (I guess five are G6, one G4+3, and one G3+4), you should ask your Dr about having an MRI(?) to be sure it hasn't spread. I also wouldn't wait to long to make a decision.... Pick an experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery (you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy to have surgery) while also researching proton and other treatments (and make sure that treatment is covered by your insurance). If you decide on surgery, you'll have it at the earliest possible moment and never have to second guess yourself about waiting. If you decide on proton or other treatment, then you can simply cancel the surgery.

Posts.Content: My Gleason score also changed (from a 3+4 to a 4+3) as well as amount... Are there any studies which compare biopsy reports with surgical pathology reports... what percentage of surgical reports basically downgraded the biopsy results; which "matched", and what percentage of the biopsy results "underestimated" the Score and amount? (I assume broken down by Gleason score and risk level, ie Gleason 3+3, 3+4, etc)? If I had a Gleason 3+3 (wishful thinking), but was told that (for example) that 40% of the time the biopsy "underreports" or "underestimates" the actual score, I may act differently regarding AS than if the biopsy "underreports" the actual score by 10%.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: Interesting replies.. So, someone with a Gleason 6 (or a 3+4) should really check where the positive core(s) are located. If they are on the outer edge of the prostate, or at the Apex, that is something to consider before deciding on "active surveillance"..... And, if positive core is by the bladder neck, that could be a data point to be considered as part of the radiation-vs-surgery decision. (I hope I got this right) Would really be interesting for everyone to ask their urologist/radiologist about this...

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: In the US, most employment contracts state that you could get laid off for any reason, such as a "reorg" (where they can simply change the wording of the title of your position). I also believe that in the US after you can go on disability after you've used all of your sick and vacation time. Perhaps go to Human Resources first and then tell your boss. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PCWIFE3 Thanks everyone for your quick responses and any he warm welcome. I heard back from the nurse and she confirmed what you all said. Just have one issue. He's been great since coming home on Friday (managing pain, eating, walking, etc). Had a bit of a set back tonight. He got a sudden fever, shakes and severe pain in loser abdomin. Called the nurse again and she said this was likely a bladder spasm. Fever is gone but he's had2 more "spasms" since. They last a few minutes and pain subsides a but but doesn't go away completely. Has anyone experienced this? He did have any "spasms" up till now...is it normal to start 6 days after surgery? If the pain is that severe, then I strongly recommend a Dr visit. Otherwise sounds like he is doing OK. Read the DaVinci "sticky" as it contains first hand experience from others who also had surgery. Glad to hear it was a G6. Good luck

Posts.Title: biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SeaCock I'm almost 12 weeks post op and last week did some light ab's and never felt a thing. I have been stretching them briefly for the last three weeks getting them ready to do some work. I started light lifting when the NP said it was ok...which was 4 weeks post op. Last week I started trying to back to my normal weights...lost 10lbs waiting to get back in the gym...still no legs yet...don't want to stress anything down below until the little man wakes up a little more... Interesting... When I started lifting again (circuit training), also about 12 weeks out, my abs and the area felt "different", and were the absolute last thing to come back. It took almost a year for me to feel that I could do normal ab work. Maybe it was the scar tissue, maybe I was just a bit hesitant to put stress anything down there. I don't see the scars anymore either, but then again they are covered with my gorilla hair...

Posts.Title: Vigorous Exercise Post RP

Posts.Content: Had surgery in Northern Westchester Hospital (NY State) on July 28th... Came back today to have my what my son calls my "Borg Implant" removed. The nurse came in and asked me for a urine sample. I said, "Nyuk Nyuk, Nyuk, this will be easiest urine sample in the world, just hold the cup to my thigh". She then realized I had the catheter and said "hmmm, maybe we should wait for the Doctor". The Doctor came in and removed the staples and stitches, no big deal. Then he started to pull out the catheter. I'll use that famous pain scale on 1 to 10 with a slight modification.. 1 = no pain and 10 = It fells like you are pissing out a bowling ball covered with thumb tacks and razor wire It was a two and sometimes a three for about 5 seconds. It jumped to a four for one second. The Dr said that was the catheter passing the anal sphincter. Another five seconds of a two or three. Then I hit a four for about two seconds and it was out! It was actually less pain than when the drainage tube was pulled from my stomach. It was probably less time than what I have above, that's just what it felt like... When I stood up, I immediately pee'd all over the floor (it was kinda nice seeing the pee leaving my actual pee-hole). The Doctor caught enough for his purposes. I told him I wish I had time to aim at him as revenge for what he put me through (don't forget the catheter was already out...) I put on a depends and an extra pad in there. The Dr recommended buying some "tightie whities" underwear for the pad. He also said not to do the Kagel exercises for a few days and then I can start. We all dread "the pulling out of the catheter" but after everything else we've gone through it really wasn't that horrible.

Posts.Title: Catheter is Out!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Now, while this looks to be a strong testament for AS, it has to be noted that all of the men involved were classified as low risk at the time they made their decisions. So, it is perhaps more useful as a caution against choosing possible over-treatment, when AS is being suggested as an option by your physician(s). Actually, all men involved were classified as low-risk AND between 66 and 69 years of age at diagnosis. I would also be interested in the exact definition of low-risk, as the definition isn't consistent, as well as what other tests were performed to validate the low-risk classification (MRI?) I know that if I was 69, low-risk, I'd have chosen AS as well. But since at the time of my diagnosis I was 54, with a 12-year-old, it would take a lot for me to have considered AS (like one G6 core <5% with every MRI and test known to man). But with the right numbers, I would have done AS, but with a very low "trigger" to begin active treatment. No right or wrong answer, some of us are just not wired for AS and some are.

AgeInfo.Phrase: of my diagnosis I was 54  with a 12 year old

Posts.Title: Does this seem stange - PCP did DRE after Prostate Cancer Surgery ?

Posts.Content: I'm wondering if there's any way to determine if the radiation is not 100% effective, then as quickly as possible take out the "big guns" - HT -- to add to the fight. Perhaps ask the oncologist if your hubby can have PSA tested every two or three weeks, and if PSA continues to rise (or doesn't decrease), then immediately start HT as well...?

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fxoptions I received my result the other day and my Dr told me the following 12/15 samples positive - Gleason 7= 3+4 positive in following Samples: right base 70%, right lateral base 15%,right mid 85%, right lateral mid 100%, right apex 50%, right lateral apex 15%, left lateral base 35%, left mid 5%, left apex 40%, apical nodule 40% Multiple cores (3) PNI (Perineural Invasion present) in 4 cores. my age is 55 Before Biopsy CT showed nodule on apex of prostate (this is why I went to urologist) DRE positive PSA 2.5 was 1.5 10 months ago I will going back to DR soon, I guess he may suggest surgery, what I am concerned about is the PNI in four cores and the nodule. I have read this may show aggression, I will be sending my slide to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion soon, any advise on surgery that may help , open vs robotic? Looks like basically the whole prostate has cancer, 12out of 15, does this also determine treatment options ? Any reply or experience is helpful. I would do it in this order: 1. Find a good experienced (400+) surgeon and schedule the surgery. At your age, unless you have an underlying medical condition, robotic sounds best. 2. After you've scheduled the surgery (about six weeks after the biopsy), then research radiation alternatives. You can always cancel the surgery if you decide to go with radiation. And if you decide to go with surgery, you'll have the first available time "reserved" and you will never have to second guess yourself about waiting...

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> my age is 55 Before Biopsy CT showed nodule

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results in, now what?

Posts.Content: Northwestern U researchers find that vitamin D deficiency could be linked to aggressive prostate cancer http://www.cancer.gov/newscenter/can...ProstateCancer Caught my eye as I my rise in PSA coincided with low Vitamin-D -- and my PCa was more aggressive than what was found on the biopsy... Seems like anyone on AS should also monitor their Vitamin-D levels carefully, and anyone who has both low-vitamin D and rising PSA should think about something more than a standard 12-core biopsy....

Posts.Content: I do think that it's a combination of both - shortening of the urethra as well as your friend just being more "bashful" and not as hard as before. In my mind, that's yet another reason for me to to try a pump or Trimix (cialis and friiends did not work for me), with the first few tries to just stretch my guy out a bit and "remind" him of what it's like to be full of blood

Posts.Title: Shrinkage following DaVinci

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Oh, brother. I would love to be a fly on the wall as you explain to the wife-unit that some stranger on the Internet named "ddayglo" insists that you MUST have as much sex as possible RIGHT NOW. Not that I disagree, but that should be quite an encounter. LOL. I wish I said that to my wife-unit before my surgery. The best I can do now is insist that I can oogle every pretty girl for as long as I want as part of my recovery She agreed for about 3 minutes... Anyway, my wife-unit has been patient, my little-unit is finally starting to "wake-up" from his DaVinci-hibernation. Hopefully things will work down there enough for us to "celebrate" the one-year anniversary of my joining the zero-club.

Posts.Title: Well Crap!

Posts.Content: Here's a reluctant welcome to our club. With all G6's, some would argue that you could consider Active Surveillance (AS). Other may suggest seeds or other treatments. But at your age, I believe most doctors would lean towards surgery. Also, you seem to have an excellent, experienced, caring surgeon. with your stats, there isn't a huge rush to have the surgery and I believe waiting a few extra weeks to decide wouldn't make a difference one way or another. If I were you, I would schedule the surgery and research other options since you can always cancel the surgery if you decide on AS or another treatment. But if you decide to go through with the surgery, your "spot" is already reserved... Take a deep breath, read the stickies, start your kegels now, get the viagra/cialis pills immediately (some insurance plans limit the number of six a month so you can "hoard" a few now). Have as much sex as possible right now. We have a ticket with your name on it already filled out for membership in the "zero" club. Good luck!

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: Definately stay on top of the PSA with very regular tests. Regarding ED, it may be soon soon to try injections but ask your Dr. And read the "ED" sticky and this thread: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/46091-Trimix-update The needle, while sounding scary, is absolutely no big deal at all. After all my little friend was through, he appreciates anything I can do to give him a "boost." My, err OUR only regret is that I wish I had done it much sooner.

Posts.Title: Another update from England

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde Hi Gary, I was diagnosed with G7 in october and was in shock of course. The advice you are given here are excellent and given by guys who are experienced so you are in the right place. The two things that stuck in me which helped a lot was: 1. You are not in a hurry, you have the time to make an informed decision, but with G7 you need to make a decision 2. Talk to an urologist AND an oncologist and if you do not have confidence in them find another. You need input from both sides. Good luck Not to be an alarmist, but with a G3+4 involving at 95%, and another G4+3 on the other side, in my opinion you should start treatment as soon as possible (which if you decide on surgery is about 6 weeks after the biopsy). If I were you, I'd schedule the surgery with an EXPERIENCED surgeon, and then explore other options. You can always cancel the surgery if you decide on something else. And if you decide to go through with the surgery you'll have not had any delay in treatment. I'm also not quite sure what the benefit of a second opinion on the slides would be in this case... You already know you need treatment..... I assume the Drs will be asking you to have scans run to ensure that everything is localized to your prostate, which by every indication seems to be (cross fingers). Good luck!
