The advice you are given here are excellent and given by guys who are experienced so you are in the right place. The two things that stuck in me which helped a lot was: 1. You are not in a hurry, you have the time to make an informed decision, but with G7 you need to make a decision 2. Talk to an urologist AND an oncologist and if you do not have confidence in them find another. You need input from both sides. Good luck Not to be an alarmist, but with a G3+4 involving at 95%, and another G4+3 on the other side, in my opinion you should start treatment as soon as possible (which if you decide on surgery is about 6 weeks after the biopsy). If I were you, I'd schedule the surgery with an EXPERIENCED surgeon, and then explore other options. You can always cancel the surgery if you decide on something else. And if you decide to go through with the surgery you'll have not had any delay in treatment. I'm also not quite sure what the benefit of a second opinion on the slides would be in this case... You already know you need treatment..... I assume the Drs will be asking you to have scans run to ensure that everything is localized to your prostate, which by every indication seems to be (cross fingers). Good luck!

Posts.Title: Vigorous Exercise Post RP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SeaCock I'm almost 12 weeks post op and last week did some light ab's and never felt a thing. I have been stretching them briefly for the last three weeks getting them ready to do some work. I started light lifting when the NP said it was ok...which was 4 weeks post op. Last week I started trying to back to my normal weights...lost 10lbs waiting to get back in the gym...still no legs yet...don't want to stress anything down below until the little man wakes up a little more... Interesting... When I started lifting again (circuit training), also about 12 weeks out, my abs and the area felt "different", and were the absolute last thing to come back. It took almost a year for me to feel that I could do normal ab work. Maybe it was the scar tissue, maybe I was just a bit hesitant to put stress anything down there. I don't see the scars anymore either, but then again they are covered with my gorilla hair...

Posts.Title: Vigorous Exercise Post RP

Posts.Content: Based on the G9, I'm wondering if the Doctor could be thinking conservatively and with an "abundance of caution", and may recommend radiation prophylacticly to make sure all of it is gone. Not to scare you further (if that is possible), but wouldn't it be better to kill one or two cells of G9 lurking in the area surrounding the prostate rather than waiting until it spreads and then shows up on a PSA test? A google of "G9, radiation post ddr" does show that some Doctors seem to recommend radiation even for "G9, PSA 0". Get a second opinion, and good luck.

Posts.Title: I really did not want to be in this club.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 Now have 5/13 cores positive with 4 7's and one 8. IMO, In the unlikely event that every core was downgraded to G6, you still need treatment. And with a G8, you should not wait too long to decide on the treatment type. I think you should choose a good, very experienced surgeon and set a date. You need to wait 6-8 weeks after a biopsy anyway for surgery. Then research radiation specialists. If you decide to choose radiation, you can just cancel the surgery. If you decide on surgery, then it's already "reserved" for the earliest date possible (especially in light of several G7s and a G8 ). Good Luck

Posts.Title: Swollen penis six days after surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steven72 Hi again. Just an interim update. I took two weeks of Cipro, and there has been only minor improvement in the diarrhea situation. Unfortunately my appointment with the urologist did not get scheduled until next week. December 20 is when my GP referred me - a long wait time, but she said he is an excellent urologist. I am having all new blood work and my PSA retest in a couple days. I'll provide another update after my urology appointment. Sometimes antibiotics kill the "good" bacteria in your stomach and cause diarrhea and other issues... Have you been eating plenty of yogurt and taking an acidophilus/probiotic supplement something like culturelle?

Posts.Title: Just recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: HighlanderCFH and your wife has some great advice. Going to a well known "center of excellence" makes a lot of sense to get to the bottom of this. The PCA-3 test (I assume that is what you had) I had was explained to me as an indicator of whether or not cancer has spread to both sides of the prostate But the test is really in it's early stages and many Doctors are waiting for more research on this test. Good luck.

Posts.Title: First Post-op PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steven72 Hi again. Just an interim update. I took two weeks of Cipro, and there has been only minor improvement in the diarrhea situation. Unfortunately my appointment with the urologist did not get scheduled until next week. December 20 is when my GP referred me - a long wait time, but she said he is an excellent urologist. I am having all new blood work and my PSA retest in a couple days. I'll provide another update after my urology appointment. Sometimes antibiotics kill the "good" bacteria in your stomach and cause diarrhea and other issues... Have you been eating plenty of yogurt and taking an acidophilus/probiotic supplement something like culturelle?

Posts.Title: Here we go again...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves I asked before surgery.. how often we would re test he said " 3 months, 3 months , 6 months then yearly. ... I then asked what if the numbers come up? He then said we would start radiation before it hit 1 and it should knock out any remainder... but those questions were asked when we thought we were dealing with a 7 & small 8 .. My surgeon tested me at 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months, 6 months and then yearly... it seems to be the preference of the surgeon. If I was in your situation, I would request, "out of an abundance of caution", if the testing could be done something like 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months... etc. Perhaps say something like your"quality of life" increase if that schedule could be followed as, it would reduce your stress. I believe there is no guarantee that the PSA will be zero the first or second test, but it should steadily decrease... Finally (fingers crossed that it would not be necessary), if your surgeon still believes that salvage radiation would be the next treatment, perhaps you should interview and choose a radiation center/radiation oncologist now. That way if further treatment is needed (lets cross our toes as well that it would not be needed), your basically ready to jump on the treatment the same day. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves Husband, 61 years ~ Biopsy gleeson 7 & 8 right side only . Left side was clear . No symptoms this was caught on routine physical .. Just had Divinci last week now got results today from that upgraded to Gleeson 9 It was contained to prostate lymph glands clear, surgeon said everything was clear and free on edges . Bone scan ..negative Wondering if we dodged a bullet or 2 My question is do you all think we are out of the clear or should I still be worried . Have followed this since he was diagnosed and this seems not to be very good to have a score such as a 9 . We have a appt for cath removal next monday and will have a sit down with him then but I have gone from complete excitment that it was all gone to air sucking omg when he said it was up graded to a 9 ....thoughts We all hope you dodged a bullet! You know the saying, "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst".... If I were in your shoes, I would discuss with the doctor that you want to be as aggressive as possible with post-op PSA testing, scans, etc (every six weeks?) for as-early-as-possible detection of anything which may need further treatment. Also, have a complete plan already in place just in case your husband's PSA doesn't drop to zero (radiation?) . Good Luck!

Posts.Title: new member and trying to decide on surgery vs. radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gunrun Psa 6.9 free Fpsa 11% Biopsy results yesterday from 12 cores? 1 core positive 1% Gleason 7 Sent to secondary pathologist for opinion. Going into Dr office today for consult. I'm 46 with 4 young kids so I have to treat this aggressively. Dr said it's possible he might Of missed other tumors or the tumor he found possibly just nicked it and could be more Than 1%. I will try and copy my pathologist report today. Anyone from Missouri know a good Dr for surgery? Agree, at your age with four young kids you should seek treatment. Most of us would recommend DaVinci rather than open surgery. I would suggest finding a good surgeon (400+ surgeries, perhaps at a major teaching hospital. and schedule the surgery (which will be 6-8 weeks after your biopsy). Then research radiation and other treatments (as well as undergo further tests if needed). You can always reschedule or cancel the surgery if necessary. But if you decide to go through with the surgery, your spot will be "reserved" for the earliest possible time and you will never second guess yourself about waiting an extra few weeks before having the surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news

Posts.Content: Agree with everyone. If you are forced to use physical force on a prisoner charges at you, you don't want to be put in the position of hesitating or second guessing yourself. Perhaps after 10-12 weeks meet one of your partners and go through some potential physical scenarios, starting easy at first, and then wait until the next day and see how you feel... (with Dr approval of course...). Sort of build yourself up over several weeks so you are both mentally and physically ready... ?

Posts.Title: When to go back to work

Posts.Content: Before I discussed my options with my wife, I found some famous people who she knew who are members of our club. I made sure it was a few years ago so I was able to say it was "over 10 years ago" and mentioned Rudy Giuliani, Robert De Niro and Joe Torre. I even used then when discussing my treatment options. "I can go the Joe Torre route and have surgery or the Rudy Giulani route and have radiation..."

Posts.Title: Robert Guillaume - PCa for 25 years?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Now What? I am his wife and he also has these questions and needs answers but doesn't ask, so that's why I am here.). It is two weeks post robotic surgery. Wounds are healing well, he needs to go to the bathroom twice at night and pees quite a bit from what I can hear. Leaking at night is minimal. My question is about rehabbing the penis for erections. We do get a careful, hesitant response so that is hopeful. How often do we need to practice rehab (masturbation) in order to maintain progress? At this time it is just rehab, not desire. He is not taking any Cialis or Viagra. Hubby is upbeat and beside all this basically back to his old self. Thanks for your support. There's still a month or so of healing, so one needs to be very careful notto do any pulling or stretching... One thing I would add is to "stock up" on the cialis and viagra now each month, in case his friend gets "stuck" at 50% or 70% firmness and needs a bit extra push...

Posts.Title: Here we go again...

Posts.Content: Many people have two or three biopsies -- I believe that once you have more than three or so biopsies, treatment can become complicated to some scar tissue forming. Ask about having some sort of "MRI guided" or "saturation" biopsy as opposed to a regular "blind" biopsy. Having your slides checked is also a great idea. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Stay on top of your PSA. Since I had some G4 as well, after my surgeon put me on an annual schedule, I scheduled that PSA and my regular physical six months apart and insisted PSA be taken at the physical as well. My annual PSA with the surgeon is coming up but I am sleeping better knowing that I had it checked six months ago at my standard physical as well.

Posts.Title: Prostate Biospys safe?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves I asked before surgery.. how often we would re test he said " 3 months, 3 months , 6 months then yearly. ... I then asked what if the numbers come up? He then said we would start radiation before it hit 1 and it should knock out any remainder... but those questions were asked when we thought we were dealing with a 7 & small 8 .. My surgeon tested me at 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months, 6 months and then yearly... it seems to be the preference of the surgeon. If I was in your situation, I would request, "out of an abundance of caution", if the testing could be done something like 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months... etc. Perhaps say something like your"quality of life" increase if that schedule could be followed as, it would reduce your stress. I believe there is no guarantee that the PSA will be zero the first or second test, but it should steadily decrease... Finally (fingers crossed that it would not be necessary), if your surgeon still believes that salvage radiation would be the next treatment, perhaps you should interview and choose a radiation center/radiation oncologist now. That way if further treatment is needed (lets cross our toes as well that it would not be needed), your basically ready to jump on the treatment the same day. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves Husband, 61 years ~ Biopsy gleeson 7 & 8 right side only . Left side was clear . No symptoms this was caught on routine physical .. Just had Divinci last week now got results today from that upgraded to Gleeson 9 It was contained to prostate lymph glands clear, surgeon said everything was clear and free on edges . Bone scan ..negative Wondering if we dodged a bullet or 2 My question is do you all think we are out of the clear or should I still be worried . Have followed this since he was diagnosed and this seems not to be very good to have a score such as a 9 . We have a appt for cath removal next monday and will have a sit down with him then but I have gone from complete excitment that it was all gone to air sucking omg when he said it was up graded to a 9 ....thoughts We all hope you dodged a bullet! You know the saying, "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst".... If I were in your shoes, I would discuss with the doctor that you want to be as aggressive as possible with post-op PSA testing, scans, etc (every six weeks?) for as-early-as-possible detection of anything which may need further treatment. Also, have a complete plan already in place just in case your husband's PSA doesn't drop to zero (radiation?) . Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Question about Robotic Prostatectomy Techniques

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oshguy I was sent home from the hospital with Surgilube (a sterile surgical lubricant) for that purpose, but was instructed not to use it unless necessary. I was cautioned to NOT use any type of antibiotic (Neosporin, etc.) or vaseline. Fortunately, I didn't have any discomfort, so never needed to use the Surgilube. I alternated between Vaseline, KY Jelly, neosporin, bacitration. By the time I dediced that KY worked best, it was time to have the tube pulled out...

Posts.Title: Vagisil at catheter insertion point?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves Husband, 61 years ~ Biopsy gleeson 7 & 8 right side only . Left side was clear . No symptoms this was caught on routine physical .. Just had Divinci last week now got results today from that upgraded to Gleeson 9 It was contained to prostate lymph glands clear, surgeon said everything was clear and free on edges . Bone scan ..negative Wondering if we dodged a bullet or 2 My question is do you all think we are out of the clear or should I still be worried . Have followed this since he was diagnosed and this seems not to be very good to have a score such as a 9 . We have a appt for cath removal next monday and will have a sit down with him then but I have gone from complete excitment that it was all gone to air sucking omg when he said it was up graded to a 9 ....thoughts We all hope you dodged a bullet! You know the saying, "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst".... If I were in your shoes, I would discuss with the doctor that you want to be as aggressive as possible with post-op PSA testing, scans, etc (every six weeks?) for as-early-as-possible detection of anything which may need further treatment. Also, have a complete plan already in place just in case your husband's PSA doesn't drop to zero (radiation?) . Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by murphy749 Thanks for your response. I did ask about the PSA Free and the Urologist didnt think it was needed. I think Im going to insist on this test. If the biopsy is negative, then insist on having his PSA checked three or four months later. If it continues to rise, then ask for on a MRI-guided biopsy. Resist the urge to start taking any of those "prostate health" supplements, as you dont want to change the baseline already established. I hope he doesn't have to join our club, but the good news is that you guys are on top of it. Good luck!

Posts.Title: PSA that increased

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves I asked before surgery.. how often we would re test he said " 3 months, 3 months , 6 months then yearly. ... I then asked what if the numbers come up? He then said we would start radiation before it hit 1 and it should knock out any remainder... but those questions were asked when we thought we were dealing with a 7 & small 8 .. My surgeon tested me at 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months, 6 months and then yearly... it seems to be the preference of the surgeon. If I was in your situation, I would request, "out of an abundance of caution", if the testing could be done something like 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months... etc. Perhaps say something like your"quality of life" increase if that schedule could be followed as, it would reduce your stress. I believe there is no guarantee that the PSA will be zero the first or second test, but it should steadily decrease... Finally (fingers crossed that it would not be necessary), if your surgeon still believes that salvage radiation would be the next treatment, perhaps you should interview and choose a radiation center/radiation oncologist now. That way if further treatment is needed (lets cross our toes as well that it would not be needed), your basically ready to jump on the treatment the same day. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves Husband, 61 years ~ Biopsy gleeson 7 & 8 right side only . Left side was clear . No symptoms this was caught on routine physical .. Just had Divinci last week now got results today from that upgraded to Gleeson 9 It was contained to prostate lymph glands clear, surgeon said everything was clear and free on edges . Bone scan ..negative Wondering if we dodged a bullet or 2 My question is do you all think we are out of the clear or should I still be worried . Have followed this since he was diagnosed and this seems not to be very good to have a score such as a 9 . We have a appt for cath removal next monday and will have a sit down with him then but I have gone from complete excitment that it was all gone to air sucking omg when he said it was up graded to a 9 ....thoughts We all hope you dodged a bullet! You know the saying, "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst".... If I were in your shoes, I would discuss with the doctor that you want to be as aggressive as possible with post-op PSA testing, scans, etc (every six weeks?) for as-early-as-possible detection of anything which may need further treatment. Also, have a complete plan already in place just in case your husband's PSA doesn't drop to zero (radiation?) . Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Sorry to see you join our "club". You may be a candidate for active survallence (AS). some people aren't "wired" for AS (for example, knowing that there's a chance the biopsy missed a higher grade of PCa). Others go on AS while realizing that probably will need treatment in the future but feel comfortable with active monitoring. If you decide on treatment, then given your age, most of us on this board would suggest DaVinci surgery. (But remember, there's no right or wrong answer). good luck on your journey, you're among friends who know what you are going through.

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by murphy749 Thanks for your response. I did ask about the PSA Free and the Urologist didnt think it was needed. I think Im going to insist on this test. If the biopsy is negative, then insist on having his PSA checked three or four months later. If it continues to rise, then ask for on a MRI-guided biopsy. Resist the urge to start taking any of those "prostate health" supplements, as you dont want to change the baseline already established. I hope he doesn't have to join our club, but the good news is that you guys are on top of it. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Herbal Supplement Could Outperform Observation in Recurrent Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gunrun Psa 6.9 free Fpsa 11% Biopsy results yesterday from 12 cores? 1 core positive 1% Gleason 7 Sent to secondary pathologist for opinion. Going into Dr office today for consult. I'm 46 with 4 young kids so I have to treat this aggressively. Dr said it's possible he might Of missed other tumors or the tumor he found possibly just nicked it and could be more Than 1%. I will try and copy my pathologist report today. Anyone from Missouri know a good Dr for surgery? Agree, at your age with four young kids you should seek treatment. Most of us would recommend DaVinci rather than open surgery. I would suggest finding a good surgeon (400+ surgeries, perhaps at a major teaching hospital. and schedule the surgery (which will be 6-8 weeks after your biopsy). Then research radiation and other treatments (as well as undergo further tests if needed). You can always reschedule or cancel the surgery if necessary. But if you decide to go through with the surgery, your spot will be "reserved" for the earliest possible time and you will never second guess yourself about waiting an extra few weeks before having the surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Who Has a Post-op Ejaculate?

Posts.Content: Sorry to see you join our "club". You may be a candidate for active survallence (AS). some people aren't "wired" for AS (for example, knowing that there's a chance the biopsy missed a higher grade of PCa). Others go on AS while realizing that probably will need treatment in the future but feel comfortable with active monitoring. If you decide on treatment, then given your age, most of us on this board would suggest DaVinci surgery. (But remember, there's no right or wrong answer). good luck on your journey, you're among friends who know what you are going through.

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves Husband, 61 years ~ Biopsy gleeson 7 & 8 right side only . Left side was clear . No symptoms this was caught on routine physical .. Just had Divinci last week now got results today from that upgraded to Gleeson 9 It was contained to prostate lymph glands clear, surgeon said everything was clear and free on edges . Bone scan ..negative Wondering if we dodged a bullet or 2 My question is do you all think we are out of the clear or should I still be worried . Have followed this since he was diagnosed and this seems not to be very good to have a score such as a 9 . We have a appt for cath removal next monday and will have a sit down with him then but I have gone from complete excitment that it was all gone to air sucking omg when he said it was up graded to a 9 ....thoughts We all hope you dodged a bullet! You know the saying, "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst".... If I were in your shoes, I would discuss with the doctor that you want to be as aggressive as possible with post-op PSA testing, scans, etc (every six weeks?) for as-early-as-possible detection of anything which may need further treatment. Also, have a complete plan already in place just in case your husband's PSA doesn't drop to zero (radiation?) . Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by loves I asked before surgery.. how often we would re test he said " 3 months, 3 months , 6 months then yearly. ... I then asked what if the numbers come up? He then said we would start radiation before it hit 1 and it should knock out any remainder... but those questions were asked when we thought we were dealing with a 7 & small 8 .. My surgeon tested me at 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months, 6 months and then yearly... it seems to be the preference of the surgeon. If I was in your situation, I would request, "out of an abundance of caution", if the testing could be done something like 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 3 months... etc. Perhaps say something like your"quality of life" increase if that schedule could be followed as, it would reduce your stress. I believe there is no guarantee that the PSA will be zero the first or second test, but it should steadily decrease... Finally (fingers crossed that it would not be necessary), if your surgeon still believes that salvage radiation would be the next treatment, perhaps you should interview and choose a radiation center/radiation oncologist now. That way if further treatment is needed (lets cross our toes as well that it would not be needed), your basically ready to jump on the treatment the same day. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bobkeenan Not sure why they did this but I could look at my MyChart this Sunday and there was my biopsy results. I got to see them before i can talk to the doctor. Out of 12 samples one had gleason of 3+4 with 60% of the cells. i think it was left base. And one of 4 (of the 12) samples from the transition zone with gleason 3+4 at 5%. All 10 of the others were benign. My PSA has gone from about 2.8, 8 years ago to 5.75 a few months ago. The last few years it had gone up about .75/ yr. I had a 12 sample biopsy about 3 years ago but it was all benign. My prostate is small, smooth, and no irregularities. Except for having to pee at night once in a while I have no symptoms. I am 64. So..... Hopefully I can talk or see the urologist tomorrow. In the meantime..... 1. Does this sound like early stage? 2. Will the Doc likely want to run more tests? which ones? 3. what would be good questions for the first visit? 4. Any good books or other reading material that I should be reading? Thanks for any help. Sorry to hear that you've joined our club. With those results, most would agree that you need treatment (surgery or radiation). I'm not sure of your stats (such as age), but many of us (not all) have opted for DaVinci surgery. I was given a choice of a second opinion to see if my Gleason score could be downgraded to a 3+3, but I decided against it, as someone saw some Gleason-4 cells there, and therefore I felt I needed treatment. I also scheduled my surgery while deciding if I wanted to have surgery or radiation treatment. That way my place was "reserved" for the surgery in case I decided to go ahead with the surgery knowing that I could always cancel if I decided to go ahead with radiation treatments. Read Dr Patrick Walsh's book "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", and consult with a radiation oncologist and also a surgeon to learn all of the pros and cons of each treatment. Experience is the most important - pick someone with at least 300 surgeries. Hopefully you will keep in touch and become a member of the "zero club" soon. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Question about Robotic Prostatectomy Techniques

Posts.Content: Sorry to see you join our "club". You may be a candidate for active survallence (AS). some people aren't "wired" for AS (for example, knowing that there's a chance the biopsy missed a higher grade of PCa). Others go on AS while realizing that probably will need treatment in the future but feel comfortable with active monitoring. If you decide on treatment, then given your age, most of us on this board would suggest DaVinci surgery. (But remember, there's no right or wrong answer). good luck on your journey, you're among friends who know what you are going through.

Posts.Content: How old are you? What is your PSA level? How many cores were positive? You may wish to consider having another lab look at your biopsy to be sure it's a "true 3+3" and not something borderline. Also, shouldn't you have another PSA test in 3 months to see if it stable or rising? There are several AS'ers here who I assume (and hope) will give their own perspective. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Going back to what Otago said... If I were in your shoes (err had your prostate), and were considering AS, I would consider this course of action: - having slides read again to make sure there is agreement that it's a 6 - discussing with your Dr having a "saturation" biopsy in 3 (or 4) months or so. If the saturation biopsy is still a 6, then in my eyes there would be a strong case for AS.... Regarding Testosterone... Your Dr mentioned that after 6 months of radiation, it's possible that you could go back on it. Is the six months true for other forms of treatment such as surgery? Would one type of treatment would give you a "better" changes of resuming the Testosterone over another? Is that something for you to consider? Again, none of us are medical professionals, and by now you can see that everyone has their own very strong opinions... But we all have been down this road, and wish you the best.

Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Frenchy One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. With 7 out of 12 cores positive (I guess five are G6, one G4+3, and one G3+4), you should ask your Dr about having an MRI(?) to be sure it hasn't spread. I also wouldn't wait to long to make a decision.... Pick an experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery (you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy to have surgery) while also researching proton and other treatments (and make sure that treatment is covered by your insurance). If you decide on surgery, you'll have it at the earliest possible moment and never have to second guess yourself about waiting. If you decide on proton or other treatment, then you can simply cancel the surgery.

Posts.Content: Assuming the bone scan is negative, choose an EXPERIENCED surgeon as soon as possible and make an appointment for the surgery. Surgery cannot happen until about six weeks after the biopsy. Then research radiation.... If you decide on surgery, your spot is already "reserved" and you'll never second guess yourselves for any delay. If you decide on radiation, then you can simply cancel the surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Second Opinion on Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind ddayglo, it sounds like your doctor is assuming the reduction in PSA level is due to "masking" and is not due to a reduction in cancer activity..I wonder how he is able to determine that difference..Medical doctors have a bad habit of rejecting anything you can buy in a health food store as bunco. But if THEY had been diagnosed with terminal cancer, I bet they would not be so quick to reject natural or off-patent treatments and drugs...The drug industry is not interested in anything they can not get a patent on and proclaim to their stock-holders they have discovered a new billion dollar a year drug... I think you may be right... I believe he only ordered the second biopsy after my PSA continued to rise, and did not want me to start something which may lower my PSA, or "mask" a rise in my PSA which would cause him not to order a second biopsy.

Posts.Content: talk to your Dr - the web page http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/551563_5 says the maximum dose is .40

Posts.Title: Why Men and Couples Suffer Alone

Posts.Content: Don't have a standard 12-core biopsy, especially with an "enormous" biopsy. There will be an even greater chance that the biopsy would miss something... Look into a MRI-Guided biopsy. That way the biopsy would be "zero-in" on any suspicious areas found. Good Luck

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: How old are you? What is your PSA level? How many cores were positive? You may wish to consider having another lab look at your biopsy to be sure it's a "true 3+3" and not something borderline. Also, shouldn't you have another PSA test in 3 months to see if it stable or rising? There are several AS'ers here who I assume (and hope) will give their own perspective. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Read and memorize the "AS" sticky. If I had your prostate, err, were in your shoes I would do all of the tests in the AS sticky and then have followup PSA tests every four months (if your insurance allows it). That way if your PSA does increase, you've caught it two months earlier. I would also decide on a treatment plan now, as opposed to waiting for a positive result. That way if you have to switch off of AS, you can start immediately. I believe DaVinci surgery may be a bit stressful for your heart but Open could be an option as well as focal HIFU or radiation. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance Protocol

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Frenchy One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. With 7 out of 12 cores positive (I guess five are G6, one G4+3, and one G3+4), you should ask your Dr about having an MRI(?) to be sure it hasn't spread. I also wouldn't wait to long to make a decision.... Pick an experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery (you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy to have surgery) while also researching proton and other treatments (and make sure that treatment is covered by your insurance). If you decide on surgery, you'll have it at the earliest possible moment and never have to second guess yourself about waiting. If you decide on proton or other treatment, then you can simply cancel the surgery.

Posts.Title: Number Of Advanced Prostate Cancer Cases Soars

Posts.Content: In the US, most employment contracts state that you could get laid off for any reason, such as a "reorg" (where they can simply change the wording of the title of your position). I also believe that in the US after you can go on disability after you've used all of your sick and vacation time. Perhaps go to Human Resources first and then tell your boss. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Location of Positive Cores

Posts.Content: A sad welcome to our "club". While AS certainly seems like an option, Chuck's question about the your kidney situation is spot-on. IMO you need to go through the "what-if" scenarios. (I don't know much about kidney treatment and a possible transplant, so please excuse me if I'm off-base). For example: If your husband's number is called and he has the transplant, would that change his PCa treatment options? If your husband's number is called in the middle or radiation or seed therapy, can he still have the transplant? Regarding surgery, I believe my Dr said that I needed to check with him for three months if any other medical condition came up. How soon after the surgery would he be able to have a transplant? Good luck!

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer options

Posts.Content: I believe in your case with one core at 85%, and a PSA >10, you aren't a candidate for AS and need treatment no matter what, even if you had several labs agree you were a G6. When I was diagnosed with 3+4, one Dr suggested I get a second opinion and if the G7 was downgraded to a G6, then I could consider holding off one treatment and go on AS. I decided against it, as in my mind, I would have needed both labs to agree I was a G6 before going on AS (in my mind, a "solid G6"). So my suggestion would be to start researching treatment and not bother with a second opinion, since with your age and stats I don't think anyone would consider you a candidate for AS. Most of us, especially at our age, lean towards Robotic surgery. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Recovery from DaVinci Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Can you post a copy of the biopsy report and your stats (age, general health, etc)? With 11 out of 12 cores positive you do need treatment, and as soon as possible. Find a good EXPERIENCED surgeon and schedule the surgery for the earliest possible date (usually 6 weeks after biopsy). Then research radiation treatment. If you decide on radiation, then you can always cancel the surgery (but keep those notes handy as it's a possibility that you will need salvage radiation in case something did leave the prostate). If you decide on surgery, then your spot is already "reserved" for the earliest possible date and you will never have to second-guess yourself about delaying treatment. Good luck!

Posts.Title: need help about prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Going back to what Otago said... If I were in your shoes (err had your prostate), and were considering AS, I would consider this course of action: - having slides read again to make sure there is agreement that it's a 6 - discussing with your Dr having a "saturation" biopsy in 3 (or 4) months or so. If the saturation biopsy is still a 6, then in my eyes there would be a strong case for AS.... Regarding Testosterone... Your Dr mentioned that after 6 months of radiation, it's possible that you could go back on it. Is the six months true for other forms of treatment such as surgery? Would one type of treatment would give you a "better" changes of resuming the Testosterone over another? Is that something for you to consider? Again, none of us are medical professionals, and by now you can see that everyone has their own very strong opinions... But we all have been down this road, and wish you the best.

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Frenchy One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. With 7 out of 12 cores positive (I guess five are G6, one G4+3, and one G3+4), you should ask your Dr about having an MRI(?) to be sure it hasn't spread. I also wouldn't wait to long to make a decision.... Pick an experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery (you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy to have surgery) while also researching proton and other treatments (and make sure that treatment is covered by your insurance). If you decide on surgery, you'll have it at the earliest possible moment and never have to second guess yourself about waiting. If you decide on proton or other treatment, then you can simply cancel the surgery.

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Frenchy One of the lucky one percenters to be diagnosed early. Just turned fifty. No symptoms. Just did the required tests, Colonoscopy (they removed 9 polyps (good decision this was)), and biopsy as a result of the elevated PSA, 21.7; 7 out of 12 cores, Gleason 7, one 3+4, and another 4+3, the rest not as high, all on the left side, prostate normal size at 25cc. With 7 out of 12 cores positive (I guess five are G6, one G4+3, and one G3+4), you should ask your Dr about having an MRI(?) to be sure it hasn't spread. I also wouldn't wait to long to make a decision.... Pick an experienced surgeon and schedule the surgery (you need to wait about six weeks after the biopsy to have surgery) while also researching proton and other treatments (and make sure that treatment is covered by your insurance). If you decide on surgery, you'll have it at the earliest possible moment and never have to second guess yourself about waiting. If you decide on proton or other treatment, then you can simply cancel the surgery.

Posts.Title: Your input needed. Do an MRI guided Biopsy or Just Biopsy if delay in getting MRI

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bernard1 My doctor texted me this morning and told me that the steroids will actually impair healing. Do I want to heal from the surgery or have burning, itching hives? I think I'll go with the hives. Hopefully Benadryl will do the trick. However, I discovered that taking Benadryl at night has its own risks! I believe somebody shared a similar situation on another post about taking NyQuil before bedtime and flooding the mattress! http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...-the-Titanic!? Are you still on the steroids? Usually prednisone is given in a six-day "medrol pack", where the dosage is decreased each day. You CANNOT just go off of it "cold turkey". You MUST go off of it gradually. Going off a high-dose "cold turkey" can be life-threatening! Talk to your internist about how to best decrease the dose each day. At worst, you'll be a week or two behind on the healing.

Posts.Title: 3-Week Post-DaVinci Update - and a Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Hi My fathers PSA from last year went from 4.5 to 5.2 . He had his 12 point biopsy done and today came back positive for pc. I dont know yet his number for sure but I believe he mentioned 7. His doctor send him for bone and lymph node scan. He is 64 years young. I'm also upset because previous doctor he went to when he was 4.5 told him not to worry and didn't order any fallow up tests. He never had any symptoms. Im just worried and scared. We are in NYC and I know that are few great surgeons that you guys recommend. Any help, advice will be highly appreciated. Im 37 now and I guess I have to make an appointment and get myself check too - is that a good idea ? Sorry that your father joined our "club" and we hope you never do. Your internist should be able to take your PSA as well as perform a "DRE" annually. You'll have a good baseline at a minimum for yourself. As far as your father goes, the more stats the better - the number of "positive" cores, the percent involvement, Grade (which sounds like either a G3+4 or a G4+3), etc. But with a G7, your father needs treatment and it is probably a choice between radiation and surgery. I'm sure others will also contribute. Dr Walsh has a book called the "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" - it's a must read. NYC has some of the best Doctors in the world; the more experience the better. Good Luck and we hope your father will soon join the "Zero Club" and also hope that you'll never be a member!

Posts.Title: Location of Positive Cores

Posts.Content: Interesting replies.. So, someone with a Gleason 6 (or a 3+4) should really check where the positive core(s) are located. If they are on the outer edge of the prostate, or at the Apex, that is something to consider before deciding on "active surveillance"..... And, if positive core is by the bladder neck, that could be a data point to be considered as part of the radiation-vs-surgery decision. (I hope I got this right) Would really be interesting for everyone to ask their urologist/radiologist about this...

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: Did the Dr also tell you to have yogurt or acidophilus along with the Antibiotic? While Antibiotics kill bacteria-based germs, it also kills some of the good stuff in your body and stomach so many Drs tell you to have a lot of foods with "active cultures" like yogurt and acidophilus. Even though you are off of the Bactrim, continue having yogurt several times a day along with something like "culturelle" which has lots of active cultures. Prednisone is a type of steroid (not the type that athletes use)... It prevents the release of substances in the body that cause inflammation. It also suppresses the immune system. I'm prescribed it when I have a nasty sinus infection... I remember peeing more often when on it, and a search on the internet shows that some people complain that prednisone will cause more frequent urination, so that may be related to what you are going through. Are you on a "medrol" pack, which means you take one less pill each day for six days? If so, a day or two after you are off the prednisone you should begin to get back to normal. Have you contacted your surgeon? Another search of "Dr Google" shows that prednisone can affect PSA level, which you'll be tested for regularly post-surgery... So your surgeon needs to know ASAP about the predisone in case he wants to move back any testing by a week or two while the prednisone gets out of your system. (to be clear, I'm not questioning the need for prednisone, it sounds like you really needed it). Also, as Chuck says, asking your pharmacist would also be a good idea. Lets hope this is your only pothole in your road to recovery. Goo luck

Posts.Title: Surgery or Radiation or Is waiting 6 weeks for a vaccine trail worth it?

Posts.Content: I would go to urologist and plan out an "Active Surveillance" schedule. Let the urologist do his own DRE (as a baseline). Maybe antibiotics. Plan for another PSA test in 3-6 months. Probably most important, it will give your brother a chance to see if the urologist's "bedside manner" is to his (and your) liking. That way if your brother does need treatment down the road, you have already chosen a urologist which you are comfortable with and you would be one step ahead of many of us were at that stage... good luck

Posts.Title: Psa doubled 2.6. Twin bro has pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by regress I'm putting together questions for my local Uro. What I have so far is based on posts I've read here, input from my local support group, and Walsh's book. Would love feedback/additional suggestions if anyone has a moment! In your opinion, difference between robotic/open/laparoscopic -- pros/cons? Are you familiar with Patrick Walsh's book and what is your opinion of it? Number of surgeries performed: Total, per year, last year and type (open, larapro, robot)? How many surgeries does the hospital do per month/year? Patient mix in terms of stage and how many in my stage (T1C)? What are your clear margin rates per stage? % of your patients who have regained continence? % of your patients who have overcome ED? How do you reconstruct the urinary sphincter? I've read about a "Rocco stitch"? Who assists you in surgery? What days do you do surgery and how many do you schedule on one day? If I decide to go with an out-of-state surgeon, will you coordinate with him as my local specialist? Great list! Once it is finalized, it would be great to add it to DaVinci sticky post so others may benefit as well... Otago's points are very valid.... I'll have a tiny squirt when lifting a 40-50 lb bag of pellets or rock salt. My Dr defines that as "continent". Others say one pad per day. Maybe ask how many surgeries actually performed (not just observe) Maybe ask about the Dr's philosophy on Kegels? How soon to start Viagra?

Posts.Title: Questions for Surgeon

Posts.Content: I was a "single core 3+4, 5%". Decided to have DaVinci, turns out I had 4+3 and more widespread than the biopsy suggested. Definitely get that second opinion, and research whether a "saturation biopsy" would give you and your Dr additional data for your decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: While I did not chose AS due to my risk score, if I was a Gleason 6, knowing what I do now, before proceeding down that road, I would have: a)Had my slides looked at my someone else to confirm it was a "true" 6 and nothing borderline; b)Discuss with my urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" biopsy and doing a "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... c)Add PCA-III test as an additional "marker"

Posts.Signature: BD: 1959 PSA 4.9 11/2012 (no symptoms) Biopsy 12/2012 Negative PSA 5.9 05/2013 (still no symptoms) Biopsy 6/2013 3+4 (thank goodness for PSA tests) 1 core positive (upper left), 1 suspicious (lower left) out of 12 DRE: bump right side T1c; PCA-III = 20 (normal) Da Vinci 7/18/2013: Invasive carcinoma involves left lobe of prostate only, extends from left apex to posterior mid region of left lobe Gleason 7/10 (4+3); G4 tumor comprises 75% of invasive carcinoma present Estimated total volume of carcinoma in entire prostate gland: 10% TNM: T2b NX MX (Stage IIA) 8/25/13 11/4/13 2/11/14 8/1/14 2/15/15 8/20/15 3/1/16, 8/30/16, 3/25/17,9/25/17,4/14/18: PSA undetectable My Story: [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32491-T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci..."]T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci...[/URL] [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32693-Catheter-is-Out!?highlight=ddayglo"] Catheter is Out![/URL]
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: While I did not chose AS due to my risk score, if I was a Gleason 6, knowing what I do now, before proceeding down that road, I would have: a)Had my slides looked at my someone else to confirm it was a "true" 6 and nothing borderline; b)Discuss with my urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" biopsy and doing a "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... c)Add PCA-III test as an additional "marker"

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side. While walking is good to help get the bloating down, be careful not to overdo it. I'm sure you've read each of our "BM Quests"... Have plenty of fresh fruit and stool softener. It'll happen eventually and you'll be tempted to mark it as a national holiday. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Finally on Day+1

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Leob I asked him what about doing a saturation biopsy. He explained that the current 12 core biopsy samples 1/1000 of the prostate, so even if I would take 120 samples this would be statistically insignificant and increase very slightly the chances of identifying PCa therefore it is not worth running to have an additional biopsy so fast. I am aware that apart from doing a standard biopsy the only way to confirm PCa is to do a biopsy on the prostate after removing it, so I am asking myself if the chances of discovering PCa through a standard biopsy are so low why do it at all ?? I will probably at this point not ask for a 2nd opinion, just do the 2nd PSA test, don’t really know if having the PCA3 would be beneficial? Any suggestions remarks would be appreciated? Thanking you all for all the answers and support I received up to now.!! Leo After my first biopsy was negative, I went for another PSA test, which was higher. That's when my Urologist recommended a second biopsy. I'm not sure I understand the logic of the Saturation Biopsy.... For example, wouldn't 24 cores double the chance of finding something?

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsy results this is what my Urologist Recommended

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Hi My fathers PSA from last year went from 4.5 to 5.2 . He had his 12 point biopsy done and today came back positive for pc. I dont know yet his number for sure but I believe he mentioned 7. His doctor send him for bone and lymph node scan. He is 64 years young. I'm also upset because previous doctor he went to when he was 4.5 told him not to worry and didn't order any fallow up tests. He never had any symptoms. Im just worried and scared. We are in NYC and I know that are few great surgeons that you guys recommend. Any help, advice will be highly appreciated. Im 37 now and I guess I have to make an appointment and get myself check too - is that a good idea ? Sorry that your father joined our "club" and we hope you never do. Your internist should be able to take your PSA as well as perform a "DRE" annually. You'll have a good baseline at a minimum for yourself. As far as your father goes, the more stats the better - the number of "positive" cores, the percent involvement, Grade (which sounds like either a G3+4 or a G4+3), etc. But with a G7, your father needs treatment and it is probably a choice between radiation and surgery. I'm sure others will also contribute. Dr Walsh has a book called the "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" - it's a must read. NYC has some of the best Doctors in the world; the more experience the better. Good Luck and we hope your father will soon join the "Zero Club" and also hope that you'll never be a member!

Posts.Title: Post-RALP Catheter Removal

Posts.Content: I would go to urologist and plan out an "Active Surveillance" schedule. Let the urologist do his own DRE (as a baseline). Maybe antibiotics. Plan for another PSA test in 3-6 months. Probably most important, it will give your brother a chance to see if the urologist's "bedside manner" is to his (and your) liking. That way if your brother does need treatment down the road, you have already chosen a urologist which you are comfortable with and you would be one step ahead of many of us were at that stage... good luck

Posts.Title: Psa doubled 2.6. Twin bro has pca

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear the news. I assume there will be more tests to determine if its still localized. Surgery may still be an option even if it's spread, to "debulk" the PC. Please find out what kind of treatment (hormone therapy?) can be started immediately to stop the PC from from spreading either outside the Prostate if it is localized or any further if it has. That could give you some time and "breathing room" to choose a major center-of-excellence knowing that you've "frozen" the PC from spreading further and tackling this head-on. I'm sure others will more experience will add their recommendations.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Hi My fathers PSA from last year went from 4.5 to 5.2 . He had his 12 point biopsy done and today came back positive for pc. I dont know yet his number for sure but I believe he mentioned 7. His doctor send him for bone and lymph node scan. He is 64 years young. I'm also upset because previous doctor he went to when he was 4.5 told him not to worry and didn't order any fallow up tests. He never had any symptoms. Im just worried and scared. We are in NYC and I know that are few great surgeons that you guys recommend. Any help, advice will be highly appreciated. Im 37 now and I guess I have to make an appointment and get myself check too - is that a good idea ? Sorry that your father joined our "club" and we hope you never do. Your internist should be able to take your PSA as well as perform a "DRE" annually. You'll have a good baseline at a minimum for yourself. As far as your father goes, the more stats the better - the number of "positive" cores, the percent involvement, Grade (which sounds like either a G3+4 or a G4+3), etc. But with a G7, your father needs treatment and it is probably a choice between radiation and surgery. I'm sure others will also contribute. Dr Walsh has a book called the "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" - it's a must read. NYC has some of the best Doctors in the world; the more experience the better. Good Luck and we hope your father will soon join the "Zero Club" and also hope that you'll never be a member!

Posts.Content: While I did not chose AS due to my risk score, if I was a Gleason 6, knowing what I do now, before proceeding down that road, I would have: a)Had my slides looked at my someone else to confirm it was a "true" 6 and nothing borderline; b)Discuss with my urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" biopsy and doing a "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... c)Add PCA-III test as an additional "marker"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bob_R I must be missing something here, if my Urologist said to me "Hey looks like it is negative lets keep an eye on you over the coming months" I would be ecstatic, live large , forget about it for 6 months and circle back to see if there is a problem or does your prostate engine just run at a higher temp than normal expectations. In hindsight, I wish after my first negative biopsy I did two things: a)consider myself as under "AS" and follow an "AS" diet (see the AS Thread for more details); and b)ask for cialis, viagra, etc and live LARGE below the waist

Posts.Title: Your input needed. Do an MRI guided Biopsy or Just Biopsy if delay in getting MRI

Posts.Content: While I did not chose AS due to my risk score, if I was a Gleason 6, knowing what I do now, before proceeding down that road, I would have: a)Had my slides looked at my someone else to confirm it was a "true" 6 and nothing borderline; b)Discuss with my urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" biopsy and doing a "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... c)Add PCA-III test as an additional "marker"
Posts.Signature: BD: 1959 PSA 4.9 11/2012 (no symptoms) Biopsy 12/2012 Negative PSA 5.9 05/2013 (still no symptoms) Biopsy 6/2013 3+4 (thank goodness for PSA tests) 1 core positive (upper left), 1 suspicious (lower left) out of 12 DRE: bump right side T1c; PCA-III = 20 (normal) Da Vinci 7/18/2013: Invasive carcinoma involves left lobe of prostate only, extends from left apex to posterior mid region of left lobe Gleason 7/10 (4+3); G4 tumor comprises 75% of invasive carcinoma present Estimated total volume of carcinoma in entire prostate gland: 10% TNM: T2b NX MX (Stage IIA) 8/25/13 11/4/13 2/11/14 8/1/14 2/15/15 8/20/15 3/1/16, 8/30/16, 3/25/17,9/25/17,4/14/18: PSA undetectable My Story: [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32491-T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci..."]T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci...[/URL] [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32693-Catheter-is-Out!?highlight=ddayglo"] Catheter is Out![/URL]
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I believe surgery is still a "standard". My surgeon and a radiologist I spoke to says that cyberknife uses a high dose of radiotherapy and can cause burns, and the technology is still being perfected... Maybe in 5 or 10 years, most MRIs will be replaced by biopsies and cyberknife will become a standard.

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: I was a "single core 3+4, 5%". Decided to have DaVinci, turns out I had 4+3 and more widespread than the biopsy suggested. Definitely get that second opinion, and research whether a "saturation biopsy" would give you and your Dr additional data for your decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Leob I asked him what about doing a saturation biopsy. He explained that the current 12 core biopsy samples 1/1000 of the prostate, so even if I would take 120 samples this would be statistically insignificant and increase very slightly the chances of identifying PCa therefore it is not worth running to have an additional biopsy so fast. I am aware that apart from doing a standard biopsy the only way to confirm PCa is to do a biopsy on the prostate after removing it, so I am asking myself if the chances of discovering PCa through a standard biopsy are so low why do it at all ?? I will probably at this point not ask for a 2nd opinion, just do the 2nd PSA test, don’t really know if having the PCA3 would be beneficial? Any suggestions remarks would be appreciated? Thanking you all for all the answers and support I received up to now.!! Leo After my first biopsy was negative, I went for another PSA test, which was higher. That's when my Urologist recommended a second biopsy. I'm not sure I understand the logic of the Saturation Biopsy.... For example, wouldn't 24 cores double the chance of finding something?

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bob_R I must be missing something here, if my Urologist said to me "Hey looks like it is negative lets keep an eye on you over the coming months" I would be ecstatic, live large , forget about it for 6 months and circle back to see if there is a problem or does your prostate engine just run at a higher temp than normal expectations. In hindsight, I wish after my first negative biopsy I did two things: a)consider myself as under "AS" and follow an "AS" diet (see the AS Thread for more details); and b)ask for cialis, viagra, etc and live LARGE below the waist

Posts.Signature: BD: 1959 PSA 4.9 11/2012 (no symptoms) Biopsy 12/2012 Negative PSA 5.9 05/2013 (still no symptoms) Biopsy 6/2013 3+4 (thank goodness for PSA tests) 1 core positive (upper left), 1 suspicious (lower left) out of 12 DRE: bump right side T1c; PCA-III = 20 (normal) Da Vinci 7/18/2013: Invasive carcinoma involves left lobe of prostate only, extends from left apex to posterior mid region of left lobe Gleason 7/10 (4+3); G4 tumor comprises 75% of invasive carcinoma present Estimated total volume of carcinoma in entire prostate gland: 10% TNM: T2b NX MX (Stage IIA) 8/25/13 11/4/13 2/11/14 8/1/14 2/15/15 8/20/15 3/1/16, 8/30/16, 3/25/17,9/25/17,4/14/18: PSA undetectable My Story: [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32491-T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci..."]T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci...[/URL] [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32693-Catheter-is-Out!?highlight=ddayglo"] Catheter is Out![/URL]
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: While I did not chose AS due to my risk score, if I was a Gleason 6, knowing what I do now, before proceeding down that road, I would have: a)Had my slides looked at my someone else to confirm it was a "true" 6 and nothing borderline; b)Discuss with my urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" biopsy and doing a "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... c)Add PCA-III test as an additional "marker"

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear the news. I assume there will be more tests to determine if its still localized. Surgery may still be an option even if it's spread, to "debulk" the PC. Please find out what kind of treatment (hormone therapy?) can be started immediately to stop the PC from from spreading either outside the Prostate if it is localized or any further if it has. That could give you some time and "breathing room" to choose a major center-of-excellence knowing that you've "frozen" the PC from spreading further and tackling this head-on. I'm sure others will more experience will add their recommendations.

Posts.Title: Shorter penis after prostate removal?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by regress I'm putting together questions for my local Uro. What I have so far is based on posts I've read here, input from my local support group, and Walsh's book. Would love feedback/additional suggestions if anyone has a moment! In your opinion, difference between robotic/open/laparoscopic -- pros/cons? Are you familiar with Patrick Walsh's book and what is your opinion of it? Number of surgeries performed: Total, per year, last year and type (open, larapro, robot)? How many surgeries does the hospital do per month/year? Patient mix in terms of stage and how many in my stage (T1C)? What are your clear margin rates per stage? % of your patients who have regained continence? % of your patients who have overcome ED? How do you reconstruct the urinary sphincter? I've read about a "Rocco stitch"? Who assists you in surgery? What days do you do surgery and how many do you schedule on one day? If I decide to go with an out-of-state surgeon, will you coordinate with him as my local specialist? Great list! Once it is finalized, it would be great to add it to DaVinci sticky post so others may benefit as well... Otago's points are very valid.... I'll have a tiny squirt when lifting a 40-50 lb bag of pellets or rock salt. My Dr defines that as "continent". Others say one pad per day. Maybe ask how many surgeries actually performed (not just observe) Maybe ask about the Dr's philosophy on Kegels? How soon to start Viagra?

Posts.Signature: BD: 1959 PSA 4.9 11/2012 (no symptoms) Biopsy 12/2012 Negative PSA 5.9 05/2013 (still no symptoms) Biopsy 6/2013 3+4 (thank goodness for PSA tests) 1 core positive (upper left), 1 suspicious (lower left) out of 12 DRE: bump right side T1c; PCA-III = 20 (normal) Da Vinci 7/18/2013: Invasive carcinoma involves left lobe of prostate only, extends from left apex to posterior mid region of left lobe Gleason 7/10 (4+3); G4 tumor comprises 75% of invasive carcinoma present Estimated total volume of carcinoma in entire prostate gland: 10% TNM: T2b NX MX (Stage IIA) 8/25/13 11/4/13 2/11/14 8/1/14 2/15/15 8/20/15 3/1/16, 8/30/16, 3/25/17,9/25/17,4/14/18: PSA undetectable My Story: [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32491-T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci..."]T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci...[/URL] [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32693-Catheter-is-Out!?highlight=ddayglo"] Catheter is Out![/URL]

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: While I did not chose AS due to my risk score, if I was a Gleason 6, knowing what I do now, before proceeding down that road, I would have: a)Had my slides looked at my someone else to confirm it was a "true" 6 and nothing borderline; b)Discuss with my urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" biopsy and doing a "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... c)Add PCA-III test as an additional "marker"

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: With every ZERO, your "PSAnxiety" will decrease. After your six month test is zero, your Dr will suggest the PSA retest in another six months. Don't. Ask him to be retested in three months and then again after another three months. Tell him that while it may not be logical, tell him that if you do this your level of anxiety will decrease and QUALITY OF LIFE will increase. Then after those tests are zero, your Dr will recommend annual PSA testing. Don't. Be tested every six months. I did this my scheduling my annual physical and annual surgical visit six months apart (and insisting that the PSA be tested). Knowing that I am being tested TWICE AS OFTEN as what is recommended significantly decreased my "PSAnxiety". You may have a problem with insurance although I haven't so far. When I told my internist how much it decreased my stress, he liked the idea so much that he's recommending it to all of his patients.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I believe surgery is still a "standard". My surgeon and a radiologist I spoke to says that cyberknife uses a high dose of radiotherapy and can cause burns, and the technology is still being perfected... Maybe in 5 or 10 years, most MRIs will be replaced by biopsies and cyberknife will become a standard.

Posts.Signature: BD: 1959 PSA 4.9 11/2012 (no symptoms) Biopsy 12/2012 Negative PSA 5.9 05/2013 (still no symptoms) Biopsy 6/2013 3+4 (thank goodness for PSA tests) 1 core positive (upper left), 1 suspicious (lower left) out of 12 DRE: bump right side T1c; PCA-III = 20 (normal) Da Vinci 7/18/2013: Invasive carcinoma involves left lobe of prostate only, extends from left apex to posterior mid region of left lobe Gleason 7/10 (4+3); G4 tumor comprises 75% of invasive carcinoma present Estimated total volume of carcinoma in entire prostate gland: 10% TNM: T2b NX MX (Stage IIA) 8/25/13 11/4/13 2/11/14 8/1/14 2/15/15 8/20/15 3/1/16, 8/30/16, 3/25/17,9/25/17,4/14/18: PSA undetectable My Story: [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32491-T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci..."]T-Minus-36-Hours-until-da-Vinci...[/URL] [URL="http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/32693-Catheter-is-Out!?highlight=ddayglo"] Catheter is Out![/URL]
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Make the surgery at the earliest possible date (probably six weeks after the biopsy), and make sure its an experienced (400+) surgeries. We have a reservation already made out in your name for the zero club. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Diagnosed in Atlanta

Posts.Content: While I did not chose AS due to my risk score, if I was a Gleason 6, knowing what I do now, before proceeding down that road, I would have: a)Had my slides looked at my someone else to confirm it was a "true" 6 and nothing borderline; b)Discuss with my urologist going beyond the standard "12 core" biopsy and doing a "saturation biopsy" for additional assurance that there are no Gleason 7's hiding in there.... c)Add PCA-III test as an additional "marker"

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 From what I have read, it is difficult to get up from a sitting or lying position after DaVinci surgery. I remember how sore my abdomen was in this regard, when recovering from umbilical hernia surgery years back. I am doing DaVinci surgery on August 3rd. and strongly suspect much worse soreness abdominal pain compared to the hernia recovery. I am thinking of using snow ski poles to help hoist myself out of a chair, or up from a bed. I have practiced this a few times with the ski poles, and the strain on the abdomen is much reduced when using your shoulder muscles to pull yourself up. Has anyone tried this, or similar after DaVinci?? I have given some thought about sleeping on a recliner as suggested on this forum, but with my wife is recovering from knee replacement surgery, and she will be unable to move the recliner from the reclined position to regular upright chair position. So, don't think a recliner is the way to go. I am thinking our bed is better choice, and using the poles to help get up. Any thoughts or suggestions?? Rooster2 While I was sore like I did 1,000 situps, for me, it wasn't the soreness, it was a complete lack of strength in my abdominal area. Chairs were not a problem for me. I'm not sure how the poles would help with a recliner (they may work in a regular bed)

Posts.Title: Use snow ski poles during DaVinci surgery recovery

Posts.Content: If you are considering AS (and most of us would not as you have 3 cores, one with 60% involvement), have should serious consider having your slides sent out to a second lab. Your surgeon who placed the spinal stimulator may also have recommendations about radiation. Good luck

Posts.Content: I would also wait and have the MRI... make sure it's the very latest technology (others would know exactly which type). My first biopsy was negative. Perhaps if I had one along with the MRI it would not have been. You could even discuss having a "saturation" biopsy (20+ cores) along with the state-of-the-art MRI. Good luck

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I am Originally Posted by ourtime I don't have any questions, answers, or words of wisdom, just need a little support. I posted here a month ago or so. My husband at that time was a Gleason 5+3=8. Right: 4 cores of 6 positive, 25% involved by tumor. Left: 3 cores of 6 positive, 2.0% involved by tumor. Prostate size 75 grams.. Bone scan and CT were negative. Da Vinci surgery on Nov 23. Final Path; 1) Left peripheral margin, biopsy; positive 2)Apical margin, positive 3) Posterior apical margin, negative 4) Left peripheral margin, negative, 5) apical margin, negative 6) prostate gland, Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+5=9. Tumor quantification; right and left lobes, percentage of prostate involved by tumor 80% Extraprostatic extension: present. Seminal vesicle invasion: present, right and left Margins: Focally positive for malignancy (apical, bladder neck, anterior lateral) 7)Right lateral biopsy: negative Lymph nodes, (4) right pelvic, 1 node positive (3.8 MM) 9)Lymph nodes, (7) left pelvic, 4 nodes positive (largest focus 10MM) Prostate size 82 grams. Pathologic staging: pT3b pN1 We are in for a battle! We have not made a plan written in stone just yet. We will wait for husband's body to heal and for a 3 month PSA to really develop the plan. Dr said with this path. report, he doubts that his PSA will be 0 in three months. He will more then likely will be starting ADT. Words of encouragement needed! With G9 and positive margins, I'm not sure why your Dr wants to wait 3 months for ADT and other treatment. Maybe I'm mistaken, but it doesn't seen aggressive enough - I would think the this needs to be attacked this head-on with both barrels and carpet bombed... I would seek a second opinion ASAP. Good Luck

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I was a "single core 3+4, 5%". Decided to have DaVinci, turns out I had 4+3 and more widespread than the biopsy suggested. Definitely get that second opinion, and research whether a "saturation biopsy" would give you and your Dr additional data for your decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Sorry to have you join our "club". You do need treatment. Many would say DaVinci, but if you are not "wired" for a catheter than you should consider other treatments such as radiation. While you would be satisfied with a full life at 72 without treatment, I'm not sure that those last few years would be very satisfying. Good luck

Posts.Title: Looking for advice and emotional support with new Prostate Ca diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Plan for the worst but hope for the best. Suggest you make an appointment to see a rad oncologist and an oncologist to see what options you have going forward if plan B is needed. With a G9 and positive seminal vesicle invasion, if cancer is outside, you want to get a jump on the cancer ASAP. Sound advice.

Posts.Title: Persistent PSA post RP

Posts.Content: Based on these numbers, how much would a "saturation biopsy" (say 40 cores) increase the probability of finding PCa? Basically I'm curious how much is gained by having a saturation biopsy (as opposed to a "regular one) before deciding on AS... I can see how multiple saturation biopsies is not good. But assuming your insurance pays for it, why would you not do one before going on AS?

Posts.Title: 12 core biopsy samples 1/1000 of the prostate, What does that mean

Posts.Content: All excellent advise, especially the scans to see if anything has spread. In the meantime, decide on a surgeon as quickly as possible and schedule the surgery (make sure the surgeon has 300+ or 400+ surgeries). Then research radiation treatment. The surgery needs to scheduled 6-8 weeks after the biopsy. And many times there is a waiting list for surgery. If you or your Drs decide that radiation is best, then you can simply cancel the surgery. Otherwise, you have the "reservation" for surgery already set at the earliest possible time and you will never have to second guess yourself worrying that you had to delay the surgery by a few weeks. Good luck

Posts.Title: husband just diagnosed

Posts.Content: If you are considering AS (and most of us would not as you have 3 cores, one with 60% involvement), have should serious consider having your slides sent out to a second lab. Your surgeon who placed the spinal stimulator may also have recommendations about radiation. Good luck

Posts.Content: Make the surgery at the earliest possible date (probably six weeks after the biopsy), and make sure its an experienced (400+) surgeries. We have a reservation already made out in your name for the zero club. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Once I found out that I joined this "club", (or even after my first biopsy, which was negative) I wish I had realized (and expected) that insurance will not cover more than a handful each month. I wish I had immediately asked for an ED Drug such as viagra, filled it each month, and "stockpiled them" for use after my surgery.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 if psa is undetectable, perform a genetic test on the prostatectomy sample - if score is high, this would lead to more caution by proceeding immediately with AR. If score is low, we could monitor closely. If psa is detectable - all bets are off and most likely looking at Early Salvage treatment. Steve Sounds like a good course of action, with the caveat that if the genetic score is low and the PSA is undetectable, monitor with follow up with six-week PSA tests for at least a year if not longer... Good Luck

Posts.Content: The DaVinci procedure basically puts you at a 45 degree downwards angle, please be sure to discuss this with the surgeon as well as whomever is treating him for the strokes and coagulation issue. Good luck

Posts.Title: Robotic Procedure and Lymph Node Removal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Rylee I had read on this forum that after 2 or 3 biopsies scar tissue becomes an issue. Could someone explain that further. Is the scar tissue an issue in future surgery and if so how? My surgeon told me he's seen scar tissue after 3 or 4 biopsies, especially saturation biopsies (which basically double the amount of cores).. . However, he also mentioned that with the advent of MRI-guided biopsies, saturation biopsies are becoming less and less common.

Posts.Title: Recently Diagnosed with Questions

Posts.Content: With every ZERO, your "PSAnxiety" will decrease. After your six month test is zero, your Dr will suggest the PSA retest in another six months. Don't. Ask him to be retested in three months and then again after another three months. Tell him that while it may not be logical, tell him that if you do this your level of anxiety will decrease and QUALITY OF LIFE will increase. Then after those tests are zero, your Dr will recommend annual PSA testing. Don't. Be tested every six months. I did this my scheduling my annual physical and annual surgical visit six months apart (and insisting that the PSA be tested). Knowing that I am being tested TWICE AS OFTEN as what is recommended significantly decreased my "PSAnxiety". You may have a problem with insurance although I haven't so far. When I told my internist how much it decreased my stress, he liked the idea so much that he's recommending it to all of his patients.
