Posts.Title: Looking for advice and emotional support with new Prostate Ca diagnosis.

Posts.Content: All excellent advise, especially the scans to see if anything has spread. In the meantime, decide on a surgeon as quickly as possible and schedule the surgery (make sure the surgeon has 300+ or 400+ surgeries). Then research radiation treatment. The surgery needs to scheduled 6-8 weeks after the biopsy. And many times there is a waiting list for surgery. If you or your Drs decide that radiation is best, then you can simply cancel the surgery. Otherwise, you have the "reservation" for surgery already set at the earliest possible time and you will never have to second guess yourself worrying that you had to delay the surgery by a few weeks. Good luck

Posts.Title: Bike riding, DRE, & sexual activity effects on PSA

Posts.Content: Once I found out that I joined this "club", (or even after my first biopsy, which was negative) I wish I had realized (and expected) that insurance will not cover more than a handful each month. I wish I had immediately asked for an ED Drug such as viagra, filled it each month, and "stockpiled them" for use after my surgery.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: All excellent advise, especially the scans to see if anything has spread. In the meantime, decide on a surgeon as quickly as possible and schedule the surgery (make sure the surgeon has 300+ or 400+ surgeries). Then research radiation treatment. The surgery needs to scheduled 6-8 weeks after the biopsy. And many times there is a waiting list for surgery. If you or your Drs decide that radiation is best, then you can simply cancel the surgery. Otherwise, you have the "reservation" for surgery already set at the earliest possible time and you will never have to second guess yourself worrying that you had to delay the surgery by a few weeks. Good luck

Posts.Content: Strong Agree. Your dad needs to see another Dr, one who be much more aggressive with G9. I believe one course of action would be hormone therapy, basically to stop the G9 in its tracks from spreading, while additional tests and an aggressive treatment is planned out. There are some posters here who have been diagnosed with G9 several if not many years ago and I'm sure will post as well. Good Luck and get rid of this Dr and find one ASAP who will treat this with the urgency it deserves. Good

Posts.Title: Father with Gleason 9 & PSA 2.5

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 if psa is undetectable, perform a genetic test on the prostatectomy sample - if score is high, this would lead to more caution by proceeding immediately with AR. If score is low, we could monitor closely. If psa is detectable - all bets are off and most likely looking at Early Salvage treatment. Steve Sounds like a good course of action, with the caveat that if the genetic score is low and the PSA is undetectable, monitor with follow up with six-week PSA tests for at least a year if not longer... Good Luck

Posts.Content: Based on these numbers, how much would a "saturation biopsy" (say 40 cores) increase the probability of finding PCa? Basically I'm curious how much is gained by having a saturation biopsy (as opposed to a "regular one) before deciding on AS... I can see how multiple saturation biopsies is not good. But assuming your insurance pays for it, why would you not do one before going on AS?

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: Strong Agree. Your dad needs to see another Dr, one who be much more aggressive with G9. I believe one course of action would be hormone therapy, basically to stop the G9 in its tracks from spreading, while additional tests and an aggressive treatment is planned out. There are some posters here who have been diagnosed with G9 several if not many years ago and I'm sure will post as well. Good Luck and get rid of this Dr and find one ASAP who will treat this with the urgency it deserves. Good

Posts.Content: My biopsy showed a 3+4 in one core, the surgeon never mentioned lymph nodes and didn't take any out with my procedure. Afterwards, I asked him why not, and he said that he doesn't feel the need to unless he saw some evidence of things spreading or close to the edge. I guess it's up to the surgeon.

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: I can see the value of someone having a second opinion on biopsy slides if someone is thinking of AS... But what is the value if someone is already above the guidelines for AS? Say someone has say six positive cores, with several G3+4's, all at 50% involvement, and a high PSA. What would be the value of the second opinion? What would change in treatment if some or even if all of the cores were downgraded from a G3+4 to a G3+3?

Posts.Title: Question about the value of a 2nd opinion on the biopsy slides...

Posts.Content: Ask about an advanced MRI (3T, I forget the exact term). It's non-evasive (no needles). It will give a good baseline of your prostate. Get your PSA tested again in four-six months or so. Make sure you don't do any bike riding or have sex or for a few days beforehand. Then if your PSA rises again, then you can have a second MRI -- which can be compared to the first one for any changes.

Posts.Title: Next Year

Posts.Content: Agree with Walt, need another "trigger" before treating. Read the "AS" sticky. Go on the "AS Diet" listed in the sticky. Ask Dr about antibiotics/BPH. Have your PSA retested in 3 or 4 months. If PSA goes up again, schedule another biopsy but make sure it's a "saturation" biopsy or a "targeted MRI" biopsy. Tell your wife/girlfriend that you are on AS and need to have as much sex as you possibly can and are required to watch as much porn as possible Good luck

Posts.Title: Spindle Cell Sarcoma of the Prostate - Any Cure?

Posts.Content: Yes, based on the number of cores and % involvement you need treatment. In my case, I knew that once i decided on a treatment, I wanted to have it start as soon as possible. I was leaning towards surgery but I wasn't 100% certain. And if it took me a few weeks to decide, I didn't want to basically "lose" those few weeks and then schedule the surgery. So, I scheduled with a surgeon for DaVinci while researching the other treatments such as seeds. That way, if I decided on surgery, my slot already "reserved" with no time lost. If I decided on another treatment, then all I would have to do is cancel the surgery. I ended up doing the surgery, which is what most Doctors will recommend for someone our age. Read the stickies about the different treatments, do your own research, and chose what you feel is best for you. While you have a reluctant welcome into our club, we will be very glad to welcome you into the "Zero Club" once this ordeal is over. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Bike riding, DRE, & sexual activity effects on PSA

Posts.Content: Sorry your husband had to join our "club". Read all of the stickies, they contain a wealth of information. At your husband's age, most of us would lean towards surgery..... Most would also recommend robotic (DaVinci) surgery as well. I thought about sending my slides out as well but decided against it. Even the slides were downgraded to a G3+3, someone had "seen" some G4 cells in there. Therefore I decided not to send my slides out and AS was off the table for me -- it would have taken two different labs to both agree on G6 before I would consider AS. I picked a good, experienced DaVinci surgeon, chose a surgery date, and then researched radiation alternatives. That way, my "spot" was reserved if I decided to go through with the surgery. If not, I could simply cancel the surgery and switch to alternative treatment and I would never have to second guess any delay in treatment. I went through with the surgery and it turned out I had G4+G3 instead of G3+G4. But so far all if good as it was caught early. One thing I would do immediately is order viagra or cialis in order to "stock up" as insurance usually doesn't cover more than a few a month. And have your husband start kegels now. You guys got this. No reason to panic, just make a decision and don't look back.

Posts.Title: OT: Pharmacies and Security

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your news. I assume he had a positive biopsy. Can you get a copy of the results and post it here? Will he advocate for himself at the Dr and find out as much as he can about treatment options or does he need someone to be there for him? Don't take it wrong, but many guys would feel shy about discussing prostate cancer with anyone, especially a female and very especially to their daughter. If there is someone he does listed to, then the best thing to do is have that person "take point" with your dad (maybe your mom?) . What you can do is research the best surgeons and radiologists in the area who are affiliated with a world-class hospital. Maybe find two or three very good experienced ones and then let himchoose which one to go to (that way he feels like he has some choice, you know us guys)... My gut feeling is that if the PC is still located within his prostate and since he's in good health then DaVinci surgery, with a good, experienced surgeon (400+ surgery's) could be an option (e.g. a CURE). But you'll have to await the results of the scans. In the meantime, there's a good book by Dr Patrick Walsh, you can order it on Amazon with express shipping. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: 25 yrs old - my dad was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Agree with Walt, need another "trigger" before treating. Read the "AS" sticky. Go on the "AS Diet" listed in the sticky. Ask Dr about antibiotics/BPH. Have your PSA retested in 3 or 4 months. If PSA goes up again, schedule another biopsy but make sure it's a "saturation" biopsy or a "targeted MRI" biopsy. Tell your wife/girlfriend that you are on AS and need to have as much sex as you possibly can and are required to watch as much porn as possible Good luck

Posts.Title: Spindle Cell Sarcoma of the Prostate - Any Cure?

Posts.Content: Had Davinci on 7/18. Follow-up next week. I know before surgery when havig a PSA test we are not supposed to do anything which could raise the level. But now that my prostate is out, I'm assuming it doesn't matter, right? I'm almost wondering if I should do everything I was told not to do before checking PSA level, like bike riding, giving my semi-limp friend a "helping hand", etc. Almost do everything I can to raise whatever PSA level there may be to find it sooner. And I do plan on talking to the Dr about what I can do to wake by "lil buddy" up some more.

Posts.Title: Need opinions on Da vinci or radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Another thing is not to allow a doctor to perform a digital rectal exam before having a PSA test. It will temporarily elevate the number. In the 48-72 hours before having a PSA test, do NOT have: a DRE, sex, ride a bike, perform vigorous exercise. All of those things, including anything else that can place stress on the prostate, can put a temporary spike in the PSA. Good luck -- and welcome to the forum. We hope you're just "passing through." LOL Chuck Interestingly, for a PCA3 test, you want to do those things! One Doc gave me a DRE right before he drew blood CORRECTION: I GAVE URINE for the PCA3 test. Then again, he's the one who said I could go on AS even with G3+4 since it was only in one core...

Posts.Title: Advice

Posts.Content: I'm wondering if you could schedule another PSA test in a month or so, after a bout of antibiotics and zero biking and sex for about a week before the PSA test. Also find out if your insurance company and hospital will let you do a 3T MRI-guided biopsy. That way the needles will be guided to any suspicious areas. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Newbie: This is not looking good.

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your news. I assume he had a positive biopsy. Can you get a copy of the results and post it here? Will he advocate for himself at the Dr and find out as much as he can about treatment options or does he need someone to be there for him? Don't take it wrong, but many guys would feel shy about discussing prostate cancer with anyone, especially a female and very especially to their daughter. If there is someone he does listed to, then the best thing to do is have that person "take point" with your dad (maybe your mom?) . What you can do is research the best surgeons and radiologists in the area who are affiliated with a world-class hospital. Maybe find two or three very good experienced ones and then let himchoose which one to go to (that way he feels like he has some choice, you know us guys)... My gut feeling is that if the PC is still located within his prostate and since he's in good health then DaVinci surgery, with a good, experienced surgeon (400+ surgery's) could be an option (e.g. a CURE). But you'll have to await the results of the scans. In the meantime, there's a good book by Dr Patrick Walsh, you can order it on Amazon with express shipping. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Decided on a doctor and scheduling for daVinci.

Posts.Content: Had Davinci on 7/18. Follow-up next week. I know before surgery when havig a PSA test we are not supposed to do anything which could raise the level. But now that my prostate is out, I'm assuming it doesn't matter, right? I'm almost wondering if I should do everything I was told not to do before checking PSA level, like bike riding, giving my semi-limp friend a "helping hand", etc. Almost do everything I can to raise whatever PSA level there may be to find it sooner. And I do plan on talking to the Dr about what I can do to wake by "lil buddy" up some more.

Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: Sorry your husband had to join our "club". Read all of the stickies, they contain a wealth of information. At your husband's age, most of us would lean towards surgery..... Most would also recommend robotic (DaVinci) surgery as well. I thought about sending my slides out as well but decided against it. Even the slides were downgraded to a G3+3, someone had "seen" some G4 cells in there. Therefore I decided not to send my slides out and AS was off the table for me -- it would have taken two different labs to both agree on G6 before I would consider AS. I picked a good, experienced DaVinci surgeon, chose a surgery date, and then researched radiation alternatives. That way, my "spot" was reserved if I decided to go through with the surgery. If not, I could simply cancel the surgery and switch to alternative treatment and I would never have to second guess any delay in treatment. I went through with the surgery and it turned out I had G4+G3 instead of G3+G4. But so far all if good as it was caught early. One thing I would do immediately is order viagra or cialis in order to "stock up" as insurance usually doesn't cover more than a few a month. And have your husband start kegels now. You guys got this. No reason to panic, just make a decision and don't look back.

Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde I have noticed this also, could it be that the DaVinci methods are getting better and better? It is a rather new method. Witnesses from 10 years ago seems to have more incontinence issues. Or the guys who have no problems just stop talking about it and move on... You may be on to something. A few years ago a surgeon named Bernardo Rocco gave a speech about a new technique which is now called the "Rocco Stitch" to help incontinence. I asked my surgeon about it, and he said that does something similar but even better. Google "Rocco Stitch" and you can see several articles about it and variations.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH If it were me, and my initial Gleason estimate was Gleason 7, and a second opinion gave a Gleason 6, I would consider it a jump ball and seek a THIRD opinion to break the tie. In other words, I'd be wondering WHICH one was the correct assessment, so the best 2 out of 3 would come into play. I my case, my biopsy had one core at G3+4 and one Dr highly recommended I get a second opinion, and if it was downgraded to a G6, then go on AS. I decided against it, as someone who was trained "saw" some G4 cells, and I would have needed TWO different labs both agreeing that I was a G6 before considering AS (and see my final stats, I was not a good candidate for AS) Pratoman - I agree that there is value in knowing the "real deal", but that's just the deal for whatever tissue was sampled (since something like 20% of higher grade PC's is missed. In your case, the G3+5 was "strange", and a second opinion was a good idea. I guess I'm seeing a lot of posts here suggesting a second opinion, which for some of the "PC Newbies" is causing some additional stress because of either resistance or delay from the biopsy center to sending the slides... It would be sad if sending the slides out causes any kind of delay in treatment.... I'm not sure I see the value in a second opinion for ALL biopsies.

Posts.Title: Question about the value of a 2nd opinion on the biopsy slides...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Foilingfool2 Hi, I am new here and hope to get some opinions. I started getting my PSA checked 3 years ago when I turned 50. My first check was 0.3 and my DRE was normal. A year later my PSA was 0.6 and my DRE was normal. I am now 52, and just had my most recent check. My PSA is now 3.4. I did have a colonoscopy on Jan 12 and my PSA test was on Jan 28. I see my GP next week. I will likely head to the urologist as well. Very worried, as expected. Just wondering if you might think the colonoscopy may be the cause of the raised PSA. I know it can have an effect, just not sure how much and for how long? Thanks, Tom It does sound like a rapid rise, which may be the result of an infection. Ask the Dr about taking antibiotics and then having a retest. Good Luck

Posts.Title: PC Risk, PSA and Biopsy

Posts.Content: A reluctant welcome to our "club". Adding some stats about your age and general help would be useful (we are full of advise!) Some may disagree with me, but I'm not sure having a second opinion on the biopsy is necessary as you do need treatment. When I couldn't decide the type of treatment, I decided to choose a surgeon and surgical method first and schedule it as soon as I could (which was for me about seven weeks after the biopsy). I then interviewed and researched radiation. If I decided on radiation, then all I had to do was cancel the surgery. But then if I went through with the surgery, my spot on line was already "reserved" and I didn't ever have to second guess myself about delaying my treatment because of indecision. In the meantime, read the stickies, stock up on Viagra, and know that we all were exactly in the same place you were and we're happy to share our own experiences with a new club member. Good luck

Posts.Title: Need opinions on Da vinci or radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Sorry your husband had to join our "club". Read all of the stickies, they contain a wealth of information. At your husband's age, most of us would lean towards surgery..... Most would also recommend robotic (DaVinci) surgery as well. I thought about sending my slides out as well but decided against it. Even the slides were downgraded to a G3+3, someone had "seen" some G4 cells in there. Therefore I decided not to send my slides out and AS was off the table for me -- it would have taken two different labs to both agree on G6 before I would consider AS. I picked a good, experienced DaVinci surgeon, chose a surgery date, and then researched radiation alternatives. That way, my "spot" was reserved if I decided to go through with the surgery. If not, I could simply cancel the surgery and switch to alternative treatment and I would never have to second guess any delay in treatment. I went through with the surgery and it turned out I had G4+G3 instead of G3+G4. But so far all if good as it was caught early. One thing I would do immediately is order viagra or cialis in order to "stock up" as insurance usually doesn't cover more than a few a month. And have your husband start kegels now. You guys got this. No reason to panic, just make a decision and don't look back.

Posts.Content: I was asked to come back in six months, and I'm glad I did (see my stats) Two years is WAAAYYYY too long. In hindsight, I wish... a) I would have considered myself on a type of "Active Surveillance" and followed Walt's "AS Diet" (see the sticky for more info) b) perhaps had the PSA test even sooner than six months c) asked for antibiotics in case to eliminate prostatitis Good luck and I hope you never have to join our "club"

Posts.Title: 55 yr old husband just diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Sorry your husband had to join our "club". Read all of the stickies, they contain a wealth of information. At your husband's age, most of us would lean towards surgery..... Most would also recommend robotic (DaVinci) surgery as well. I thought about sending my slides out as well but decided against it. Even the slides were downgraded to a G3+3, someone had "seen" some G4 cells in there. Therefore I decided not to send my slides out and AS was off the table for me -- it would have taken two different labs to both agree on G6 before I would consider AS. I picked a good, experienced DaVinci surgeon, chose a surgery date, and then researched radiation alternatives. That way, my "spot" was reserved if I decided to go through with the surgery. If not, I could simply cancel the surgery and switch to alternative treatment and I would never have to second guess any delay in treatment. I went through with the surgery and it turned out I had G4+G3 instead of G3+G4. But so far all if good as it was caught early. One thing I would do immediately is order viagra or cialis in order to "stock up" as insurance usually doesn't cover more than a few a month. And have your husband start kegels now. You guys got this. No reason to panic, just make a decision and don't look back.

Posts.Title: 55 yr old husband just diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: A reluctant welcome to our "club". Adding some stats about your age and general help would be useful (we are full of advise!) Some may disagree with me, but I'm not sure having a second opinion on the biopsy is necessary as you do need treatment. When I couldn't decide the type of treatment, I decided to choose a surgeon and surgical method first and schedule it as soon as I could (which was for me about seven weeks after the biopsy). I then interviewed and researched radiation. If I decided on radiation, then all I had to do was cancel the surgery. But then if I went through with the surgery, my spot on line was already "reserved" and I didn't ever have to second guess myself about delaying my treatment because of indecision. In the meantime, read the stickies, stock up on Viagra, and know that we all were exactly in the same place you were and we're happy to share our own experiences with a new club member. Good luck

Posts.Title: Just learned my biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: At this and other forums, I've read good things about the following three pharmacies: www.northwestpharmacy.com, www.affordabledrugs.com, and www.alldaychemist.com. Being a paranoid IT security guy, I decided to test strength of their SSL encryption. (At the risk of oversimplifying, SSL encryption is used to encrypt communication between your browser and the remote web server. It's basically mandated by Visa, MC, etc when entering credit card info. I tested them using www.ssllabs.com (a free service). Here are the results... www.northwestpharmacy.com: Grade A: https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/anal...stpharmacy.com www.alldaychemist.com Grade B: https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/anal...hideResults=on www.affordabledrugs.com: Grade F: https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/anal..._reg_step1.cfm I would not overgeneralize and say that affordabledrugs is not secure internally, but, personally, to me, a failing score for the SSL certificate does raise a red flag. (I'll contact them and see if they upgrade their certificate, which would be a good indication that they do care about their security) I would also suggest using a prepaid card when ordering from one of the pharmacies (and many other internet web sites for that matter). Update 9/5/2013: never heard back from affordabledrugs. Also, northwestpharmacy and affordabledrugs are listed as members of the Canadian International Pharmacy Association: http://www.cipa.com/member/northwestpharmacy.com http://www.cipa.com/member/affordabledrugs.com

Posts.Title: OT: Pharmacies and Security

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sky365 Whoda thunk at 54, no sex and wearing panty liners. Hopeful but not too confident. I could live with the incontinence if only the ED could be solved. Having a wife 18 years younger than me used to be a thrilling thing. Good luck to you all, Dan Assuming you've tried Viagra without any luck, ask your Dr about Trimix. He may think it's a bit early for you to resort to injections, but its worth asking. According to the ED thread and especially this thread (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/46091-Trimix-update), we all agree the shot isn't that bad, and the results vary from really good to hanging-wet-towels-to-dry or hailing-a-cab amazing, and that we should have asked about it much much sooner.

Posts.Content: I was asked to come back in six months, and I'm glad I did (see my stats) Two years is WAAAYYYY too long. In hindsight, I wish... a) I would have considered myself on a type of "Active Surveillance" and followed Walt's "AS Diet" (see the sticky for more info) b) perhaps had the PSA test even sooner than six months c) asked for antibiotics in case to eliminate prostatitis Good luck and I hope you never have to join our "club"

Posts.Title: Just had the Prostate Ultrasound and Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Well, today I go for my one year PSA Blood draw, I have an appointment with the Surgeon on Friday, so that's the latest I'll have the results, but who knows maybe they post it online tomorrow. Today is also, Ironically, one year to the day that I went under the knife. I'll never forget sitting in that hospital waiting room for over an hour waiting for them to take me in. I'm particularly nervous about this one, I guess because it's the one year mark, so in my mind (assuming I still have a mind) it's a big one. Probably also a little PSTD, after my experience 3 months ago, when Quest mistakenly reported my 9 month PSA as 3.88 Keeping my fingers crossed. Yup, one year is a huge "birthday". After my one year "zero", my surgeon put me on an annual PSA schedule. I decided to tweak my schedule for my physical to make it six months later and then insist the PSA be drawn. That way even though I "graduated" to annual testing I'm actually having my PSA tested every six months (once by the surgeon and once by my internist as part of my physical). Doubling the recommended testing more than halved my "PSAnxiety". Anyway, after all you've been through you deserve a big fat ZERO and then a big fat glass of scotch to celebrate!

Posts.Title: Ache on right side of stomach

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sky365 Whoda thunk at 54, no sex and wearing panty liners. Hopeful but not too confident. I could live with the incontinence if only the ED could be solved. Having a wife 18 years younger than me used to be a thrilling thing. Good luck to you all, Dan Assuming you've tried Viagra without any luck, ask your Dr about Trimix. He may think it's a bit early for you to resort to injections, but its worth asking. According to the ED thread and especially this thread (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/46091-Trimix-update), we all agree the shot isn't that bad, and the results vary from really good to hanging-wet-towels-to-dry or hailing-a-cab amazing, and that we should have asked about it much much sooner.

Posts.Title: Newbe - 66 Days post op Da Vinci

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Well, today I go for my one year PSA Blood draw, I have an appointment with the Surgeon on Friday, so that's the latest I'll have the results, but who knows maybe they post it online tomorrow. Today is also, Ironically, one year to the day that I went under the knife. I'll never forget sitting in that hospital waiting room for over an hour waiting for them to take me in. I'm particularly nervous about this one, I guess because it's the one year mark, so in my mind (assuming I still have a mind) it's a big one. Probably also a little PSTD, after my experience 3 months ago, when Quest mistakenly reported my 9 month PSA as 3.88 Keeping my fingers crossed. Yup, one year is a huge "birthday". After my one year "zero", my surgeon put me on an annual PSA schedule. I decided to tweak my schedule for my physical to make it six months later and then insist the PSA be drawn. That way even though I "graduated" to annual testing I'm actually having my PSA tested every six months (once by the surgeon and once by my internist as part of my physical). Doubling the recommended testing more than halved my "PSAnxiety". Anyway, after all you've been through you deserve a big fat ZERO and then a big fat glass of scotch to celebrate!

Posts.Title: Travel

Posts.Content: Most of the time, Drs will recommend treatment based on their area of speciality.... surgeons will recommend surgery and radiation specialists will recommend radiation. Sort of surprised AS was not presented as an option. Surgery is much more difficult (but not impossible) after seeds. Also, Send your slides out for a second opinion. At your age and family history, most of us would recommend surgery unless there was a reason like a preexisting condition. I would forget the three week "deadline". If it takes you a month or six weeks, so be it. Good luck

Posts.Title: Travel

Posts.Content: This is the second time (or maybe it was from the same poster) that a second opinion has downgraded things by two levels. Anyway, what everyone says above makes perfect sense. Assuming you have the surgery scheduled at the earliest possible date, you've done everything right, and there's every expectation that things will also turn out fine. Take a deep breath, try to relax, and remember that we have a reservation waiting for you to join the "zero club".

Posts.Title: Dad's catheter and staples removed today...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH *****"Those favoring surgery will tell you that surgeons cannot perform surgery following a failed primary radiation treatment. IMHO experience counts more than anything else.... None of the surgeons in my area had performed surgery after seeds, nor have heard of any surgeons who had done so. (I live in the NY Tri-State region, and I met with several surgeons...) Does anyone know of a surgeon who has performed many of these types of surgery-after-seeds?

Posts.Content: I just posted a link to this thread in the "What I need to know about ED"... sticky

Posts.Title: Penile Injections

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden Two days ago, I learned that I have prostate cancer. My urologist gave me some literature to review and I will be meeting with him next week to discuss the treatment alternatives. This support group is excellent and I thank you in advance for your help. With regard to the pathology report, I asked my doctor if I should get a second opinion on the pathology and he said it's up to me. He told me the pathologist who read the slides is excellent. The core sample from the right lateral apex is "prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 7 (3+4) (Grade Group 1 of 5), involving one of two fragments, less than 5% of the tissue". The new prostate cancer group grading system (see below) says Grade Group 1 is for a Gleason score of 6. My Gleason score is 7 (3+4) and I think it should be a Grade Group 2, not Grade Group 1 - as the pathology report states. If the pathologist is wrong, do you think I should question his overall diagnosis and tell my doctor that I want another pathologist to review the slides? If it wasn't for this, I probably wouldn't ask for it. Am I overreacting? It's my understanding that the Grade Group system is pretty new. The new grading system is: Grade Group 1 (Gleason score 6) Only individual, discrete, well-formed glands Grade Group 2 (Gleason score 3 + 4 = 7) Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component of poorly formed/fused/ cribriform glands Grade Group 3 (Gleason score 4 + 3 = 7) Predominantly poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands with a lesser component of wellformed glands Grade Group 4 (Gleason score Only poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands or Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component lacking glands or Predominantly lacking glands with a lesser component of well-formed glands Grade Group 5 (Gleason scores 910) Lacks gland formation/necrosis with or without poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands A second opinion on the slides is never a bad idea. Sorry you had you had to join our "club". The good news is that with one core G3+4 at <5% you don't have to rush into treatment.

Posts.Title: Overwhelmed

Posts.Content: It's hard, but think in terms of weekly and not daily improvement. I had a big improvement between weeks four and five and again at three months. Try not to fatigue your muscle too much by overdoing the exercises. I personally found that, like weightlifting, alternating "heavy" days (eg lots of "Kegal"s) with "light" days worked best for me. * Note: As much as I enjoyed peeing like a fire-hose, what actually worked best for me was to try and "stop the stream" rather than Kegels.

Posts.Title: Bladder control after robotic surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikem350 Buy CVS Triple Antibiotic and Pain Relief. Its an ointment, not water based, so it does not dry out and acts as a lube. Best the tube has a long tip for ease of application!!! No Q tip needed!! I applied it often and moved the tube in and out (very little) to distribute the stuff. Oh what joy... I lived on this stuff when I had my catheter "borg implant". Highly recommended.

Posts.Title: Golf?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PaulG Thought I'd introduce myself. I'm 53 and was diagnosed with prostate cancer just five days ago, so I'm just starting to learn about all this. (I'm reading the Dr. Walsh book now.) Based on what I know so far, it was caught early and I'm in a low-risk category. I've got a Gleason score of 6 (3+3) and a PSA of just 0.6 ng/mL. Nothing unusual was felt with DRE. My cancer was caught only because I had a 10-month history of hematospermia (blood in semen). No other symptoms. They assumed prostatitis, but when antibiotics did nothing and the bleeding continued, a new urologist suggested a biopsy to rule out anything serious. Imagine my surprise. I will meet with my urologist again in two weeks to discuss treatment options in more detail, and I am seeing a different urologist for a second opinion soon after that. (Also, awaiting lab results on whether PTEN is absent.) My initial reaction is that prostatectomy seems best, given my age and life expectancy (dad lived to 87). But I'm keeping an open mind, and I'd welcome any suggestions. One question: I'll ask the doctors about the number of RPs they've done, rates of complications, how much incontinence their patents reported 3, 6, 12 month out, etc. (Q's that Dr. Walsh's book suggests.) Is there any resource that compiles that sort of information and makes it publicly available? One problem is that the more experienced surgeons take on the harder cases, so their results may look "worse" than other surgeons. But a surgeon at a center of excellence from a teaching hospital with over 400 surgeries would be a good start! Also, ask the surgeons about whether or not hematospermia is a potential complication for RP, and also how they define being "dry" (some call it one pad a day, some say zero pads. This thread and the DaVinci sticky also have some questions to ask your surgeon. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: New guy

Posts.Content: I used a recliner for the first few days... Put a towel or sheet under you since you'll have a fever and sweat a lot for a day or two (read the surgery sticky for more tips). It took me almost a year to feel comfortable doing situps, not the least due to a guaranteed pee squirt every time! Good luck

Posts.Title: Golf?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH *****"Those favoring surgery will tell you that surgeons cannot perform surgery following a failed primary radiation treatment. IMHO experience counts more than anything else.... None of the surgeons in my area had performed surgery after seeds, nor have heard of any surgeons who had done so. (I live in the NY Tri-State region, and I met with several surgeons...) Does anyone know of a surgeon who has performed many of these types of surgery-after-seeds?

Posts.Title: Penile Injections

Posts.Content: Most of the time, Drs will recommend treatment based on their area of speciality.... surgeons will recommend surgery and radiation specialists will recommend radiation. Sort of surprised AS was not presented as an option. Surgery is much more difficult (but not impossible) after seeds. Also, Send your slides out for a second opinion. At your age and family history, most of us would recommend surgery unless there was a reason like a preexisting condition. I would forget the three week "deadline". If it takes you a month or six weeks, so be it. Good luck

Posts.Title: Penile Injections

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PaulG Thought I'd introduce myself. I'm 53 and was diagnosed with prostate cancer just five days ago, so I'm just starting to learn about all this. (I'm reading the Dr. Walsh book now.) Based on what I know so far, it was caught early and I'm in a low-risk category. I've got a Gleason score of 6 (3+3) and a PSA of just 0.6 ng/mL. Nothing unusual was felt with DRE. My cancer was caught only because I had a 10-month history of hematospermia (blood in semen). No other symptoms. They assumed prostatitis, but when antibiotics did nothing and the bleeding continued, a new urologist suggested a biopsy to rule out anything serious. Imagine my surprise. I will meet with my urologist again in two weeks to discuss treatment options in more detail, and I am seeing a different urologist for a second opinion soon after that. (Also, awaiting lab results on whether PTEN is absent.) My initial reaction is that prostatectomy seems best, given my age and life expectancy (dad lived to 87). But I'm keeping an open mind, and I'd welcome any suggestions. One question: I'll ask the doctors about the number of RPs they've done, rates of complications, how much incontinence their patents reported 3, 6, 12 month out, etc. (Q's that Dr. Walsh's book suggests.) Is there any resource that compiles that sort of information and makes it publicly available? One problem is that the more experienced surgeons take on the harder cases, so their results may look "worse" than other surgeons. But a surgeon at a center of excellence from a teaching hospital with over 400 surgeries would be a good start! Also, ask the surgeons about whether or not hematospermia is a potential complication for RP, and also how they define being "dry" (some call it one pad a day, some say zero pads. This thread and the DaVinci sticky also have some questions to ask your surgeon. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: New guy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden Two days ago, I learned that I have prostate cancer. My urologist gave me some literature to review and I will be meeting with him next week to discuss the treatment alternatives. This support group is excellent and I thank you in advance for your help. With regard to the pathology report, I asked my doctor if I should get a second opinion on the pathology and he said it's up to me. He told me the pathologist who read the slides is excellent. The core sample from the right lateral apex is "prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 7 (3+4) (Grade Group 1 of 5), involving one of two fragments, less than 5% of the tissue". The new prostate cancer group grading system (see below) says Grade Group 1 is for a Gleason score of 6. My Gleason score is 7 (3+4) and I think it should be a Grade Group 2, not Grade Group 1 - as the pathology report states. If the pathologist is wrong, do you think I should question his overall diagnosis and tell my doctor that I want another pathologist to review the slides? If it wasn't for this, I probably wouldn't ask for it. Am I overreacting? It's my understanding that the Grade Group system is pretty new. The new grading system is: Grade Group 1 (Gleason score 6) Only individual, discrete, well-formed glands Grade Group 2 (Gleason score 3 + 4 = 7) Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component of poorly formed/fused/ cribriform glands Grade Group 3 (Gleason score 4 + 3 = 7) Predominantly poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands with a lesser component of wellformed glands Grade Group 4 (Gleason score Only poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands or Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component lacking glands or Predominantly lacking glands with a lesser component of well-formed glands Grade Group 5 (Gleason scores 910) Lacks gland formation/necrosis with or without poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands A second opinion on the slides is never a bad idea. Sorry you had you had to join our "club". The good news is that with one core G3+4 at <5% you don't have to rush into treatment.

Posts.Title: Overwhelmed

Posts.Content: Even his PSA is now zero, while it sounds aggressive, attacking what little PC which may may have been left behind does sound reasonable. The PC in your dad's body is on the ropes. Something like 99% of it was been removed. The radiation would make sure it it stays at 100% gone. Not sure about going into a "full court press" and adding HT - I'm sure others will add their experiences. Posting a copy of the full report would be useful. For example, G7 could be G3+4, which means it was mostly G3, the "better" kind of PC. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Penile Injections

Age.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> Im 37 now and I guess I

DoctorRecommended.Sample: I ended up doing the surgery, which is what most Doctors will recommend for someone our age. Read the stickies about the different treatments, do your own research, and chose what you feel is best for you....You can add to your signature some details (number of positive cores, location of the positives, % involvement, Gleason 3+4 or 4+3, etc). As you will soon find out, surgeons tend to recommend surgery and radiologists tend to recommend seeds or other types of radiation....Some doctors don't advise surgery after the age of 70 or 75. Sorry you had to join our group....I would suggest finding a good surgeon (400+ surgeries, perhaps at a major teaching hospital. and schedule the surgery (which will be 6-8 weeks after your biopsy)....Assuming that the rest of your scans are OK, then most of us would suggest surgery as well, as you could always have followup "salvage" radiation but having surgery after radiation is much more difficult. Read the stickies and put up a book by Dr Walsh caled "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer"....Most of the time, Drs will recommend treatment based on their area of speciality.... surgeons will recommend surgery and radiation specialists will recommend radiation....For me at least, deciding on a treatment course was more stressful than actually finding out I had PCa. Radiation specialists will tend to recommend radiation and surgeons will tend to recommend surgery.......As you will soon find out, surgeons tend to recommend surgery and radiologists tend to recommend seeds or other types of radiation. To my case, deciding upon a treatment course was almost as stressful as the initial diagnosis....Most of us would recommend DaVinci rather than open surgery. I would suggest finding a good surgeon (400+ surgeries, perhaps at a major teaching hospital....As you are deciding on surgery vs radiation, then I suggest doing it in this order: 1) find a good, experienced surgeon with 400+ surgeries. 2)immediately book the surgery (which will be about 6-8 weeks after the biopsy)....Radiation specialists will tend to recommend radiation and surgeons will tend to recommend surgery.... For your age group, many doctors (and us here) will lean towards surgery but my no means is that etched in stone....Agree with most posters - unless the treatment will change if one or more cores was upgraded to G7 or G8, then having a second opinion is optional since you need treatment. As you are deciding on surgery vs radiation, then I suggest doing it in this order: 1) find a good, experienced surgeon with 400+ surgeries....Originally Posted by fxoptions I received my result the other day and my Dr told me the following 12/15 samples positive - Gleason 7= 3+4 positive in following Samples: right base 70%, right lateral base 15%,right mid 85%, right lateral mid 100%, right apex 50%, right lateral apex 15%, left lateral base 35%, left mid 5%, left apex 40%, apical nodule 40% Multiple cores (3) PNI (Perineural Invasion present) in 4 cores. my age is 55 Before Biopsy CT showed nodule on apex of prostate (this is why I went to urologist) DRE positive PSA 2.5 was 1.5 10 months ago I will going back to DR soon, I guess he may suggest surgery, what I am concerned about is the PNI in four cores and the nodule....If I decided on another treatment, then all I would have to do is cancel the surgery. I ended up doing the surgery, which is what most Doctors will recommend for someone our age....This thread (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ns-for-Surgeon) and the surgery sticky has some advise on how to choose a surgeon....Originally Posted by Michael F Also, in high risk post RP patients, some Medical Oncologists will recommend a short course of Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) commencing soon after surgery and prior to the start of AR....Decided to have DaVinci, turns out I had 4+3 and more widespread than the biopsy suggested. Definitely get that second opinion, and research whether a "saturation biopsy" would give you and your Dr additional data for your decision....Originally Posted by Michael F Also, in high risk post RP patients, some Medical Oncologists will recommend a short course of Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) commencing soon after surgery and prior to the start of AR. Certainly discuss this with your expert MDs....At age 57, many Drs and people here would recommend surgery.... if additional treatment is needed, it's "easier" to have "salvage" radiation after surgery than the other way around. I would suggest scheduling the surgery (there needs to be about six weeks after a biopsy before surgery)....All excellent advise, especially the scans to see if anything has spread. In the meantime, decide on a surgeon as quickly as possible and schedule the surgery (make sure the surgeon has 300+ or 400+ surgeries)....Other may suggest seeds or other treatments. But at your age, I believe most doctors would lean towards surgery....Was there a nodule on the prostate? Some doctors don't advise surgery after the age of 70 or 75....At age 57, many Drs and people here would recommend surgery.... if additional treatment is needed, it's "easier" to have "salvage" radiation after surgery than the other way around....This thread (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ns-for-Surgeon) and the surgery sticky has some advise on how to choose a surgeon. A reluctant welcome to our "club"...Turns out after surgery I was a G4+3 and my surgeon and GP use me as a textbook case to seek active treatment if there's anything beyond a G3 living in a prostate. IF you decide to go on AS, then I suggest you get every test you can which are listed in the AS sticky and have a strict "threshold" to get off AS and seek active treatment (most of us would argue that you are already past that threshold)....my age is 55 Before Biopsy CT showed nodule on apex of prostate (this is why I went to urologist) DRE positive PSA 2.5 was 1.5 10 months ago I will going back to DR soon, I guess he may suggest surgery, what I am concerned about is the PNI in four cores and the nodule. I have read this may show aggression, I will be sending my slide to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion soon, any advise on surgery that may help , open vs robotic?...He did have any "spasms" up till now...is it normal to start 6 days after surgery? If the pain is that severe, then I strongly recommend a Dr visit....Most of the time, Drs will recommend treatment based on their area of speciality.... surgeons will recommend surgery and radiation specialists will recommend radiation. Sort of surprised AS was not presented as an option....
